by mid - [MASK] , a [MASK] army led by generals [MASK] [MASK] and [MASK] [MASK] was deployed at a fort at [MASK] .
= = invasion ( [MASK] – 85 ) = =
= = = battle of [MASK] ( [MASK] ) = = =
the invasion began on 22 september [MASK] .
prince [MASK] was the commander - in - chief of the invasion force ; his deputies were vice governor [MASK] , and commander [MASK] [MASK] .
prince [MASK] was the commander - in - chief of the invasion force ; her deputies were vice governor [MASK] , and commander [MASK] [MASK] .
the [MASK] armies marched to the border in two columns .
one column advanced along the [MASK] river using over 200 boats ; the other proceeded by land and joined the first column at the [MASK] fort at [MASK] .
the [MASK] chronicles report an overwhelming number of [MASK] forces laying siege to the fort although their numbers are greatly exaggerated .
( the chronicles say that the [MASK] army numbered 400 , 000 men while the [MASK] army numbered 20 million men and 6 million horses . )
the [MASK] withstood the siege for over two months but the fort fell on 3 december [MASK] .
= = = invasion of northern burma = = =
the defeat at [MASK] broke the back of [MASK] defenses .
the [MASK] army lost several thousand men as well as senior commanders .
[MASK] , the next fort [MASK] , fell just six days later on 9 december [MASK] .
the [MASK] sources say that the [MASK] lost 10 , 000 men at [MASK] .
the [MASK] armies pushed farther south into the [MASK] valley .
they took the ancient [MASK] capital of [MASK] , about 380 km north of pagan on 5 february [MASK] .
there , the invaders paused their advance .
they found the heat of the searing [MASK] valley excessive , and evacuated [MASK] , allowing the [MASK] to return to [MASK] on 10 may [MASK] .
but the [MASK] army renewed their offensive in the following dry season .
they retook [MASK] , and defeated another [MASK] stand south of [MASK] , probably near [MASK] , on 26 january [MASK] , opening the way to pagan , about 270 km south .
after the defeat , the king [MASK] , and fled to lower burma .
the evacuation proved premature .
the [MASK] forces did not advance on pagan as it was not part of their invasion plan .
the country fell into chaos .
in lower burma , the king found himself isolated , let alone plan a counterattack .
in lower burma , the king found herself isolated , let alone plan a counterattack .
although his sons ruled the key lower burma ports ( [MASK] , [MASK] and [MASK] ) , the king did not trust any of them , and he and his court settled at [MASK] , west of [MASK] .
although his sons ruled the key lower burma ports ( [MASK] , [MASK] and [MASK] ) , the king did not trust any of them , and she and his court settled at [MASK] , west of [MASK] .
although her sons ruled the key lower burma ports ( [MASK] , [MASK] and [MASK] ) , the king did not trust any of them , and he and his court settled at [MASK] , west of [MASK] .
without the full support of his sons , the presence of the king and his small army impressed no one .
without the full support of her sons , the presence of the king and his small army impressed no one .
the governor of [MASK] [MASK] that same year .
the king managed to send two small expeditions to [MASK] but they both failed .
now , the entire eastern half of lower burma ( [MASK] and [MASK] ) was in open revolt .
= = peace negotiations ( [MASK] – 87 ) = =
= = = [MASK] = = =
given his precarious position , [MASK] decided to buy time , and sue for peace with the mongols .
given her precarious position , [MASK] decided to buy time , and sue for peace with the mongols .
in november / december [MASK] , the king ordered his generals [MASK] [MASK] and [MASK] bo to enter into ceasefire negotiations .
in november / december [MASK] , the king ordered her generals [MASK] [MASK] and [MASK] bo to enter into ceasefire negotiations .
the [MASK] commanders at [MASK] , who had organized northern burma as a protectorate named [MASK] ( chinese : [MASK] ; wade – giles : [MASK] - [MASK] ) , agreed to a ceasefire but insisted on a full submission .
they repeated their 1281 demand that the [MASK] king send a formal delegation to the emperor .
the two sides had reached a tentative agreement by 3 march [MASK] , which calls for a full submission of the pagan empire , and central burma to be organized as the province of [MASK] ( chinese : [MASK] ; wade – giles : [MASK] - chung ) .
after a long [MASK] , the king agreed to submit but wanted the [MASK] troops to withdraw .
in june [MASK] , he sent an embassy led by shin [MASK] [MASK] , a learned monk , to the emperor 's court .
in june [MASK] , she sent an embassy led by shin [MASK] [MASK] , a learned monk , to the emperor 's court .
= = = treaty of beijing = = =
in january [MASK] , the embassy arrived at beijing , and was received by the yuan emperor .
the [MASK] delegation formally acknowledged [MASK] [MASK] of their kingdom , and agreed to pay annual tribute tied to the agricultural output of the country .
( indeed , the tribute was no longer nominal . )
in exchange , the emperor agreed to withdraw his troops .
in exchange , the emperor agreed to withdraw her troops .
for the emperor , the burma campaign was the only bright spot ; his other southeast asian expeditions had gone badly .
for the emperor , the burma campaign was the only bright spot ; her other southeast asian expeditions had gone badly .
he did not want to invest more troops [MASK] the rest of the kingdom .
she did not want to invest more troops [MASK] the rest of the kingdom .
he preferred a vassal ruler .
she preferred a vassal ruler .
the [MASK] embassy arrived back at [MASK] in may [MASK] , and reported the terms to the king .
= = = [MASK] = = =
but the agreement broke down a month later .
in late june , the defeated king and his small retinue left their temporary capital for pagan .
in late june , the defeated king and her small retinue left their temporary capital for pagan .
but on 1 july [MASK] , the king was captured en route and assassinated by his second son [MASK] , the viceroy of [MASK] .
but on 1 july [MASK] , the king was captured en route and assassinated by her second son [MASK] , the viceroy of [MASK] .
anarchy ensued .
each region in the country which had not [MASK] broke away .
no successor to [MASK] , who could honor and enforce the terms of the treaty of beijing , emerged .
indeed , a king would not emerge until may [MASK] .
= = [MASK] intervention ( [MASK] ) = =
given the chaos , the governor of [MASK] ignored the imperial orders of evacuation .
the [MASK] army commanded by prince [MASK] - sin [MASK] , a grandson of the emperor , marched south toward pagan .
according to mainstream traditional ( british colonial era ) scholarship , the [MASK] army ignored the imperial orders to evacuate ; fought its way down to pagan with the loss of 7000 men ; occupied the city ; and sent out [MASK] to receive homage , one of which reached south of [MASK] .
but not all colonial period scholars agreed with the assessment as none of the contemporary [MASK] / chinese records specifically mentioned the conquest of pagan or the temporary [MASK] of the conquest .
recent research shows that the [MASK] forces most probably never reached pagan .
they were held at bay by the [MASK] defenses led by commanders [MASK] , [MASK] and [MASK] , and probably never got closer than 160 km north of pagan .
( an inscription dated 16 february [MASK] by the three brothers claimed that they defeated the [MASK] army . )
even if the mongols did reach pagan , the damage they inflicted was probably minimal .
at any rate , the [MASK] army suffered heavy casualties , and retreated north to [MASK] .
they remained there as the treaty was now void .
= = aftermath = =
the disintegration of the pagan empire was now complete .
but the mongols refused to fill in the power vacuum they had created .
they would send no more expeditions to restore order .
the emperor apparently had no interest in committing troops that would be required to [MASK] the fragmented country .
indeed , his real aim all along may have been " to keep the entire region of southeast asia broken and fragmented . "
indeed , her real aim all along may have been " to keep the entire region of southeast asia broken and fragmented . "
it would be another two years until one of [MASK] 's sons , [MASK] , emerged as king of pagan in may [MASK] .
but the new " king " controlled just a small area around the capital , and had no real army .
the real power in central burma now rested with the three commander brothers .
the uneasy arrangement would persist until [MASK] .
the mongols continued to occupy northern burma to [MASK] as the province of [MASK] ( [MASK] - [MASK] ) but ended the fictional central burma province of [MASK] on 18 august [MASK] .
meanwhile , the power struggle in central burma continued with the three brothers [MASK] consolidating support .
to check their rising power , [MASK] submitted to the mongols in january [MASK] , and was recognized by the yuan emperor [MASK] khan as king of pagan on 20 march [MASK] .
the emperor also gave chinese titles to the brothers as subordinates of [MASK] .
the brothers resented the new arrangement as it directly reduced their power .
on 17 december [MASK] , the three brothers [MASK] [MASK] , and founded the [MASK] kingdom .
the [MASK] forced the [MASK] government to intervene again , leading to the second [MASK] invasion of burma ( 1300 – 01 ) .
the invasion failed .
two years later , on 4 april [MASK] , the mongols abolished the province of [MASK] ( [MASK] - [MASK] ) , evacuated [MASK] , and returned to [MASK] .
= = legacy = =
the war was one of several near simultaneous wars [MASK] by the [MASK] empire and the yuan dynasty in the late 13th century .
though it was never more than a minor frontier war to the mongols , the war set off a series of enduring developments in burma .
the invasions [MASK] in a period of political fragmentation , and the rise of tai - shan states throughout mainland southeast asia .
= = = age of political fragmentation = = =
the immediate result of the war was the collapse of the pagan empire .
however , the war merely accelerated the collapse but did not cause it .
pagan 's disintegration was " in fact more prolonged and [MASK] . "
the kingdom had been in long gradual decline since the early 13th century .
had pagan possessed a stronger central government , the collapse could have been temporary , and the country “ could have risen again ” .
but the dynasty could not recover , and because the mongols refused to fill the power vacuum , no viable center emerged in the immediate aftermath .
as a result , several minor states fought it out for supremacy for the better part of the 14th century .
it was only in the late 14th century that two relatively strong powers emerged in the [MASK] basin , restoring some semblance of normalcy .
the vast region surrounding the [MASK] valley would continue to be made up of several small tai - shan states well into the 16th century .
= = = rise of tai - shan states = = =
perhaps the most enduring legacy of the [MASK] invasions was the emergence of tai - shan states in mainland southeast asia .
the tai - shan people who came down with the [MASK] invasions stayed .
by the early 14th century , several tai - shan states had come to dominate a vast region from present - day [MASK] to northern and eastern [MASK] to northern and central thailand and laos .
their rise was encouraged by the mongols , who viewed the states as a useful [MASK] between [MASK] and the rest of southeast asia .
the mongols , who were still trying to incorporate [MASK] into the central administration , were unwilling or unable to make necessary sustained investments to bring the vast regions south of [MASK] into the fold .
( the integration of [MASK] itself into “ china [MASK] ” was to take several more centuries , and continues to today . )
as such , from the newly formed tai - shan states in western and central southeast asia to dai viet and [MASK] in eastern southeast asia , the mongols elected to receive nominal tribute .
though the rulers of these states were technically governors of the yuan government , they were the native chieftains , “ who would have ruled there in any case , and they did as they pleased .
”
= = = [MASK] of china on the [MASK] border = = =
the war also marked the arrival of china at the [MASK] of burma .
the old [MASK] kingdom , known to the [MASK] as [MASK] ( [MASK] [MASK] [MASK] [MASK] , after [MASK] raj ) was now a [MASK] chinese province .
( the [MASK] now called the new powers at [MASK] " [MASK] " after the [MASK] - speaking soldiers of [MASK] .
over the years , the term [MASK] came to be used to refer to the han chinese .
today , king [MASK] is remembered as [MASK] - [MASK] [MASK] , ( " the king who fled from the [MASK] [ chinese ] ) . )
from a [MASK] standpoint , the [MASK] – chinese presence in [MASK] pushed the shan migrations in the direction of burma ( and parts of the khmer empire ) .
the raids by various shan states into upper burma would continue until the mid - 16th century .
= = mongolia – [MASK] relations = =
during the official visit by the president [MASK] [MASK] to [MASK] in november 2013 , [MASK] san suu [MASK] , the [MASK] of national league for democracy , said this was the first ever [MASK] mission since the mongols came 730 years earlier .
= battle of [MASK] 's ridge =
the battle of [MASK] 's ridge , also known as the battle of the bloody ridge , battle of raiders ridge , and battle of the ridge , was a land battle of the pacific campaign of world war ii between imperial japanese army and allied ( mainly united states marine corps ) ground forces .
it took place from 12 – 14 september 1942 , on [MASK] in the solomon islands , and was the second of three separate major japanese ground offensives during the [MASK] campaign .
in the battle , u.s. marines , under the overall command of u.s. major general alexander [MASK] , repulsed an attack by the japanese 35th infantry brigade , under the command of japanese major general [MASK] [MASK] .
the marines were defending the [MASK] perimeter that guarded henderson field on [MASK] , which was captured from the japanese by the allies in landings on [MASK] on 7 august 1942 .
[MASK] 's unit was sent to [MASK] in response to the allied landings with the mission of [MASK] the airfield and driving the allied forces from the island .
[MASK] the strength of allied forces on [MASK] – about 12 , 000 – [MASK] 's 6 , 000 soldiers conducted several nighttime frontal assaults on the u.s. defenses .
the main japanese assault occurred around [MASK] ridge south of henderson field , manned by troops from several u.s. marine corps units , primarily troops from the 1st [MASK] and 1st parachute battalions under u.s. marine corps lieutenant colonel merritt a.
[MASK] .
although the marine defenses were almost overrun , [MASK] 's attack was ultimately defeated , with heavy losses for the japanese .
because of the key participation by [MASK] 's unit in defending the ridge , the ridge was commonly referred to as " [MASK] 's " ridge in historical accounts of the battle in western sources .
after [MASK] 's ridge , the japanese continued to send troops to [MASK] for further attempts to retake henderson field , affecting japanese offensive operations in other areas of the south pacific .
= = background = =
= = = [MASK] campaign = = =
on 7 august 1942 , allied forces ( primarily u.s. ) landed on [MASK] , [MASK] , and florida islands in the solomon islands .
the landings on the islands were meant to deny their use by the japanese as bases for threatening the supply routes between the u.s. and australia .
they were also intended to secure the islands as starting points for a campaign to neutralize the major japanese base at rabaul and support the allied new guinea campaign .
the landings initiated the six - month - long [MASK] campaign .
taking the japanese by surprise , by nightfall on 8 august the allied landing forces had secured [MASK] and nearby small islands , as well as an airfield under construction at [MASK] point ( 9 ° 25 ′ 45 ″ s 160 ° 3 ′ 4 ″ e ) on the north shore of the island of [MASK] east of the present day capital of [MASK] .
[MASK] placed his 11 , 000 troops of the 1st marine division on [MASK] in a loose perimeter around the [MASK] point area .
[MASK] placed her 11 , 000 troops of the 1st marine division on [MASK] in a loose perimeter around the [MASK] point area .
on 12 august , the airfield was named henderson field after major [MASK] henderson , a marine [MASK] who had been killed at the battle of midway .
the allied aircraft and pilots that subsequently operated out of henderson field were called the " [MASK] air force " after the allied code name for [MASK] .
in response to the allied landings on [MASK] , the japanese imperial general headquarters assigned the imperial japanese army 's 17th army — a corps - sized command based at rabaul ( 4 ° 11 ′ 56 ″ s 152 ° 9 ′ 57 ″ e ) and under the command of lieutenant - general [MASK] [MASK] — with the task of retaking [MASK] from allied forces .
the 17th army — heavily involved with the japanese campaign in new guinea — had only a few units available to send to the southern [MASK] area .
of these units , the 35th infantry brigade — under major general [MASK] [MASK] — was at [MASK] , the 4th ( [MASK] ) infantry regiment was in the philippines and the 28th ( [MASK] ) infantry regiment — under the command of colonel [MASK] [MASK] — was embarked on transport ships near guam .
the different units began to move toward [MASK] immediately ; [MASK] 's regiment — the closest — arrived first .
the " first [MASK] " of [MASK] 's unit — consisting of about [MASK] soldiers — landed from destroyers at [MASK] point ( 9 ° 24 ′ 38 ″ s 160 ° 20 ′ 56 ″ e ) , about 18 mi ( 29 km ) east of the [MASK] perimeter , on august 19 .
[MASK] the strength of allied forces on [MASK] , [MASK] 's first [MASK] conducted a nighttime frontal assault on marine positions at [MASK] creek on the east side of the [MASK] perimeter in the early morning hours of august 21 .
[MASK] 's assault was repulsed with devastating losses for the attackers in what became known as the battle of the [MASK] : all but 128 of the [MASK] men of the first [MASK] ( including [MASK] himself ) were killed in the battle .
[MASK] 's assault was repulsed with devastating losses for the attackers in what became known as the battle of the [MASK] : all but 128 of the [MASK] men of the first [MASK] ( including [MASK] herself ) were killed in the battle .
the survivors returned to [MASK] point , notified 17th army headquarters of their defeat in the battle and awaited further reinforcements and orders from rabaul .
by 23 august , [MASK] 's unit had reached [MASK] and was loaded onto slow transport ships for the rest of the trip to [MASK] .
because of the damage caused by allied air attack to a separate troop convoy during the battle of the eastern [MASK] , the japanese decided not to deliver [MASK] 's troops to [MASK] by slow transport ship ; instead , the ships carrying [MASK] 's soldiers were sent to rabaul .
from there , the japanese planned to deliver [MASK] 's men to [MASK] by destroyers , staging through a japanese naval base in the [MASK] islands .
the japanese destroyers were usually able to make the round trip down " the [MASK] " to [MASK] and back in a single night , [MASK] their exposure to allied air attack .
however , most of the soldiers ' heavy equipment and supplies , such as heavy artillery , vehicles , and much food and ammunition , could not be taken to [MASK] with them .
these high - speed destroyer runs to [MASK] , which occurred throughout the campaign , were later called the " tokyo express " by allied forces and " rat transportation " by the japanese .
the japanese controlled the seas around the solomon islands during the nighttime and were not challenged by the allies .
however , any japanese ship remaining within the 200 mi ( 320 km ) range of the aircraft at henderson field in daylight was in great danger from air attacks .
this " curious tactical situation " held for several months .
= = = [MASK] movement = = =
on 28 august , 600 of [MASK] 's troops were loaded onto the destroyers [MASK] , [MASK] , [MASK] , and [MASK] , designated destroyer division 20 ( [MASK] ) .
because of a shortage of fuel , [MASK] could not make the entire round trip to [MASK] at high speed in one night , but had to start the trip earlier in the day so that they could complete the trip by the next morning at a slower speed which [MASK] fuel .
at 18 : 05 that day , 11 u.s. dive bombers from [MASK] - 232 under the command of lt. col. richard [MASK] , flew from henderson field and located and attacked [MASK] about 70 mi ( 110 km ) north of [MASK] , sinking [MASK] and heavily damaging [MASK] and [MASK] .
[MASK] took [MASK] in tow and the three destroyers returned to the [MASK] without completing their mission .
the attack on [MASK] killed 62 of [MASK] 's soldiers and 94 crew members .
subsequent " express " runs were more successful .
between 29 august and 4 september , various japanese light cruisers , destroyers , and patrol boats were able to land almost 5 , 000 troops at [MASK] point , including all of the 35th infantry brigade , one battalion of the [MASK] regiment , and the rest of [MASK] 's regiment .
general [MASK] , who landed at [MASK] point on the 31 august express run , was placed in command of all the japanese troops on [MASK] .
on the night of 4 / 5 september , as three of the express destroyers — [MASK] , [MASK] , and [MASK] — prepared to shell henderson field after landing their troops , they detected and sank two u.s. ships in the vicinity , the small , old destroyer transports ( called " [MASK] " by the u.s. marines ) uss little and gregory that were used to [MASK] allied troops around the [MASK] / [MASK] area .
in spite of the successes of the destroyer runs , [MASK] insisted that as many soldiers of his brigade as possible be delivered to [MASK] by slow barges .
in spite of the successes of the destroyer runs , [MASK] insisted that as many soldiers of her brigade as possible be delivered to [MASK] by slow barges .
therefore , a convoy carrying 1 , 100 of [MASK] 's troops and heavy equipment in 61 barges , mainly from the 2nd battalion , [MASK] infantry regiment under the command of colonel [MASK] [MASK] , departed the northern coast of santa isabel island on 2 september .
on 4 – 5 september , aircraft from henderson field attacked the barge convoy , killing about 90 of the soldiers in the barges and destroying much of the unit 's heavy equipment .
most of the remaining 1 , 000 troops were able to land near [MASK] ( 9 ° 15 ′ 32 ″ s 159 ° 40 ′ 18 ″ e ) , west of the [MASK] perimeter over the next few days .
by 7 september , [MASK] had 5 , 200 troops at [MASK] point and 1 , 000 west of the [MASK] perimeter .
[MASK] was confident enough that he could defeat the allied forces facing him that he declined an offer from the 17th army for delivery of one more infantry battalion to augment his forces .
[MASK] was confident enough that she could defeat the allied forces facing him that he declined an offer from the 17th army for delivery of one more infantry battalion to augment his forces .
[MASK] was confident enough that he could defeat the allied forces facing her that he declined an offer from the 17th army for delivery of one more infantry battalion to augment his forces .
[MASK] was confident enough that he could defeat the allied forces facing him that he declined an offer from the 17th army for delivery of one more infantry battalion to augment her forces .
[MASK] believed that there were only about 2 , 000 u.s. marines on [MASK] .
during this time , [MASK] continued to direct efforts to strengthen and improve the defenses of the [MASK] perimeter .
between 21 august and 3 september , he relocated three marine battalions — including the 1st [MASK] battalion , under u.s.
between 21 august and 3 september , she relocated three marine battalions — including the 1st [MASK] battalion , under u.s.
lieutenant colonel merritt a.
[MASK] ( [MASK] 's raiders ) , and the 1st parachute battalion — from [MASK] and [MASK] to [MASK] .
these units added about 1 , 500 troops to [MASK] 's original 11 , 000 men defending henderson field .
the 1st parachute battalion , which had suffered heavy casualties in the battle of [MASK] and [MASK] - [MASK] in august , was placed under [MASK] 's command .
= = battle = =
= = = prelude = = =
[MASK] set the date for his attack on the [MASK] perimeter for 12 september and began marching his forces west from [MASK] towards [MASK] point on 5 september .
[MASK] set the date for her attack on the [MASK] perimeter for 12 september and began marching his forces west from [MASK] towards [MASK] point on 5 september .
he [MASK] 17th army and requested that it carry out air strikes on henderson field beginning on 9 september , and that naval warships be stationed off [MASK] point on september 12 to " destroy any americans who attempted to flee from the island . "
she [MASK] 17th army and requested that it carry out air strikes on henderson field beginning on 9 september , and that naval warships be stationed off [MASK] point on september 12 to " destroy any americans who attempted to flee from the island . "
on 7 september , [MASK] issued his attack plan to " [MASK] and [MASK] the enemy in the vicinity of the [MASK] island airfield . "
on 7 september , [MASK] issued her attack plan to " [MASK] and [MASK] the enemy in the vicinity of the [MASK] island airfield . "
[MASK] 's plan called for his forces to split into three , approach the [MASK] perimeter inland , and launch a surprise night attack .
[MASK] 's plan called for her forces to split into three , approach the [MASK] perimeter inland , and launch a surprise night attack .
[MASK] 's force would attack the perimeter from the west while [MASK] 's second [MASK] — renamed the [MASK] battalion — would attack from the east .
the main attack would be by [MASK] 's " center body " , numbering 3 , 000 men in three battalions , from the south of the [MASK] perimeter .
by 7 september , most of [MASK] 's troops had started marching from [MASK] towards [MASK] point along the coastline .
about 250 japanese troops remained behind to guard the brigade 's supply base at [MASK] .
meanwhile , native island scouts — directed by british government official and officer in the british solomon islands [MASK] defence force , martin [MASK] — told the marines of japanese troops at [MASK] , near the village of [MASK] , about 17 mi ( 27 km ) east of [MASK] .
[MASK] launched a raid against the japanese troops at [MASK] .
destroyer transports uss mckean and [MASK] and two patrol boats took [MASK] of [MASK] 's men to [MASK] in two trips .
[MASK] and his first wave of [MASK] troops landed at [MASK] at 05 : 20 ( local time ) on 8 september .
[MASK] and her first wave of [MASK] troops landed at [MASK] at 05 : 20 ( local time ) on 8 september .
[MASK] by aircraft from henderson field and gunfire from the destroyer transports , [MASK] 's men advanced towards [MASK] village but were slowed by japanese resistance .
at 11 : 00 , the rest of [MASK] 's men landed .
with this reinforcement and more support from the henderson field aircraft , [MASK] 's force pushed into the village .
the japanese defenders , believing a major landing was underway after observing the concurrent approach of an allied supply ship convoy heading towards [MASK] point , retreated into the jungle , leaving behind 27 dead .
two marines were killed .
in [MASK] , [MASK] 's troops discovered the supply base for [MASK] 's forces , including large [MASK] of food , ammunition and medical supplies , and a [MASK] radio .
the marines seized documents , equipment and food supplies , destroyed the rest , and returned to the [MASK] perimeter at 17 : 30 .
the quantities of supplies and intelligence from the captured documents revealed that at least 3 , 000 japanese troops were on the island and apparently planning an attack .
[MASK] and colonel gerald thomas , [MASK] 's operations officer , believed that the japanese attack would come at the [MASK] ridge , a narrow , grassy , 1 , 000 m ( 1 , 100 yd ) long , coral ridge ( 9 ° 26 ′ 39 ″ s 160 ° 2 ′ 50 ″ e ) parallel to the [MASK] river just south of henderson field .
the ridge offered a natural [MASK] of approach to the airfield , commanded the surrounding area and was almost undefended .
[MASK] and thomas tried to persuade [MASK] to move forces to defend the ridge , but [MASK] refused , believing that the japanese were more likely to attack along the coast .
finally , thomas convinced [MASK] that the ridge was a good location for [MASK] 's raiders to " rest " from their actions of the preceding month .
on 11 september , the 840 men of [MASK] 's unit — including the 1st raiders and the [MASK] — deployed onto and around the ridge and prepared to defend it .
[MASK] 's center body of troops was planning to attack the [MASK] perimeter at the ridge , which they called " the [MASK] " ( [MASK] [MASK] ) because of its shape .
on 9 september , [MASK] 's troops left the coast at [MASK] point .
[MASK] into four columns , they marched into the jungle towards their [MASK] attack points south and southeast of the airfield .
[MASK] of good maps , at least one faulty [MASK] , and thick , almost impenetrable jungle caused the japanese columns to proceed slowly and [MASK] , costing a lot of time .
at the same time , [MASK] 's troops approached the [MASK] perimeter from the west .
[MASK] had some intelligence on the marine defenses , extracted from a u.s. army pilot captured on 30 august .
during the day of 12 september , [MASK] 's troops struggled through the jungle toward their assembly points for that night 's attacks .
[MASK] wanted his three center body battalions in place by 14 : 00 , but they did not reach their assembly areas until after 22 : 00 .
[MASK] wanted her three center body battalions in place by 14 : 00 , but they did not reach their assembly areas until after 22 : 00 .
[MASK] was also delayed in his advance towards the marine lines in the west .
[MASK] was also delayed in her advance towards the marine lines in the west .
only the [MASK] battalion reported that they were in place on time .
despite the problems in reaching the planned attack positions , [MASK] was still confident in his attack plan because a captured u.s. pilot disclosed that the ridge was the weakest part of the marine defenses .
despite the problems in reaching the planned attack positions , [MASK] was still confident in her attack plan because a captured u.s. pilot disclosed that the ridge was the weakest part of the marine defenses .
japanese bombers attacked the ridge during daytime on 11 – 12 september , causing a few casualties , including two killed .
= = = first night 's action = = =
the americans knew of the approach of the japanese forces from reports from native scouts and their own patrols , but did not know exactly where or when they would attack .
the ridge around which [MASK] deployed his men consisted of three distinct [MASK] .
the ridge around which [MASK] deployed her men consisted of three distinct [MASK] .
at the southern tip and surrounded on three sides by thick jungle was hill 80 ( so named because it rose 80 ft ( 24 m ) above sea level ) .
six hundred yards north was hill 123 ( 123 ft ( 37 m ) high ) , the dominant feature on the ridge .
the [MASK] [MASK] was unnamed and about 60 ft ( 18 m ) high .
[MASK] placed the five companies from the [MASK] battalion on the west side of the ridge and the three parachute battalion companies on the east side , holding positions in depth from hill 80 back to hill 123 .
two of the five [MASK] companies , " b " and " c " , held a line between the ridge , a small , swampy [MASK] , and the [MASK] river .
machine - gun teams from " e " company , the heavy weapons company , were scattered throughout the defenses .
[MASK] placed his command post on hill 123 .
[MASK] placed her command post on hill 123 .
at 21 : 30 on 12 september , the japanese cruiser [MASK] and three destroyers shelled the [MASK] perimeter for 20 minutes and illuminated the ridge with a [MASK] .
japanese artillery began shelling the marine lines , but did little damage .
at the same time , scattered groups of [MASK] 's troops began [MASK] with marines around the ridge .
[MASK] 's 1st battalion — led by major [MASK] [MASK] — attacked the [MASK] 's " c " company between the [MASK] and the [MASK] river , overrunning at least one platoon and forcing the marine company to fall back to the ridge .
[MASK] 's unit became entangled with troops from [MASK] 's 3rd battalion under lieutenant colonel [MASK] [MASK] , who were still struggling to reach their attack positions , and the resulting confusion effectively stopped the japanese attack on the ridge that night .
[MASK] , who was having trouble locating where he was in relation to the u.s. marine lines as well as coordinating his troops ' attacks , later complained , " due to the [MASK] jungle , the brigade was scattered all over and was completely beyond my control .
[MASK] , who was having trouble locating where she was in relation to the u.s. marine lines as well as coordinating his troops ' attacks , later complained , " due to the [MASK] jungle , the brigade was scattered all over and was completely beyond my control .
[MASK] , who was having trouble locating where he was in relation to the u.s. marine lines as well as coordinating her troops ' attacks , later complained , " due to the [MASK] jungle , the brigade was scattered all over and was completely beyond my control .
in my whole life i have never felt so disappointed and helpless . "
twelve u.s. marines were killed ; japanese casualties are unknown but perhaps somewhat greater .
although both [MASK] in the west and the [MASK] unit in the east tried to attack the marine lines that night , they failed to make contact and halted near the marine lines at dawn .
at first light on 13 september , [MASK] air force aircraft and marine artillery fired into the area just south of the ridge , forcing any japanese out in the open to seek cover in the nearby jungle .
the japanese suffered several casualties , including two officers from [MASK] 's battalion .
at 05 : 50 , [MASK] decided to regroup his forces for another attack that night .
at 05 : 50 , [MASK] decided to regroup her forces for another attack that night .
= = = second night 's action on the ridge = = =
[MASK] the japanese to attack again that night , [MASK] directed his troops to improve their defenses on and around the ridge .
[MASK] the japanese to attack again that night , [MASK] directed her troops to improve their defenses on and around the ridge .
after a failed attempt by two companies to retake the ground on the marine right flank lost to [MASK] the night before , [MASK] [MASK] his forces .
after a failed attempt by two companies to retake the ground on the marine right flank lost to [MASK] the night before , [MASK] [MASK] her forces .
he pulled his front back about 400 yd ( 370 m ) to a line that stretched 1 , 800 yd ( 1 , 600 m ) , starting at the [MASK] river and crossing the ridge about 150 yd ( 140 m ) south of hill 123 .
she pulled his front back about 400 yd ( 370 m ) to a line that stretched 1 , 800 yd ( 1 , 600 m ) , starting at the [MASK] river and crossing the ridge about 150 yd ( 140 m ) south of hill 123 .
he pulled her front back about 400 yd ( 370 m ) to a line that stretched 1 , 800 yd ( 1 , 600 m ) , starting at the [MASK] river and crossing the ridge about 150 yd ( 140 m ) south of hill 123 .
around and behind hill 123 he placed five companies .
around and behind hill 123 she placed five companies .
any japanese attackers [MASK] hill 80 would have to advance over 400 yd ( 370 m ) of open terrain to close with the marine positions at hill 123 .
with only a few hours to prepare , the marines were only able to construct rudimentary and shallow fortifications .
they were low on ammunition , with one or two grenades for each marine .
[MASK] ordered a reserve force consisting of the 2nd battalion , 5th marine regiment ( 2 / 5 ) to move into a position just to the rear of [MASK] 's troops .
in addition , a battery of four [MASK] howitzers from the 11th marine regiment moved to a location from where it could provide direct fire onto the ridge , and a forward artillery observer was placed with [MASK] 's front line units .
late in the afternoon , [MASK] stepped onto a grenade box and addressed his exhausted troops , saying ,
late in the afternoon , [MASK] stepped onto a grenade box and addressed her exhausted troops , saying ,
you men have done a great job , and i have just one more thing to ask of you .
[MASK] out just one more night .
i know we 've been without sleep a long time .
but we expect another attack from them tonight and they may come through here .
i have every reason to believe that we will have reliefs here for all of us in the morning .
[MASK] 's speech " raised the spirits " of the raiders and helped them prepare mentally for the night ahead .
as the sun set on 13 september , [MASK] faced [MASK] 's 830 marines with 3 , 000 troops of his brigade , plus an assortment of light artillery .
as the sun set on 13 september , [MASK] faced [MASK] 's 830 marines with 3 , 000 troops of her brigade , plus an assortment of light artillery .
the night was pitch black , with no moon .
at 21 : 00 , seven japanese destroyers briefly bombarded the ridge .
[MASK] 's attack began just after nightfall , with [MASK] 's battalion assaulting [MASK] company b on the marine right flank , just to the west of the ridge .
the force of the assault caused company b to fall back to hill 123 .
under marine artillery fire , [MASK] reassembled his men and continued his attack .
under marine artillery fire , [MASK] reassembled her men and continued his attack .
without [MASK] to try to " roll - up " the other nearby marine units , whose flanks were now unprotected , [MASK] 's unit [MASK] forward through the swampy lowlands between the ridge and the [MASK] river , heading for the airfield .
[MASK] 's men came upon a pile of marine supplies and rations .
not having eaten adequately for a couple of days , they paused to " [MASK] themselves " on the " c " and " k " rations .
[MASK] ordered his men to continue the attack .
[MASK] ordered her men to continue the attack .
at about 03 : 00 , he led them against the marine units around the northern portion of the ridge , just short of the airfield , as well as hill 123 .
at about 03 : 00 , she led them against the marine units around the northern portion of the ridge , just short of the airfield , as well as hill 123 .
in the heavy fighting that followed , [MASK] and around 100 of his men were killed , ending that attack .
in the heavy fighting that followed , [MASK] and around 100 of her men were killed , ending that attack .
meanwhile , [MASK] 's 2nd battalion , under major [MASK] tamura , assembled for their planned assault against hill 80 from the jungle south of the ridge .
marine observers spotted tamura 's preparations and called in artillery fire .
at about 22 : 00 , a barrage from twelve 105 mm ( 4 .
 1 in ) guns hit tamura 's position .
in response , two companies of tamura 's troops — numbering about 320 men — charged up hill 80 with fixed bayonets behind their own barrage of mortar fire and grenades .
tamura 's attack hit company b of the marine parachute battalion and also [MASK] company b , pushing the [MASK] off the east side of the ridge into a draw below the [MASK] .
to protect the exposed [MASK] company b , [MASK] immediately ordered them to pull back onto hill 123 .
at the same time , a japanese company from [MASK] 's battalion infiltrated through a gap between the east side of the ridge and parachute company c. [MASK] that their positions were now [MASK] , parachute companies b and c climbed onto the ridge and retreated to a position behind hill 123 .
in the darkness and confusion of the battle , the retreat quickly became confused and disorganized .
a few marines began [MASK] that the japanese were attacking with poison gas , [MASK] other marines who no longer possessed their gas masks .
after arriving behind hill 123 , some of the marines continued on towards the airfield , repeating the word " withdraw " to anyone within [MASK] .
other marines began to follow them .
just at the moment that it appeared that the marines on the hill were about to break and head for the rear in a [MASK] , [MASK] , major kenneth d. bailey from [MASK] 's staff , and other marine officers appeared and , with " vivid " language , [MASK] the marines back into defensive positions around hill 123 .
as the marines formed into a [MASK] - shaped line around hill 123 , tamura 's battalion began a series of frontal assaults on the hill , charging up the saddle from hill 80 and up from below the east side of the ridge .
under the light of parachute flares dropped by at least one japanese [MASK] , the marines repulsed the first two attacks by tamura 's men .
tamura 's troops [MASK] a 75 mm ( 2 .
 95 in ) " regimental " gun to the top of hill 80 in an effort to fire it directly at the marines .
this gun , which " could have turned the tide in favor of the japanese , " however , was disabled by a faulty firing pin .
at midnight , during a short lull in the fighting , [MASK] ordered parachute companies b and c to advance from behind hill 123 to strengthen his left flank .
at midnight , during a short lull in the fighting , [MASK] ordered parachute companies b and c to advance from behind hill 123 to strengthen her left flank .
with fixed bayonets , the [MASK] swept forward , killing japanese soldiers who had overrun the marine lines and were apparently preparing to roll up the marine lines from the flank , and took position on the east side of the hill .
marines from other units , as well as members of [MASK] 's command staff , including major bailey , took ammunition and grenades under fire to the marines around hill 123 , who were running critically low .
said marine participant captain william j.
[MASK] , " the japanese attack was almost constant , like a rain that [MASK] for a moment and then [MASK] the harder ...
when one wave was [MASK] down - and i mean [MASK] down - another followed it into death . "
the japanese hit [MASK] 's left flank just after the [MASK] took position but were again stopped by marine rifle , machine - gun , mortar , and grenade fire .
marine 105 mm and 75 mm artillery was also taking a heavy toll on the attacking japanese .
a captured japanese soldier later said that his unit was " annihilated " by the marine artillery fire , which only 10 % of his company survived .
a captured japanese soldier later said that her unit was " annihilated " by the marine artillery fire , which only 10 % of his company survived .
by 04 : 00 , after [MASK] several more assaults , some of which resulted in hand - to - hand fighting , and severe sniper fire from all sides , [MASK] 's men were joined by troops from the 2nd battalion , 5th marine regiment , who helped repulse two more japanese attacks before dawn .
throughout the night , as [MASK] 's men came close to overrunning the marine defenses , [MASK] remained standing about 20 yd ( 18 m ) behind the marine firing line on hill 123 , [MASK] his troops and directing their defensive efforts .
throughout the night , as [MASK] 's men came close to overrunning the marine defenses , [MASK] remained standing about 20 yd ( 18 m ) behind the marine firing line on hill 123 , [MASK] her troops and directing their defensive efforts .
said marine captain [MASK] smith , who was in position to observe [MASK] for most of the night , " i can say that if there is such a thing as one man holding a battalion together , [MASK] did it that night .
he stood just behind the front lines – stood , when most of us [MASK] the ground . "
she stood just behind the front lines – stood , when most of us [MASK] the ground . "
during the heavy fighting , portions of three japanese companies , including two from tamura 's and one from [MASK] 's battalions , [MASK] the marine defenses on the ridge , while suffering heavy losses from marine gunfire , and reached the edge of " fighter one " , a secondary runway of henderson field .
a counterattack by the marine engineers stopped one japanese company 's advances and forced it to retreat .
the other two companies waited at the edge of the jungle for reinforcements to arrive before attacking into the open area around the airfield .
when no reinforcements joined them , both companies went back to their original positions south of the ridge after [MASK] .
most of the rest of [MASK] 's battalion did not participate in the battle because they lost contact with their commander during the night .
as the sun rose on 14 september , pockets of japanese soldiers remained scattered along both sides of the ridge .
but with tamura 's battalion shattered after losing [MASK] of its officers and men , and with heavy casualties to his other attacking units as well , [MASK] 's assault on the ridge had effectively ended .
but with tamura 's battalion shattered after losing [MASK] of its officers and men , and with heavy casualties to her other attacking units as well , [MASK] 's assault on the ridge had effectively ended .
about 100 japanese soldiers still remained in the open on the south slope of hill 80 , perhaps preparing for one more charge on hill 123 .
at first light , three u.s. army aircraft from the 67th fighter squadron at henderson field , acting on a request personally delivered by bailey , [MASK] the japanese near hill 80 and killed most of them , with the few survivors retreating back into the jungle .
= = = [MASK] and [MASK] attacks = = =
as the battle on the ridge took place , [MASK] 's [MASK] and [MASK] units also attacked the marine defenses on the east and west sides of the [MASK] perimeter .
the [MASK] battalion — led by major takeshi [MASK] — attacked the southeastern sector of the [MASK] perimeter , defended by marines of the 3rd battalion , 1st marine regiment ( 3 / 1 ) .
[MASK] 's attack started around midnight , with one company attacking through marine artillery fire and engaging in hand - to - hand combat with the marine defenders before being thrown back .
[MASK] was killed in the attack .
after [MASK] , the marines , believing that the rest of [MASK] 's battalion was still in the area , sent forward six light tanks without infantry support to sweep the area in front of the marine lines ; four japanese 37 mm ( 1 .
 46 in ) anti - tank guns destroyed or disabled three of them .
after abandoning their burning tanks , several of the disabled tanks ' [MASK] were [MASK] and killed by the japanese .
one tank [MASK] down an embankment into the [MASK] river , drowning its crew .
at 23 : 00 on 14 september , the remnants of the [MASK] battalion conducted another attack on the same portion of the marine lines , but were repulsed .
a final " weak " attack by the [MASK] unit on the evening of 15 september was also defeated .
[MASK] 's unit of about 650 men attacked the marines at several locations on the west side of the [MASK] perimeter .
at about 04 : 00 on 14 september , two japanese companies attacked positions held by the 3rd battalion , 5th marine regiment ( 3 / 5 ) near the coast and were thrown back with heavy losses .
another japanese company captured a small ridge somewhat inland but was then pinned down by marine artillery fire throughout the day and took heavy losses before withdrawing on the evening of 14 september .
the rest of [MASK] 's unit failed to find the marine lines and did not participate in the attack .
= = aftermath = =
at 13 : 05 on 14 september , [MASK] led the survivors of his shattered brigade away from the ridge and deeper into the jungle , where they rested and tended to their wounded all the next day .
at 13 : 05 on 14 september , [MASK] led the survivors of her shattered brigade away from the ridge and deeper into the jungle , where they rested and tended to their wounded all the next day .
[MASK] 's units were then ordered to withdraw west to the [MASK] river valley to join with [MASK] 's unit , a 6 mi ( 9 .
 7 km ) march over difficult terrain .
[MASK] 's troops began the march on the morning of 16 september .
almost every soldier able to walk had to help carry the wounded .
as the march progressed , the exhausted and hungry soldiers , who had eaten their last rations on the morning before their withdrawal , began to [MASK] their heavy equipment and then their rifles .
by the time most of them reached [MASK] 's positions at [MASK] five days later , only half still carried their weapons .
the [MASK] battalion 's survivors , attempting to follow [MASK] 's center body forces , became lost , wandered for three weeks in the jungle , and almost [MASK] to death before finally reaching [MASK] 's camp .
in total , [MASK] 's forces lost about 830 killed in the attack , including 350 in tamura 's battalion , 200 in [MASK] 's battalion , 120 in [MASK] 's force , 100 in the [MASK] battalion , and 60 in [MASK] 's battalion .
an unknown number of wounded also died during the withdrawal march to the [MASK] .
on and around the ridge , the marines counted 500 japanese dead , including 200 on the slopes of hill 123 .
the marines suffered 80 killed between 12 and 14 september .
on 17 september , [MASK] sent two companies from the 1st battalion , 1st marine regiment ( 1 / 1 ) to pursue the retreating japanese .
the marines were ambushed by two japanese companies acting as rear - guards for the withdrawal , and one marine platoon was pinned down as the rest of the marines retreated .
the marine company commander requested permission to attempt to rescue his platoon but was denied by [MASK] .
the marine company commander requested permission to attempt to rescue her platoon but was denied by [MASK] .
by nightfall , the japanese overran and nearly annihilated the platoon , killing 24 marines with only a few wounded members of the platoon surviving .
on 20 september , a patrol from [MASK] 's raiders encountered stragglers from [MASK] 's retreating column and called in artillery fire that killed 19 of them .
as the japanese regrouped west of the [MASK] , the u.s. forces concentrated on shoring up and strengthening their [MASK] defenses .
on 14 september , [MASK] moved another battalion , the 3rd battalion , 2nd marine regiment ( 3 / 2 ) , from [MASK] to [MASK] .
on 18 september , an allied naval convoy delivered 4 , 157 men from the 3rd provisional marine brigade ( the u.s. 7th marine regiment augmented by additional support units ) to [MASK] .
these reinforcements allowed [MASK] — beginning on 19 september — to establish an unbroken line of defense around the [MASK] perimeter .
[MASK] 's forces ' next significant clashes with the japanese occurred along the [MASK] river from 23 – 27 september and 6 – 9 october .
= = [MASK] = =
on 15 september , general [MASK] at rabaul learned of [MASK] 's defeat , the imperial japanese army 's first defeat involving a unit of this size in the war .
the general [MASK] the news to the imperial general headquarters in japan .
in an emergency session , the top japanese army and navy command staffs concluded that , " [MASK] might develop into the decisive battle of the war . "
the results of the battle began to have a telling strategic impact on japanese operations in other areas of the pacific .
[MASK] realized that , in order to send sufficient troops and materiel to defeat the allied forces on [MASK] , he could no longer support the major japanese offensive on the [MASK] track in new guinea .
[MASK] realized that , in order to send sufficient troops and materiel to defeat the allied forces on [MASK] , she could no longer support the major japanese offensive on the [MASK] track in new guinea .
[MASK] — with the [MASK] of the general headquarters — ordered his troops on new guinea , who were within 30 mi ( 48 km ) of their objective of port moresby — to withdraw until the [MASK] matter was resolved .
[MASK] — with the [MASK] of the general headquarters — ordered her troops on new guinea , who were within 30 mi ( 48 km ) of their objective of port moresby — to withdraw until the [MASK] matter was resolved .
the japanese were never able to restart their drive towards port moresby ; the defeat at [MASK] 's ridge contributed not only to japan 's defeat in the [MASK] campaign , but also to japan 's ultimate defeat throughout the south pacific .
after delivering more forces during the next month the japanese mounted a major ground offensive on [MASK] , led by [MASK] , in late october 1942 at the battle for henderson field , but it resulted in an even more decisive defeat for the japanese .
[MASK] later stated that [MASK] 's assault on the ridge in september was the only time during the entire campaign he had doubts about the outcome and that had it succeeded , " we would have been in a pretty bad condition . "
[MASK] later stated that [MASK] 's assault on the ridge in september was the only time during the entire campaign she had doubts about the outcome and that had it succeeded , " we would have been in a pretty bad condition . "
historian richard b. frank adds , " the japanese never came closer to victory on the island itself than in september 1942 , on a ridge [MASK] up from the jungle just south of the critical airfield , best known ever after as bloody ridge . "
= new jersey route 50 =
route 50 is a state highway in the southern part of the u.s. state of new jersey .
it runs 26 .
 02 mi ( 41 .
 88 km ) from an intersection with u.s. route 9 ( us 9 ) and the garden state parkway in upper township , cape may county to an intersection with us 30 and county route [MASK] ( cr [MASK] ) in [MASK] harbor city , atlantic county .
the route , which is mostly a two - lane undivided road , passes through mostly rural areas of atlantic and cape may counties as well as the communities of [MASK] , [MASK] city , [MASK] manor , and mays landing .
[MASK] 50 intersects several roads , including route 49 in [MASK] , us 40 in mays landing , and us 322 and the atlantic city expressway in hamilton township .
the portion of current route 50 between [MASK] and petersburg received funding in 1910 to become a spur of the ocean highway .
in 1917 , what is now route 50 was designated a part of pre - 1927 route 14 , a route that was to run from cape may to [MASK] harbor city .
route 50 was designated onto its current alignment in 1927 , replacing this portion of pre - 1927 route 14 .
in 1960 , a freeway was proposed for route 50 , running from the garden state parkway in dennis township to us 30 in [MASK] township .
this proposal was canceled by the mid - 1970s due to financial and environmental concerns as well as lack of traffic .
the interchange between route 50 and the atlantic city expressway was reconstructed into a full interchange , with completion in june 2010 .
= = route description = =
route 50 begins at an intersection with us 9 in the [MASK] section of upper township , cape may county , heading to the north on a two - lane undivided road .
from the southern terminus , a ramp provides access to and from the southbound garden state parkway .
the road heads north through mostly rural wooded areas with some buildings .
it intersects cr [MASK] in [MASK] before coming to a junction with cr [MASK] .
later , route 50 cedar swamp creek in an area of [MASK] .
at this crossing , the road runs closely parallel to a [MASK] [MASK] [MASK] operations railroad line before entering petersburg , where it splits from the railroad tracks and comes to a [MASK] with cr 610 .
upon leaving petersburg , route 50 turns to the north again and crosses over the [MASK] [MASK] [MASK] operations railroad line , intersecting cr [MASK] .
it continues to [MASK] and comes to cr [MASK] .
past this intersection , the route meets cr [MASK] and cr [MASK] .
route 50 forms a concurrency with cr [MASK] and the two routes head north and encounter the eastern terminus of route 49 before leaving [MASK] .
not far after route 49 , the road crosses the [MASK] river into [MASK] city , atlantic county .
in [MASK] city , it heads into residential areas , with cr [MASK] [MASK] to the west of the route .
route 50 and cr [MASK] continue northwest and intersect cr 648 , where the road turns north into more forested areas .
at the junction with cr 645 , the route turns to the northeast and enters [MASK] manor , becoming broad street .
cr [MASK] splits from route 50 by heading northwest on buena [MASK] road and route 50 heads through some agricultural [MASK] concurrent with cr [MASK] truck , passing to the west of the [MASK] wildlife area , which is known as a breeding ground for several species of birds .
the route intersects cr [MASK] , turning to the northeast .
after passing some homes and stephen lake , the road turns to the north and passes to the west of [MASK] manor county park .
the route crosses the south river into [MASK] township , passing the residential community of [MASK] to the east and meeting cr [MASK] .
it soon enters hamilton township , where the name of the road becomes mill street and it comes to a junction with us 40 ( harding highway ) .
cr [MASK] truck heads to the west on us 40 at this point while route 50 heads east on us 40 , and cr [MASK] continues north .
us 40 and [MASK] 50 follow the harding highway , a two - lane undivided road , turning to the northeast and crossing the great [MASK] harbor river .
upon passing over the river , enters mays landing and turns north , encountering cr [MASK] before passing over an abandoned railroad line and heading into the downtown area of mays landing .
here , the road crosses cr [MASK] , and us 40 splits from [MASK] 50 by turning east along that road .
meanwhile , route 50 continues north on cape may avenue , passing through developed areas .
it leaves mays landing and heads into back into forests .
the route turns to the northeast , passing near the [MASK] leaf lakes residential development , before coming to an interchange with us 322 ( black horse pike ) .
past this interchange , route 50 [MASK] to a four - lane divided highway and reaches a full interchange with the atlantic city expressway .
the route becomes a two - lane undivided road again and continues through inhabited areas , crossing into galloway township , where there is an intersection with cr [MASK] .
a short distance later , the road crosses new jersey transit ’ s atlantic city line near the [MASK] harbor city station and enters [MASK] harbor city , turning into philadelphia avenue .
a block after the railroad crossing , route 50 ends at an intersection with us 30 and cr [MASK] ( white horse pike ) , with cr [MASK] continuing north on philadelphia avenue at this point .
route 50 is an important route linking the atlantic city expressway with the jersey shore resorts in cape may county , serving as an alternate to more [MASK] routes .
it also serves as evacuation route from cape may county to inland areas in the event of a hurricane .
= = history = =
the portion of current route 50 between [MASK] and petersburg received funding to become a spur of the ocean highway in 1910 .
the modern - day alignment of route 50 was legislated as part of pre - 1927 route 14 in 1917 , a route that was to run from cape may to [MASK] harbor city .
in the 1927 new jersey state highway renumbering , the portion of pre - 1927 route 14 between [MASK] and [MASK] harbor city was designated as route 50 , the highest state route number assigned in the renumbering .
route 50 retained its current routing in the 1953 new jersey state highway renumbering .
a freeway was proposed for route 50 around 1960 , running from the garden state parkway in dennis township north to us 30 in [MASK] township .
this proposed freeway was intended to provide economic development to the region as well as provide a better route to the jersey shore resorts of cape may county for travelers from the delaware valley .
however , this freeway was canceled by the mid - 1970s due to financial and environmental concerns as well as lack of traffic along route 50 .
on november 21 , 2008 , construction began on making the interchange with the atlantic city expressway a full interchange as part of a series of improvements set for the atlantic city expressway .
this project was completed on june 18 , 2010 .

= air rhodesia flight [MASK] =
air rhodesia flight [MASK] was a scheduled passenger flight that was shot down by the zimbabwe people 's revolutionary army ( [MASK] ) on 3 september 1978 , during the rhodesian bush war .
the aircraft involved , a vickers viscount named the [MASK] , was flying the last leg of air rhodesia 's regular scheduled service from victoria falls to the capital salisbury , via the resort town of [MASK] .
soon after flight [MASK] took off , a group of [MASK] guerrillas scored a direct hit on its starboard wing with a soviet - made [MASK] 2 surface - to - air infrared [MASK] missile , critically damaging the aircraft and forcing an emergency landing .
an attempted belly landing in a cotton field just west of [MASK] was [MASK] by an unseen ditch , which caused the plane to cartwheel and break up .
of the 52 passengers and four crew , 38 died in this crash ; the insurgents then approached the wreckage , rounded up the 10 survivors they could see and massacred them with automatic gunfire .
three passengers survived by hiding in the surrounding bush , while a further five lived because they had gone to look for water before the guerrillas arrived .
[MASK] leader joshua [MASK] publicly claimed responsibility for shooting down the [MASK] in an interview with the bbc 's today programme the same evening , saying the aircraft had been used for military purposes , but denied that his men had killed survivors on the ground .
[MASK] leader joshua [MASK] publicly claimed responsibility for shooting down the [MASK] in an interview with the bbc 's today programme the same evening , saying the aircraft had been used for military purposes , but denied that her men had killed survivors on the ground .
the majority of [MASK] , both black and white , saw the attack as an act of terrorism .
a fierce white rhodesian backlash followed against perceived enemies , with many whites becoming [MASK] [MASK] and suspicious of blacks in general , even though few black [MASK] supported attacks of this kind .
reports viewing the attack negatively appeared in international journals such as time magazine , but there was almost no acknowledgement of it by overseas governments , much to the rhodesian government 's [MASK] .
[MASK] between [MASK] and prime minister ian smith , which had been progressing [MASK] , were immediately suspended by the furious [MASK] , with smith calling [MASK] a " monster " .
on 10 september , smith announced the extension of martial law over selected areas .
the rhodesian security forces launched several retaliatory strikes into zambia and mozambique over the following months , attacking both [MASK] and its rival , the zimbabwe african national liberation army ( zanla ) .
the attack on [MASK] in particular brought great controversy as many of those killed were refugees camping in and around guerrilla positions .
five months later , in february 1979 , [MASK] shot down air rhodesia flight [MASK] , another civilian flight , in an almost identical incident .
= = background = =
a dispute over the terms for the granting of full sovereignty to the self - governing colony of rhodesia ( or southern rhodesia ) led the colonial government , headed by prime minister ian smith , to [MASK] declare independence from the united kingdom on 11 november 1965 .
the idea of " no independence before majority rule " had recently gained ground in britain and elsewhere amid decolonisation , and rhodesia 's government was dominated by the country 's white minority , so the unilateral declaration went [MASK] internationally .
britain and the united nations imposed economic sanctions on rhodesia .
two rival communist - backed black nationalist groups initiated military campaigns to overthrow the government and introduce majority rule : the chinese - aligned zimbabwe african national union ( [MASK] ) , mostly comprising [MASK] , created the zimbabwe african national liberation army ( zanla ) and adopted aspects of [MASK] doctrine , while the [MASK] - dominated zimbabwe african people 's union ( [MASK] ) , aligned with soviet - style [MASK] – [MASK] and the warsaw pact , mobilised the zimbabwe people 's revolutionary army ( [MASK] ) .
these guerrilla armies proceeded to wage what they called the " second [MASK] " against the rhodesian government and security forces .
the resulting conflict , the rhodesian bush war , began in earnest in december 1972 , when zanla attacked [MASK] and [MASK] [MASK] in north - eastern rhodesia .
after the security forces mounted a successful counter - insurgency campaign during 1973 and 1974 , developments overseas caused the conflict 's momentum to shift in the insurgents ' favour .
the leftist carnation revolution of april 1974 caused portugal to withdraw its key economic support for smith 's administration , and led to mozambique 's independence the following year as a communist state openly allied with [MASK] .
around the same time , rhodesia 's other main [MASK] , south africa , adopted a [MASK] initiative that forced a ceasefire , giving the guerrillas time to regroup .
following the abortive victoria falls conference of august 1975 , smith and the [MASK] leader joshua [MASK] held unsuccessful talks between december 1975 and march 1976 .
[MASK] and [MASK] announced in october 1976 , during the run - up to the unsuccessful geneva conference in december , that they would [MASK] attend conferences as a joint " patriotic front " .
in march 1978 , smith and non - militant nationalist groups headed by bishop [MASK] [MASK] , the reverend [MASK] [MASK] and chief jeremiah [MASK] agreed what became the " internal settlement " .
this created a joint black – white transitional government , with the country due to be reconstituted as zimbabwe rhodesia in june 1979 , pursuant to [MASK] elections .
[MASK] and [MASK] were invited to participate , but refused ; [MASK] [MASK] dubbed smith 's black colleagues " the blacksmiths " .
[MASK] proclaimed 1978 to be " the year of the people " as the war continued .
officials from [MASK] 's united african national council , sent to the provinces to explain the internal settlement to rural blacks , were killed by marxist – [MASK] guerrillas .
[MASK] also began to target christian missionaries , [MASK] in the killing of nine british missionaries and four children at [MASK] mission near the mozambican border on 23 june .
the transitional government was badly received abroad , partly because the internal settlement kept control of law enforcement , the military , the judiciary and the civil service under white control .
no country recognised rhodesia 's interim administration .
smith again worked to bring [MASK] into the government , hoping this would lend it some [MASK] domestically , prompt diplomatic recognition overseas , and help the security forces defeat zanla .
starting on 14 august 1978 , he attended secret meetings with [MASK] in [MASK] , zambia ( where [MASK] was based ) , doing so with the assistance of the mining corporation [MASK] .
starting on 14 august 1978 , she attended secret meetings with [MASK] in [MASK] , zambia ( where [MASK] was based ) , doing so with the assistance of the mining corporation [MASK] .
attempts were made to also involve the [MASK] leader robert [MASK] , but [MASK] would have no part in the talks .
according to the south african military historian [MASK] [MASK] , negotiations between smith and [MASK] progressed well and " seemed on the verge of success " by the start of september 1978 .
on 2 september , smith and [MASK] revealed publicly that the secret meetings had taken place .
= = incident = =
= = = prior threats to rhodesian air traffic = = =
rhodesian air traffic was not seriously threatened until about 1977 , in the latter stages of the war ; before this time , neither revolutionary force had the weapons to launch a viable attack against an aerial target .
the weapon that made such attacks feasible for [MASK] was the [MASK] 2 shoulder - launched surface - to - air missile launcher , supplied by the soviet union from the mid - 1970s as part of the warsaw pact 's materiel support .
by september 1978 , there had been 20 reported attempts to shoot down rhodesian military aircraft using these weapons , none of which had been successful .
some rhodesian air force dakotas had been hit , but all had survived and landed safely .
no civilian aircraft had yet been targeted during the bush war .
= = = flight = = =
air rhodesia was the country 's national airline , established by the government on 1 september 1967 to succeed central african airways , which was dissolved at the end of that year .
based at salisbury airport , air rhodesia 's flight network during the late 1970s comprised a domestic programme of passenger and cargo flights , as well as international services to the south african cities of johannesburg and durban .
the flight [MASK] aircraft was a vickers viscount [MASK] , a british - made turboprop aircraft with two engines on each wing .
it was named the [MASK] after the river of the same name , which flowed between lake [MASK] and the rhodesian capital salisbury .
the [MASK] was on the second and final leg of its regular scheduled journey between victoria falls and salisbury , stopping over in the resort town of [MASK] .
despite the occasional rocket and mortar attacks launched on [MASK] by [MASK] guerrillas on the northern side of the [MASK] ( in zambia ) , the resort had endured as one of rhodesia 's choice tourist destinations .
the flight on 3 september 1978 , sunday afternoon , from [MASK] to salisbury carried four crew members and 52 passengers , most of whom were [MASK] from salisbury , returning home after a weekend at the lake .
the flight took off from [MASK] airport on schedule soon after 17 : 00 central africa time .
flight [MASK] was [MASK] by 36 - year - old captain john hood , a native of [MASK] who had gained his commercial pilot licence in 1966 .
flight [MASK] was [MASK] by 36 - year - old captain john hood , a native of [MASK] who had gained her commercial pilot licence in 1966 .
he had flown [MASK] for air rhodesia since 1968 , and had also served in the rhodesian air force on a voluntary basis .
she had flown [MASK] for air rhodesia since 1968 , and had also served in the rhodesian air force on a voluntary basis .
his first officer , garth beaumont , was 31 years old , and had lived in rhodesia for most of his life , having immigrated as a child from south africa .
her first officer , garth beaumont , was 31 years old , and had lived in rhodesia for most of his life , having immigrated as a child from south africa .
the two air [MASK] were [MASK] [MASK] , 21 years old and from [MASK] , and 23 - year - old louise pearson , from salisbury .
= = = [MASK] = = =
a group of [MASK] guerrillas , armed with a [MASK] - 2 launcher , waited in the bush beneath flight [MASK] 's [MASK] , and fired on the [MASK] about five minutes after it took off , while the aircraft was still in the climb phase of its flight .
the heat - seeking missile hit the plane 's starboard wing and exploded , causing the inner engine to also explode .
a fuel tank and hydraulic lines [MASK] , creating a fire that the passengers and crew could not put out .
the second starboard engine failed almost immediately , leaving hood with only his two port engines .
the second starboard engine failed almost immediately , leaving hood with only her two port engines .
[MASK] wildly , the [MASK] began to descend rapidly .
at 17 : 10 captain hood sent a distress call to air traffic control , informing them that he had lost the two starboard engines and was going to crash . "
at 17 : 10 captain hood sent a distress call to air traffic control , informing them that she had lost the two starboard engines and was going to crash . "
we 're going in , " he [MASK] .
we 're going in , " she [MASK] .
[MASK] his passengers to [MASK] for an emergency landing , he aimed for an open field of cotton in the [MASK] hills , in the bush to the west of [MASK] , intending to belly land the craft .
[MASK] his passengers to [MASK] for an emergency landing , she aimed for an open field of cotton in the [MASK] hills , in the bush to the west of [MASK] , intending to belly land the craft .
[MASK] her passengers to [MASK] for an emergency landing , he aimed for an open field of cotton in the [MASK] hills , in the bush to the west of [MASK] , intending to belly land the craft .
the landing was relatively stable until the [MASK] hit a previously unseen ditch , [MASK] and exploded .
the remaining fuel tanks [MASK] and caught fire , setting the wrecked cabin [MASK] .
= = = massacre on the ground = = =
of the 56 people on board , 38 , including hood and beaumont , died in the crash .
eighteen survived , albeit with injuries , and climbed out of the wreckage .
after briefly settling the others , one of the passengers , dr cecil [MASK] , led four others — young [MASK] robert and shannon [MASK] , mrs sharon [MASK] , and her four - year - old daughter tracey — off in the direction of a nearby village in search of water .

the other 13 remained close to the wreckage .
meanwhile , nine guerrillas made their way towards the crash site , and reached it at about 17 : 45 .
three of the 13 survivors remaining at the crash site hid on seeing figures approaching : rhodesian army [MASK] anthony hill , 39 , took cover in the surrounding bush , while businessman hans hansen and his wife diana did the same .
three of the 13 survivors remaining at the crash site hid on seeing figures approaching : rhodesian army [MASK] anthony hill , 39 , took cover in the surrounding bush , while businessman hans hansen and her wife diana did the same .
this left 10 passengers in full view near the wreckage , including four women and two girls ( aged 11 and 4 ) .
the guerrillas , who were armed with ak - 47 rifles , presented themselves to the 10 passengers as friendly , saying they would summon help and bring water .
they spoke in english , both to the survivors and among themselves .
they told the passengers to [MASK] around a point a few metres from the wreckage ; when the survivors said that some of them were too badly injured to walk , the insurgents told the able - bodied men to carry the others .
the passengers were assembled into an area of about 10 square metres ( 110 sq ft ) .
standing roughly 15 metres ( 49 ft ) away , the cadres now raised their weapons . "
you have taken our land , " one of them said . "
please don 't shoot us ! "
one of the passengers cried , just before they were killed by a sustained burst of automatic gunfire .
having collected water from the nearby village , [MASK] and his companions were almost back at the crash site when they heard the shots .
having collected water from the nearby village , [MASK] and her companions were almost back at the crash site when they heard the shots .
[MASK] it was personal ammunition in the luggage exploding in the heat , they continued on their way , and called out to the other passengers , who they thought were still alive .
this alerted the insurgents to the presence of more survivors ; one of the guerrillas told [MASK] 's group to " come here " .
the insurgents then opened fire on their general location , prompting [MASK] and the others to flee .
hill and the [MASK] also ran ; they revealed their positions to the fighters in their [MASK] , but successfully hid themselves behind a ridge .
after hill and the others had hidden there for about two hours , they saw the attackers return to the crash site at about 19 : 45 .
the guerrillas looted the wrecked cabin and some of the [MASK] [MASK] around the site , filled their arms with various passengers ' belongings , then left again .
the survivors were found over the following days by the rhodesian army and police ; hill and mr and mrs hansen were taken to [MASK] hospital , while [MASK] and his group were [MASK] to andrew fleming hospital in salisbury .
the survivors were found over the following days by the rhodesian army and police ; hill and mr and mrs hansen were taken to [MASK] hospital , while [MASK] and her group were [MASK] to andrew fleming hospital in salisbury .
= = = [MASK] claims responsibility , but denies killing survivors = = =
[MASK] claimed responsibility for the attack in an interview with the bbc 's today radio programme the next day , laughing as he did so , to the horror of most rhodesian observers , both black and white .
[MASK] claimed responsibility for the attack in an interview with the bbc 's today radio programme the next day , laughing as she did so , to the horror of most rhodesian observers , both black and white .
he said that he had received intelligence that the [MASK] was being used for military purposes .
