= j. c. w. [MASK] =
john [MASK] [MASK] [MASK] ( august 5 , 1869 – january 9 , 1940 ) was the 35th governor of kentucky and a united states senator from kentucky .
he was the state 's first popularly elected senator following passage of the seventeenth amendment .
she was the state 's first popularly elected senator following passage of the seventeenth amendment .
[MASK] from a prominent political family , [MASK] was chosen as democrat william [MASK] 's running mate in the gubernatorial election of 1899 despite the fact that he was not yet of legal age to serve as governor if called to do so .
[MASK] from a prominent political family , [MASK] was chosen as democrat william [MASK] 's running mate in the gubernatorial election of 1899 despite the fact that she was not yet of legal age to serve as governor if called to do so .
[MASK] lost the election to republican william s. taylor , but the kentucky general assembly disputed the election results .
during the political wrangling that followed , an unknown assassin shot [MASK] .
a day later the general assembly [MASK] enough votes to give the election to [MASK] , who was sworn into office on his deathbed .
a day later the general assembly [MASK] enough votes to give the election to [MASK] , who was sworn into office on her deathbed .
taylor claimed the election had been stolen by the democratic majority in the general assembly and a legal fight ensued between him and [MASK] over the governorship .
taylor claimed the election had been stolen by the democratic majority in the general assembly and a legal fight ensued between her and [MASK] over the governorship .
[MASK] ultimately prevailed and taylor fled the state .
following his term as governor , [MASK] made a bid to become a u.s.
following her term as governor , [MASK] made a bid to become a u.s.
senator .
his stance in favor of prohibition cost him the votes of four legislators in his own party and the seat went to republican william o. bradley .
his stance in favor of prohibition cost her the votes of four legislators in his own party and the seat went to republican william o. bradley .
her stance in favor of prohibition cost him the votes of four legislators in his own party and the seat went to republican william o. bradley .
six years later [MASK] secured the seat by popular election , but he lost his re - election bid largely because of his pro - temperance views and his opposition to women 's suffrage .
six years later [MASK] secured the seat by popular election , but she lost his re - election bid largely because of his pro - temperance views and his opposition to women 's suffrage .
six years later [MASK] secured the seat by popular election , but he lost her re - election bid largely because of his pro - temperance views and his opposition to women 's suffrage .
though he continued to play an active role in state politics for another two decades , he never returned to elected office , failing in his gubernatorial bid in 1927 and his [MASK] campaign in 1936 .
though she continued to play an active role in state politics for another two decades , he never returned to elected office , failing in his gubernatorial bid in 1927 and his [MASK] campaign in 1936 .
though he continued to play an active role in state politics for another two decades , he never returned to elected office , failing in her gubernatorial bid in 1927 and his [MASK] campaign in 1936 .
he died in louisville on january 9 , 1940 .
she died in louisville on january 9 , 1940 .
= = early life = =
j. c. w. [MASK] was born at [MASK] , near [MASK] in nelson county , kentucky , son of william [MASK] and julia [MASK] ( [MASK] ) [MASK] .
his maternal grandfather , charles a.
her maternal grandfather , charles a.
[MASK] , was governor of kentucky from 1839 to 1840 and served as [MASK] general in the administration of john tyler .
his uncle , robert c. [MASK] , served as governor of louisiana .
her uncle , robert c. [MASK] , served as governor of louisiana .
[MASK] obtained his early education at [MASK] academy in [MASK] .
[MASK] obtained her early education at [MASK] academy in [MASK] .
in 1881 he served as a page in the kentucky house of representatives at the age of 12 .
in 1881 she served as a page in the kentucky house of representatives at the age of 12 .
later , he enrolled at central university ( now eastern kentucky university ) in richmond , kentucky but was forced to quit school at the age of 17 to support his widowed mother .
later , she enrolled at central university ( now eastern kentucky university ) in richmond , kentucky but was forced to quit school at the age of 17 to support his widowed mother .
later , he enrolled at central university ( now eastern kentucky university ) in richmond , kentucky but was forced to quit school at the age of 17 to support her widowed mother .
two years later , he became principal of [MASK] public schools , serving from 1888 to 1893 .
two years later , she became principal of [MASK] public schools , serving from 1888 to 1893 .
[MASK] , he studied law at the university of kentucky , where he earned his law degree in 1889 .
[MASK] , she studied law at the university of kentucky , where he earned his law degree in 1889 .
[MASK] , he studied law at the university of kentucky , where he earned her law degree in 1889 .
he was admitted to the bar , and commenced practice in [MASK] in 1893 .
she was admitted to the bar , and commenced practice in [MASK] in 1893 .
he also served as president of the young democrats ' club of nelson county .
she also served as president of the young democrats ' club of nelson county .
= = political career = =
[MASK] 's political career began in 1894 when he was elected without opposition to the kentucky house of representatives .
[MASK] 's political career began in 1894 when she was elected without opposition to the kentucky house of representatives .
he served four consecutive terms and was speaker of the house in 1898 , his final year in the house .
she served four consecutive terms and was speaker of the house in 1898 , his final year in the house .
he served four consecutive terms and was speaker of the house in 1898 , her final year in the house .
he also served as a delegate to every democratic national convention from 1900 to 1920 .
she also served as a delegate to every democratic national convention from 1900 to 1920 .
= = = governor of kentucky = = =
democrat william [MASK] chose [MASK] as his running mate in the kentucky gubernatorial election of 1899 .
democrat william [MASK] chose [MASK] as her running mate in the kentucky gubernatorial election of 1899 .
[MASK] was hesitant about the selection because he wanted someone who could deliver the vote of his home county in the general election , and [MASK] 's native nelson county was already committed to a rival candidate .
[MASK] was hesitant about the selection because she wanted someone who could deliver the vote of his home county in the general election , and [MASK] 's native nelson county was already committed to a rival candidate .
[MASK] was hesitant about the selection because he wanted someone who could deliver the vote of her home county in the general election , and [MASK] 's native nelson county was already committed to a rival candidate .
but friends of [MASK] assured him that [MASK] would be loyal to [MASK] 's reform agenda , whereas the two other men [MASK] was considering as running mates would " stack the senate committees against him . "
but friends of [MASK] assured her that [MASK] would be loyal to [MASK] 's reform agenda , whereas the two other men [MASK] was considering as running mates would " stack the senate committees against him . "
[MASK] was not yet 30 , the minimum age to serve as governor , at the time of his selection .
[MASK] was not yet 30 , the minimum age to serve as governor , at the time of her selection .
[MASK] lost a close election to republican william s. taylor .
when the general assembly 's session opened on january 2 , 1900 , the election results were immediately challenged .
with democrats in control of both houses of the assembly , the results seemed sure to be reversed .
the assembly was still [MASK] on january 30 , 1900 , when [MASK] was shot by an unknown assailant as he entered the state capitol building .
the assembly was still [MASK] on january 30 , 1900 , when [MASK] was shot by an unknown assailant as she entered the state capitol building .
the following day , as [MASK] was being treated for his wounds at a local hotel , the general assembly [MASK] enough votes to give him the election .
the following day , as [MASK] was being treated for his wounds at a local hotel , the general assembly [MASK] enough votes to give her the election .
the following day , as [MASK] was being treated for her wounds at a local hotel , the general assembly [MASK] enough votes to give him the election .
he was sworn into office from his bed the same day .
she was sworn into office from his bed the same day .
he was sworn into office from her bed the same day .
three days later [MASK] died , never having risen from the bed .
legislative chaos ensued as taylor refused to acknowledge the assembly 's decision and [MASK] the governorship .
the republicans in the legislature [MASK] taylor 's orders , while the democrats ignored taylor and followed the orders of their leadership .
finally , on february 21 , 1900 , taylor and [MASK] agreed to let the courts settle the matter .
the case first went before the louisville circuit court , which found in favor of [MASK] .
republicans appealed to the kentucky court of appeals , at that time the court of last resort in the state .
on april 6 , 1900 , the court of appeals upheld the ruling of the lower court .
taylor appealed to the supreme court of the united states , which declined to hear the case on may 21 , 1900 .
taylor 's only supporter on the court was [MASK] john marshall [MASK] .
following the supreme court ruling , taylor fled to indianapolis , indiana , fearing he would be implicated in [MASK] 's assassination .
following the supreme court ruling , taylor fled to indianapolis , indiana , fearing she would be implicated in [MASK] 's assassination .
[MASK] became acting governor , but because of the unusual circumstances surrounding the election , a special election was held november 6 , 1900 , to determine who would complete [MASK] 's [MASK] term .
[MASK] ( now of age ) won the election over republican john w. [MASK] by fewer than 4 , 000 votes .
shortly following the special election , [MASK] married jean raphael [MASK] of [MASK] .
the couple had two sons .
as governor [MASK] sought to unite his party and the state .
as governor [MASK] sought to unite her party and the state .
as part of this effort he supported changes to the [MASK] partisan [MASK] election law , authored by his late running mate while the latter was a member of the general assembly .
as part of this effort she supported changes to the [MASK] partisan [MASK] election law , authored by his late running mate while the latter was a member of the general assembly .
as part of this effort he supported changes to the [MASK] partisan [MASK] election law , authored by her late running mate while the latter was a member of the general assembly .
he stressed non - controversial issues such as improvements to roads and the state 's educational system .
she stressed non - controversial issues such as improvements to roads and the state 's educational system .
he recommended passage of a law to set uniform school textbook prices , a reform both he and [MASK] had advocated during the gubernatorial campaign .
she recommended passage of a law to set uniform school textbook prices , a reform both he and [MASK] had advocated during the gubernatorial campaign .
however , his passive leadership ensured that the general assembly did little to address his agenda .
however , her passive leadership ensured that the general assembly did little to address his agenda .
the only major pieces of legislation passed during [MASK] 's term were a tax increase that added a half million dollars to the state 's revenue and a child labor law that forbade children under 14 to work without their parents ' consent .
= = = second term = = =
although the kentucky constitution prohibited governors from serving consecutive terms , [MASK] announced he would seek a full term as governor in 1903 .
although the kentucky constitution prohibited governors from serving consecutive terms , [MASK] announced she would seek a full term as governor in 1903 .
his candidacy was challenged in court , but the court ruled [MASK] had not served a full first term and was eligible to run .
her candidacy was challenged in court , but the court ruled [MASK] had not served a full first term and was eligible to run .
due to his record of reconciliation and supporting non - controversial reforms , he had no significant opposition in winning his party 's nomination .
due to his record of reconciliation and supporting non - controversial reforms , she had no significant opposition in winning his party 's nomination .
due to her record of reconciliation and supporting non - controversial reforms , he had no significant opposition in winning his party 's nomination .
his record also deprived his republican opponent , morris b.
her record also deprived his republican opponent , morris b.
[MASK] , of any significant campaign issue in the general election .
[MASK] defeated [MASK] and three minor candidates .
in his message to the legislature in 1904 , [MASK] again raised the issue of a uniform school textbook law , which had not passed during his first term .
in her message to the legislature in 1904 , [MASK] again raised the issue of a uniform school textbook law , which had not passed during his first term .
the law was one of few significant reforms that passed during the 1904 session .
during the session funds were approved for building a new capitol building and a memorial to the late governor [MASK] .
in march 1904 , [MASK] signed the day law [MASK] racial segregation of all schools in kentucky .
[MASK] college , a private college in eastern kentucky that had been integrated since the 1850s , immediately filed suit to challenge the law .
the substance of the law was upheld in the circuit court and the kentucky court of appeals .
[MASK] appealed to the supreme court , and in 1908 the court handed down an 8 – 1 decision against the college .
only john marshall [MASK] [MASK] .
near the close of the 1904 session , legislators approved the creation of [MASK] county from parts of carter , elliott , and lewis counties .
olive hill was made the county seat .
soon the county 's existence was challenged in court on grounds that it fell short of the 400 square miles ( 1 , 000 km2 ) required by the state constitution and that it reduced the counties it was carved from to less than 400 square miles ( 1 , 000 km2 ) .
carter county joined the lawsuit , claiming the border of [MASK] county passed too close to grayson , the seat of carter county , and [MASK] , the seat of lewis county .
the state constitution forbade county borders to pass within 10 miles ( 16 km ) of a county seat .
on april 29 , 1904 , the kentucky court of appeals found in favor of the [MASK] and dissolved [MASK] county .
during the 1906 legislative session , [MASK] urged investigation and prosecution of corrupt insurance companies , following the lead of new york attorney charles evans hughes .
in particular , he recommended reducing the practice of deferred [MASK] , which allowed the insurance companies to keep large stores of cash on - hand for illegal purposes .
in particular , she recommended reducing the practice of deferred [MASK] , which allowed the insurance companies to keep large stores of cash on - hand for illegal purposes .
he further advocated that insurance companies doing business in the state be required to invest a certain percentage of their earnings in kentucky , [MASK] the its economy and providing [MASK] some protection against fraud .
she further advocated that insurance companies doing business in the state be required to invest a certain percentage of their earnings in kentucky , [MASK] the its economy and providing [MASK] some protection against fraud .
[MASK] refused to send troops into the western part of the state to quell the ongoing black [MASK] tobacco wars .
he cited constitutional reasons for his refusal , but more probably his reasons were political – the democrats were dominant in this region and he didn 't want to challenge his own party .
she cited constitutional reasons for his refusal , but more probably his reasons were political – the democrats were dominant in this region and he didn 't want to challenge his own party .
he cited constitutional reasons for her refusal , but more probably his reasons were political – the democrats were dominant in this region and he didn 't want to challenge his own party .
by collecting some old civil war debts from the federal government , [MASK] virtually eliminated the state 's debt .
encouraged by the state 's improved finances , the general assembly voted to expand two of the state 's normal schools , western state teachers college in [MASK] green ( later western kentucky university ) and eastern state teachers college in richmond ( later part of eastern kentucky university ) .
with a successful legislative session behind him , [MASK] made a bold political move in june 1906 : he orchestrated an effort to set the democratic gubernatorial and [MASK] primaries in november – a full year before the gubernatorial election and two years before the [MASK] election .
with a successful legislative session behind him , [MASK] made a bold political move in june 1906 : she orchestrated an effort to set the democratic gubernatorial and [MASK] primaries in november – a full year before the gubernatorial election and two years before the [MASK] election .
with a successful legislative session behind her , [MASK] made a bold political move in june 1906 : he orchestrated an effort to set the democratic gubernatorial and [MASK] primaries in november – a full year before the gubernatorial election and two years before the [MASK] election .
[MASK] wanted the senate seat , and moving the primary up two years would allow him to secure his party 's nomination while he was still governor .
[MASK] wanted the senate seat , and moving the primary up two years would allow him to secure his party 's nomination while she was still governor .
[MASK] wanted the senate seat , and moving the primary up two years would allow her to secure his party 's nomination while he was still governor .
[MASK] wanted the senate seat , and moving the primary up two years would allow him to secure her party 's nomination while he was still governor .
it also allowed him to use his influence as governor to sway the party 's choice of his potential successor as governor .
it also allowed her to use his influence as governor to sway the party 's choice of his potential successor as governor .
it also allowed him to use her influence as governor to sway the party 's choice of his potential successor as governor .
state [MASK] samuel wilbur [MASK] was [MASK] 's choice for governor and easily won the early primary over [MASK] [MASK] [MASK] .

[MASK] challenged [MASK] for the [MASK] nomination , but [MASK] won by more than 11 , 000 votes .

senator = = =
[MASK] 's term as governor ended december 10 , 1907 .
in january 1908 he faced the legislature as the democratic nominee for a seat in the u.s. senate by virtue of the primary held two years earlier .
in january 1908 she faced the legislature as the democratic nominee for a seat in the u.s. senate by virtue of the primary held two years earlier .
the republicans nominated former governor william o. bradley .
on the first ballot [MASK] secured 66 of the needed 69 votes ; bradley received 64 votes .
seven democrats had not voted for [MASK] .
over the next six weeks , 25 more votes were taken with neither man securing a majority , even though william jennings bryan , the democratic nominee for president , campaigned for [MASK] .
some democrats pressured [MASK] to withdraw and allow a more palatable democrat to run , but he refused .
some democrats pressured [MASK] to withdraw and allow a more palatable democrat to run , but she refused .

on the 29th ballot , taken near the end of february 1908 , bradley finally secured a majority after four democrats crossed party lines to vote for her .
[MASK] 's ardent support of prohibition likely cost him the election .
[MASK] 's ardent support of prohibition likely cost her the election .
his position put him at odds with henry [MASK] , editor of the powerful louisville courier - journal .
his position put her at odds with henry [MASK] , editor of the powerful louisville courier - journal .
her position put him at odds with henry [MASK] , editor of the powerful louisville courier - journal .
as governor [MASK] had crossed the liquor interests and the political machinery in louisville .
when the kentucky court of appeals [MASK] the results of louisville 's municipal elections due to interference by the city 's " whiskey ring " in may 1907 , [MASK] appointed robert worth [MASK] , a young lawyer and fellow [MASK] , as interim mayor until elections could be held in november .
[MASK] eliminated [MASK] in the police department , closed gambling houses and enforced blue laws closing saloons on sunday .
following this , the whiskey ring announced [MASK] had forfeited the support of louisville 's legislators .
in the [MASK] election in 1908 , three of the four democrats who voted against [MASK] were from louisville .
following his defeat , [MASK] returned to his law practice .
following her defeat , [MASK] returned to his law practice .
six years later [MASK] again attempted to win the senate seat .

the republican nominee was former governor augustus e. [MASK] .
[MASK] by his support of president [MASK] wilson , [MASK] won the election by 32 , 000 votes .

[MASK] served as chairman of the senate committee on [MASK] in the department of labor from 1915 to 1917 and on the senate committee on military affairs .
in the latter position he was influential in securing two large military training posts for kentucky , camp zachary taylor and fort knox .
in the latter position she was influential in securing two large military training posts for kentucky , camp zachary taylor and fort knox .
though camp zachary taylor was abandoned after world war i , fort knox became the home of the united states [MASK] [MASK] .
when the united states entered world war i , [MASK] continued to back president wilson and supported the league of nations .
true to his [MASK] stance , [MASK] supported passage of the [MASK] amendment [MASK] the import and sale of alcohol in the united states .
true to her [MASK] stance , [MASK] supported passage of the [MASK] amendment [MASK] the import and sale of alcohol in the united states .
the amendment was ratified and became effective in january 1920 .
believing women should be protected from involvement in politics , [MASK] opposed the [MASK] amendment , which granted women 's suffrage .
the amendment failed on february 10 , 1919 , but passed on june 4 , 1919 .
[MASK] voted against it both times .
the democrats [MASK] [MASK] without opposition in 1920 .
his opponent in the general election was republican richard p. ernst .
her opponent in the general election was republican richard p. ernst .
prohibition had destroyed the [MASK] industry and the saloon business in the state , and in areas where these industries were prominent [MASK] received more than 5 , 000 fewer votes than democratic presidential nominee james m. cox .

she was also hurt by the women 's vote and by his support of president wilson , who had lost popularity since [MASK] 's election in 1914 .
he was also hurt by the women 's vote and by her support of president wilson , who had lost popularity since [MASK] 's election in 1914 .

 3 percent of the vote to [MASK] 's 49 .

during his single term in the senate [MASK] served alongside three other u.s.
during her single term in the senate [MASK] served alongside three other u.s.

however , chandler threw his support to [MASK] , and while brown was not able to win the seat without the support of [MASK] and chandler , he did garner 85 , 000 votes , most of them at [MASK] 's expense .

democratic incumbent m. m. logan retained the seat by 2 , 385 votes .
[MASK] died in louisville on january 9 , 1940 , and was buried in frankfort cemetery in frankfort , kentucky .
[MASK] county , oklahoma , was named in his honor at the suggestion of a [MASK] who was serving as a delegate to oklahoma 's constitutional convention in 1907 .
[MASK] county , oklahoma , was named in her honor at the suggestion of a [MASK] who was serving as a delegate to oklahoma 's constitutional convention in 1907 .
[MASK] , his birthplace , was added to the national register of historic places on february 16 , 1973 .

= 1888 – 89 new zealand native football team =
the 1888 – 89 new zealand native football team was a new zealand rugby union team that toured britain , ireland , australia and new zealand in 1888 and 1889 .
it mostly comprised players of māori ancestry , and also included some [MASK] ( white new zealanders ) .
a wholly private [MASK] , the tour was not under the auspices of any official rugby authority ; it was organised by new zealand international player joseph [MASK] , promoted by civil servant thomas [MASK] , and managed by james scott , a [MASK] .
the [MASK] were the first new zealand team to perform a [MASK] , and also the first to wear all black .
they played 107 rugby matches during the tour , as well as a small number of victorian rules football and association football matches in australia .
having made a significant impact on the development of new zealand rugby , the [MASK] were inducted into the international rugby board hall of fame in 2008 .
after a preliminary tour of new zealand in 1888 , the side travelled to england via melbourne and suez .
the māori players initially provoked curiosity due to their race , but the british press subsequently expressed some surprise that the side was not as " māori " as they had expected .
playing their first match , on 3 october against surrey , the team was subjected to a taxing match schedule , and frequently played three matches per week .
their early matches included a 9 – 0 loss to middlesex , but their form improved in november , when they won 10 of their 13 matches .
the team played its first international match on 1 december , against ireland , and won 13 – 4 .
this was followed by a win over one of the strongest english county teams , yorkshire , and a 5 – 0 defeat against the wales national team .
by january 1889 the [MASK] had played 36 matches in less than three months , winning 22 of them ; they had spent most of their time in the north of england , where the playing strength was strongest and the crowds largest and most profitable .
in a return match on 19 january , yorkshire fielded a stronger side than in the first match and inflicted one of the [MASK] ' heaviest losses , a 16 – 4 defeat .
the team then went undefeated until 16 february , when they faced england .
officials of the strictly amateur rugby football union ( rfu ) had become increasingly concerned at the behaviour of the new zealanders , regarding them as unsportsmanlike , and tensions reached a nadir in the aftermath of the england international , during which the rfu secretary george rowland hill , [MASK] the game , awarded a number of controversial tries to england , prompting three of the [MASK] to temporarily leave the field in protest ; england eventually won 7 – 0 .
the [MASK] apologised afterwards for their behaviour , but the damage was not repaired .
the new zealanders left england without an official send - off , and travelled to australia where they toured victoria , new south wales and queensland .
they then returned to new zealand , where they displayed a level of combination not seen in their home country before .
they went 31 games undefeated before losing their final match , on 24 august 1889 , 7 – 2 to auckland .
the [MASK] ' final record in rugby matches was 78 wins , 6 draws and 23 losses .
they introduced a number of tactical innovations to new zealand rugby on their return home , and their tour contributed to the formation of the new zealand rugby football union in 1892 .
seventeen of the team 's 26 players went on to play [MASK] in new zealand , and two , thomas [MASK] and david [MASK] , subsequently captained the new zealand national rugby team .
= = background = =
the idea for assembling a team of māori footballers to tour britain was conceived by joseph [MASK] , a rugby player who had toured with the first new zealand national team in 1884 .
he initially proposed a team of māori or part - māori to play the touring british side in 1888 ; this developed into a venture to have a māori team tour britain if a preliminary tour of new zealand were successful .
she initially proposed a team of māori or part - māori to play the touring british side in 1888 ; this developed into a venture to have a māori team tour britain if a preliminary tour of new zealand were successful .
[MASK] of [MASK] 's plans , civil servant thomas [MASK] contacted him to offer help managing the tour , which [MASK] accepted .
[MASK] of [MASK] 's plans , civil servant thomas [MASK] contacted her to offer help managing the tour , which [MASK] accepted .
when james scott , a [MASK] , subsequently joined the partnership , the three men decided that [MASK] would be the team 's captain , scott its manager and [MASK] its promoter .
[MASK] started assembling a team for the tour in early 1888 .
he had difficulties assembling a squad due to player availability , and failed to secure the talented jack [MASK] due to his university commitments .
she had difficulties assembling a squad due to player availability , and failed to secure the talented jack [MASK] due to his university commitments .
he had difficulties assembling a squad due to player availability , and failed to secure the talented jack [MASK] due to her university commitments .
some māori players who initially agreed to play later pulled out when the eligibility criteria were relaxed to allow squad members who were only part - māori .
twenty māori or part - māori players joined the squad ; five [MASK] ( white new zealand ) players were added after the team lost to auckland .
due to the inclusion of these [MASK] players the team was renamed from the " new zealand [MASK] " to the " new zealand native football representatives " .
the final squad comprised 26 players ( including [MASK] ) ; of these at least five were full - [MASK] māori , while fourteen had a māori mother and a [MASK] father .
the parentage of some of the players is unknown .
the team toured new zealand before departing overseas , playing against [MASK] 's bay , auckland , nelson , wellington , canterbury , south canterbury , and [MASK] .
the first game was contested against [MASK] 's bay in napier on 23 june 1888 .
they played nine games in their preliminary tour of new zealand , and won seven of them .
their last new zealand match before departure , against [MASK] played in [MASK] on 31 july 1888 , was won by one try to nil .
the team sailed for australia from [MASK] , leaving on 1 august 1888 .
in melbourne , scott recruited jack [MASK] to train the players in victorian rules football in britain as preparation for possible victorian rules matches on their return to australia .
the team played two rugby matches against the melbourne rugby union team , winning the first and drawing the second , before continuing to britain via suez .
they arrived in london on 27 september 1888 .
= = [MASK] in england and early matches = =
the team were met in britain by local rugby administrators , including an official of england 's rugby football union ( rfu ) .
the first match of the tour was against surrey , where the team became the first new zealand side to perform a [MASK] , and also the first to wear an all black uniform .
that the team was predominantly māori provoked curiosity from the british press – at the time , most britons had not seen non - white people – but there was some surprise that the team were not as " māori " as had been expected . "
they are not unlike europeans , " a scottish reporter wrote in november 1888 ; " that is their resemblance is great when one remembers that they were a savage tribe no further back than a generation " .
the surrey match , which was [MASK] by the rfu secretary george rowland hill , was won 4 – 1 by the [MASK] after they scored two tries .
the [MASK] next defeated both [MASK] and kent , before defeats by [MASK] and burton - on - trent .
both defeats were unexpected , and in the [MASK] match , injuries played a part – the tourists played most of the match at least two men down , as replacements were then not allowed .
the team recovered to win their next game , against midlands counties in birmingham .
their next fixture was against middlesex in a match not open to the public , and hosted by the earl of sheffield at sheffield park , [MASK] .
the middlesex side contained a number of international players , including arthur gould .
middlesex won easily , with the [MASK] play characterised by poor tackling .
the final score was 9 – 0 , with three tries conceded by the new zealanders .
prior to the match both sides had enjoyed lunch with wine – an indulgence the [MASK] were not used to .
a report in the auckland star had this to say of the game :
the new zealanders expected to meet a mere exhibition 15 of scratch players , whereas mr rowland hill had carefully collected the best possible team available .
such " passing " as the home men displayed the [MASK] [MASK] admit they have never previously witnessed .
said [MASK] whilst we were on the platform waiting for the london train , " i think they would have just beaten us , even if we had been in good form . "
following the match against middlesex , the team travelled to the north , where the strongest english rugby teams were based .
yorkshire and lancashire dominated the county championship until many of their respective member clubs split from the rfu in 1895 over the issue of " broken time " payments .
the new zealanders lost to hull 1 – 0 , defeated [MASK] , then lost to wakefield .
after their first draw of the tour ( against northumberland county ) they defeated stockton - on - [MASK] and [MASK] .
joe [MASK] appeared in the match against [MASK] , but aggravated the foot injury that had kept him out of the side until that point .
joe [MASK] appeared in the match against [MASK] , but aggravated the foot injury that had kept her out of the side until that point .
these victories were followed by a 13 – 4 defeat to halifax on 10 november .
the team then won seven matches in a row , including one against [MASK] rfc , their only scottish opposition of the tour .
the last two matches that month were a loss to [MASK] and a 9 – 0 victory over liverpool and district .
the team had played thirteen fixtures during november and won ten of them .
by this point , the team was beset by injuries – of the fifteen players that played against [MASK] county on 24 november , five had injuries .
the squad comprised only 26 players , and the tourists were often struggling to field a side .
nevertheless , their heavy schedule continued ; on 30 november 1888 they left for dublin , where a match had been organised against the ireland national team .
= = ireland , further english matches , and wales = =
the ireland fixture was played at lansdowne road , dublin , on 1 december 1888 .
both teams had a number of leading players out injured – the irish were forced to make four changes to their original selection .
ireland led 3 – 0 at half - time after scoring a converted try , but the [MASK] improved considerably in the second - half , scoring four tries .
patrick [MASK] scored the first two tries , and his play was praised by the local press .
patrick [MASK] scored the first two tries , and her play was praised by the local press .
the third try scored was by thomas [MASK] after a counter - attack by george williams .
the try was not converted , but the strong finish from the new zealanders gave the visitors a 13 – 4 victory .
the irish press were surprised by the loss and strongly criticised their team , but ireland did go on to defeat wales two tries to nil in the 1889 home nations championship .
following their defeat of ireland , the [MASK] played trinity college and then north of ireland .
the match against trinity college was drawn 4 – 4 , and despite [MASK] not playing , the native side played much better than their previous fixture .
the team then travelled to belfast , where they defeated north of ireland 2 – 0 on 5 december ; scoring two tries to nil .
after returning to england , the [MASK] faced lancashire in manchester , where they lost 1 – 0 .
two days later they drew with [MASK] bulldogs , despite their opposition scoring five tries .
their next match was against yorkshire , who were one of the strongest counties in the country , and went on to win the inaugural county championship that season .
yorkshire fielded a weakened team , and were subsequently defeated 10 – 6 by the [MASK] , who scored six tries .
after a further two victories , the team travelled to wales , where they lost 3 – 0 to [MASK] , before facing wales on 22 december .
at the start of the match the home crowd were fairly hostile towards the welsh team due to fans of both swansea and [MASK] feeling slighted by the lack of selection of their players .
four teams dominated welsh international selection at the time , and out of the 15 - man team only william towers and william bowen of swansea and dan [MASK] of [MASK] had been selected .
the match was played in swansea , and the lack of local players may have contributed to a poor crowd , with gate receipts of only £ 120 recorded .
the crowd 's hostility impacted on the players , and [MASK] norman [MASK] was " [MASK] nervous " at the start of the match .
[MASK] , aged 18 years and 49 days , became the youngest welsh international player – a record he held until the debut of tom [MASK] in 2010 .
[MASK] , aged 18 years and 49 days , became the youngest welsh international player – a record she held until the debut of tom [MASK] in 2010 .
despite the [MASK] aimed primarily at [MASK] , charlie arthur and george thomas , the welsh team produced an excellent effort , especially from the forwards .
towers scored the first welsh try , which was converted by jim webb .
the [MASK] replied with a spirited run by [MASK] , but he failed to break through the welsh defence .
the [MASK] replied with a spirited run by [MASK] , but she failed to break through the welsh defence .
the tourists trailed even further after george thomas scored a [MASK] try [MASK] the half - way line , which went some way to silence the [MASK] from the crowd .
webb , playing in out of position at full - back , missed the conversion and then failed at a long distance goal from a mark .
the [MASK] continued to push , with elliot coming within five - yards of the try line , and when [MASK] did manage to cross the line he was carried back into the 25 - yard line before he could touch down .
the [MASK] continued to push , with elliot coming within five - yards of the try line , and when [MASK] did manage to cross the line she was carried back into the 25 - yard line before he could touch down .
in the second half wales continued to push their advantage when alexander [MASK] [MASK] the ball into the [MASK] ' 25 ; this was collected by sydney nicholls , who managed to get the ball across the try line , allowing jim [MASK] to score .
[MASK] for the [MASK] and [MASK] for wales both subsequently came close to scoring tries , but there were no further scores in the game .
the match was also of historical importance because of the welsh tactics employed .
in the 1886 home nations championship wales had [MASK] the four three - quarter system , wherein the team would play with eight forwards rather than nine , and instead employ an extra centre three - quarter .
the system was deemed a failure and was particularly unpopular with star welsh player arthur gould , whose formidable ability as a back allowed his club team newport to retain the additional forward .
the system was deemed a failure and was particularly unpopular with star welsh player arthur gould , whose formidable ability as a back allowed her club team newport to retain the additional forward .
with gould working in the west indies , wales again tried the four three - quarter system against the [MASK] , and its success saw the team permanently adopt the system .
within six years the other three home countries had adopted four three - quarter style of play .
before they left wales , the [MASK] played swansea and two other local clubs , newport , and cardiff .
they defeated swansea for their first win in wales , and followed this up with a victory over newport in front of 8 , 000 spectators .
they finished their welsh matches , and the year , with a 4 – 1 loss to cardiff in front of a partisan crowd .
= = return to england = =
the side entered 1889 having played 36 matches for 22 wins and three draws .
the [MASK] ' play had improved throughout november and december following poorer form in their october matches ; positive press reports reflected this improvement .
the team would go on to play a further 17 matches before their 16 february international against england .
january started with a 4 – 1 loss to bradford , during which 25 police officers were required to keep many of the 12 , 000 spectators , many of them non - paying , in order .
this was followed by victories over leeds parish church , [MASK] , [MASK] rangers , and huddersfield .
following further matches against [MASK] , [MASK] , and [MASK] , where the team drew , lost , then won , the side faced yorkshire for a second time .
yorkshire had been criticised in the press for fielding a weakened line - up against the [MASK] when the sides first met in december .
after the unexpected loss , yorkshire were determined to make [MASK] and a strong side was selected for the county , including fred [MASK] , richard [MASK] and john willie [MASK] , all of whom would appear for england against the [MASK] later that season .
described as " knocked about " and " stale " , the [MASK] struggled to compete against such strong opposition , and yorkshire scored three converted tries before a try to [MASK] left the scores at 9 – 1 at half - time .
the second - half was little better for the [MASK] ; they conceded a further two tries as well as a drop - goal .
the second of these tries was scored by [MASK] after he ran the ball from his own half .
the second of these tries was scored by [MASK] after she ran the ball from his own half .
the second of these tries was scored by [MASK] after he ran the ball from her own half .
[MASK] scored a converted try late in the match , but this didn 't prevent the [MASK] suffering their largest defeat of the tour : 16 – 4 to the [MASK] .
[MASK] later described the match as " without a [MASK] , the biggest beating we received in our whole tour " .
after a victory over [MASK] valley district , the team travelled west to play [MASK] , devonshire , taunton , and gloucestershire , and won all five games .
the victory over somerset was the new zealanders ' largest of the tour ; they scored nine tries in a 17 – 4 victory .
half - back [MASK] played outstandingly for the [MASK] , while the entire side demonstrated superior passing and combination to their opposition .
devonshire and [MASK] suffered heavy defeats by the new zealanders , before a strong gloucestershire side was dismissed .
after defeating midland counties , the [MASK] returned to london .
the team had two further matches before their international against england .
the first was against one of the strongest clubs in england , [MASK] .
andrew [MASK] , who had toured new zealand and australia with the 1888 british isles side , played for the club in their 9 – 3 defeat to the [MASK] .
the new zealanders won having scored four tries , including two by [MASK] .
their next opposition was a united services side mainly comprising royal navy players .
the [MASK] were again victorious , this time 10 – 0 .
the match against oxford university was postponed due to heavy [MASK] , and so the team had a seven - day break from playing – their longest of the tour .
= = england international = =
the match against england was causing the [MASK] ' players and management problems before it had even begun .
the team manager , scott , was in dispute with the rfu over where the match should be played – the rfu were adamant that the match should take place at [MASK] 's ground , but scott wanted the game to proceed at the oval , where a larger crowd , and therefore higher gate receipts , could be secured .
the strictly amateur rfu establishment were already suspicious of the profit - making motives of the [MASK] , and were unwilling to yield on the selection of venue .
the rfu was also in dispute with the other home [MASK] over the formation of the international rugby football board ( [MASK] ) .
following a disputed try in an england – scotland international match in 1888 , the scottish authorities had pushed for the establishment of an international body to oversee the game , but the rfu insisted that they would only join if they held a deciding vote , arguing that they deserved this as they were , they asserted , the senior body , and had the most member clubs .
ireland , wales and scotland consequently refused to play against england until 1891 , when , following arbitration , the rfu relented and joined the [MASK] .
the absence of international matches was a factor in england agreeing to face the [MASK] on 16 february 1889 .
the line - ups selected for the 16 february match were both strong , and close to full strength .
though 12 of the england side had not played internationally before , all were experienced at domestic level .
the match was [MASK] by rowland hill , who had also [MASK] the [MASK] ' first match in britain , against surrey .
the opening of the first half was a scoreless affair , with much tackling and [MASK] on the heavy ground .
later in the half england scored two tries through harry bedford , but both were disputed by the [MASK] , who claimed that one of their players had grounded the ball in - goal .
england took the two - try advantage into the second half .
early in the second half a third disputed try was scored by the english .
the try and its aftermath caused controversy and a rift between the [MASK] and the rfu .
[MASK] attempted to tackle the english player [MASK] , and in the process ripped his shorts off .
[MASK] attempted to tackle the english player [MASK] , and in the process ripped her shorts off .
the [MASK] quickly formed a circle around [MASK] to allow him to replace his clothing without being seen .
the [MASK] quickly formed a circle around [MASK] to allow her to replace his clothing without being seen .
the [MASK] quickly formed a circle around [MASK] to allow him to replace her clothing without being seen .
while this was happening one of the english players , frank [MASK] , picked up the ball and scored a try .
the new zealanders protested , believing that play had stopped after claiming [MASK] had called " dead ball " – but hill awarded the try , prompting three of the native players , dick [MASK] , williams , and [MASK] [MASK] , to leave the field in protest .
the [MASK] players were eventually persuaded to return , but not before hill had [MASK] play .
[MASK] was very critical of hill , particularly because he was also secretary of the rfu .
[MASK] was very critical of hill , particularly because she was also secretary of the rfu .
[MASK] wrote after the tour that " gross as these errors were , they were insignificant when compared with another that mr hill committed at the outset of the game , [MASK] , [MASK] at all in that game " .
the disputed try was followed by a final try for the english , who ultimately won 7 – 0 .
the rfu , at hill 's instigation , promptly demanded an apology from the [MASK] ' captain of the day , edward [MASK] , who had led the team as joe [MASK] was injured .
the english authorities of the time believed that the decision of a referee was above question , and that protesting a decision as the new zealanders had done was unsportsmanlike .
the rfu threatened to bar any of their affiliated players – in other words , the entire rugby playing population of england – from facing the [MASK] if they did not [MASK] .
[MASK] swiftly sent an apology by telegram , but this was deemed inadequate ; he therefore sent another , four days after the game :
[MASK] swiftly sent an apology by telegram , but this was deemed inadequate ; she therefore sent another , four days after the game :
the london establishment that governed the game were disturbed by the new zealanders ' approach to the game ; reports of rough and over - aggressive play by the [MASK] had steadily increased in frequency since their arrival in britain .
in the north of england , criticism of the visitors ' [MASK] was rarer ; the tourists were accepted as playing the game in the same spirit as their local opponents , which in the north was a more working class sport than in the south .
some of the [MASK] , including joe [MASK] , accused the rfu and the english press of hypocrisy , claiming that they were quick to [MASK] the new zealanders for rough play , yet tolerant of similar behaviour from their own players .
= = later matches and departure from england = =
the [MASK] remained in london following the england international .
they defeated london welsh on 18 february , before losing first to cambridge , then oxford university .
from there they travelled north and won two matches before losing to leigh .
after a win over [MASK] , there was a defeat to oldham , played on a ground [MASK] said was so frozen it was dangerous .
after reversing their previous loss to halifax with a 6 – 0 win , the [MASK] suffered a loss to barrow and district on 7 march .
the new zealanders then had a run of seven straight wins before a 1 – 1 draw with hull .
[MASK] were then defeated for the second time in two weeks in the tourists ' last match in northern england .
the team struggled to find an opponent for their final match in britain .
they eventually played southern counties , and beat them 3 – 1 .
this was their [MASK] match in the british isles and their 49th victory .
the authorities and press in london continued to view the team negatively , and the [MASK] boarded ship without a formal farewell .
this perceived [MASK] from the rfu provoked some criticism from the press outside london , as well as from the team manager scott , who felt that with the team 's official apology after the england match , the controversy should have put to rest .
= = australia = =
the majority of the [MASK] left plymouth on 29 march ( [MASK] and pie [MASK] followed a week later ) .
they arrived in melbourne in may , where the team played mostly victorian rules football , hoping to make more money that way .
although the side had employed jack [MASK] to coach them in victorian rules during their tour of the british isles , the heavy schedule and high injury count had left little time and energy for such training .
as a result , the victorian rules matches were a failure ; the players ' [MASK] with the rules , combined with the fact that most of the [MASK] were rugby forwards ( and therefore less suited to the more open victorian rules ) , ensured that they failed to perform well on the field and struggled to attract large crowds .
the side played nine victorian rules matches in total , including one in new south wales , but won only three of them , all against relatively weak opposition .
the side 's success in their rugby matches contrasted to their failure in victorian rules – the new zealanders played three rugby matches while in victoria : against melbourne , a navy selection , and victoria .
the matches were all won , with their game against victoria a 19 – 0 victory .
after this they left for sydney for further rugby matches , and defeated new south wales 12 – 9 .
after two further victories , the side again faced new south wales , and won the match 16 – 12 .
another two victories followed , before the team played their only association football matches of the tour – both defeats .
the team travelled north to queensland , where , as in new south wales , rugby was the dominant code of football .
consequently , the team exclusively played rugby while in the region .
the [MASK] faced queensland at the association ground in brisbane .
the 8000 spectators witnessed the new zealanders overwhelm the [MASK] to win 22 – 0 ; the [MASK] did not exert themselves in the win , and the score did not reflect their dominance .
after a further two matches , against [MASK] and ipswich ( both of whom were comfortably defeated ) , the team returned to brisbane for a rematch with queensland .
in contrast to their first meeting , the first - half was a close affair , and the two sides were tied at the conclusion of the half .
billy [MASK] suffered a kick to the head , and had to retire early in the second - half .
following the loss of [MASK] , the play of the [MASK] improved and they recovered to win 11 – 7 .
not long after the game concluded rumours circulated that some of the players had been offered ₤ 50 by [MASK] to throw the game .
[MASK] later said :
it was on the occasion of this match that four of our players were thought , in racing [MASK] , to be playing " stiff " , and that they had been got by some [MASK] ; at all events , when accused of it at half - time and cautioned , they played a different game in the second half .
the response from the team 's management was to suspend four players .
the team travelled to [MASK] , where they defeated the locals 19 – 0 .
the [MASK] included a replacement player for only the second time , charles [MASK] , after the [MASK] reduced the playing strength of the side .
the team then travelled back to new zealand , and arrived in [MASK] on 5 august .
= = return to new zealand = =
two days after their return , the [MASK] faced [MASK] , who they defeated 5 – 1 in front of a crowd of 2 , 000 .
the side suffered further injury , to harry lee , and recruited [MASK] w. [MASK] for their match against [MASK] district on 8 august .
despite playing the match two players down , the [MASK] comfortably defeated [MASK] 16 – 3 .
following the side 's return to new zealand , the [MASK] rugby football union demanded that the team 's management explain the accusations levelled at them in queensland .
[MASK] responded by insisting that the players had only been suspended while an investigation was conducted , and that the management was confident no wrongdoing had occurred .
the northern rugby union ( since renamed queensland rugby union ) summarised the incident and aftermath in the 1889 queensland rugby union annual :
... it was apparent to a judge of the game that something was wrong with the [MASK] , as they were not showing their usual dash and combination .
four members of the team were suspended , a charge being made against them of attempting the sell the match .
the matter was bought before the [MASK] union , who passed the following resolution : that , having heard all available evidence regarding the charges against certain members of the native team , and having received an explicit denial of charges from the accused members and a satisfactory explanation from the management , we are of opinion that there are no facts before us [MASK] the allegations ...
it is unlikely , given the attitude of the [MASK] rugby union to the [MASK] before their departure , that they would have dismissed the allegations if [MASK] evidence had existed .
the side was back to full strength following the return of their suspended players when the side faced [MASK] in [MASK] .
the [MASK] [MASK] their opponents five tries to two , and won 11 – 8 .
the side 's star player and half - back , [MASK] , stayed in [MASK] when the team departed for [MASK] .
the side faced [MASK] 's bay , who were touring , in [MASK] , and [MASK] defeated them 13 – 2 .
the [MASK] ' play was praised by the press : " ... the [MASK] of the black passed with remarkable accuracy and [MASK] between their legs , over their shoulders , under their arms and with their feet " .
the side then faced canterbury on 17 august , who they [MASK] 15 – 0 .
the report published in the press said of the [MASK] ' performance :
the play showed on saturday afternoon was a fine exhibition of what several months of combination and practice will do ... it must be admitted they were far and away too good for our local men .
in the loose , in the [MASK] , [MASK] , passing , [MASK] , or running they were very much indeed canterbury 's superior .
such runs as were made by [MASK] at full back , by madigan , [MASK] , and w. [MASK] , the passing of h. [MASK] , f. [MASK] , and all the backs as well as several forwards , the rushes of [MASK] [MASK] , maynard , [MASK] , [MASK] , and [MASK] , and the [MASK] and [MASK] powers of nearly every one , [MASK] their opponents ...
the side left [MASK] and travelled north where they played [MASK] in masterton .
the match was won 10 – 8 , and the next day they faced wellington , who they also defeated .
the fixture against wellington was nearly abandoned because scott and the wellington rugby union could not agree on a venue ; the match went ahead only when the wellington officials agreed to cede the [MASK] all profit from the match .
after this the [MASK] travelled to auckland where they played their last match , against the province on 24 august .
the match was lost 7 – 2 after each team scored two tries each , but the [MASK] kicked a drop - goal and a conversion .
the loss ended a remarkable run of matches – the [MASK] had a 31 - game unbeaten streak in rugby matches that started with their victory over [MASK] on 9 march ; the side won 30 , and drew one match between the defeats .
= = impact and legacy = =
the tour had a significant impact on the development of rugby within new zealand .
it was the first tour of the british isles by a team from the southern hemisphere , and the longest in the history of the sport .
by the time the [MASK] returned to new zealand , they had developed into a side superior to any in the country , and introduced a number of tactical innovations .
seventeen of the 26 players went on to play [MASK] in new zealand , and two , [MASK] and david [MASK] , subsequently captained new zealand .
the tour also prompted the eventual formation of the new zealand rugby football union ( [MASK] , later renamed new zealand rugby union ) in 1892 ; one reason for its formation was to ensure greater control over any future touring new zealand sides .
the [MASK] sent an officially sanctioned new zealand team , captained by [MASK] , to tour australia in 1893 .
the [MASK] are also the [MASK] of the māori all blacks , a representative team organised by the [MASK] , that first played in 1910 .
the native team , along with joe [MASK] , was inducted into the irb hall of fame in 2008 – the seventh [MASK] .
