= = [MASK] and charges = =
on june 27 , 2012 , blythe was arrested by the czech police on suspicion of [MASK] .
lamb of god was prepared to play in prague on june 28 , 2012 , but blythe 's arrest upon arrival at [MASK] airport caused the concert to be canceled .
according to tv nova , blythe stated that he had not been aware of [MASK] 's death and expressed his remorse .
according to tv nova , blythe stated that she had not been aware of [MASK] 's death and expressed his remorse .
according to tv nova , blythe stated that he had not been aware of [MASK] 's death and expressed her remorse .
a police spokesperson stated on june 29 , 2012 that the police had formally charged blythe under section 146 ( 4 ) of the czech criminal code , which contains intentional [MASK] of bodily harm resulting in death ( i.e.
[MASK] ) .
he faced 5 – 10 years of imprisonment if found guilty .
she faced 5 – 10 years of imprisonment if found guilty .
randy 's brother mark blythe said the charge was " [MASK] and [MASK] and will be dropped immediately . "
= = court [MASK] and bail = =
on june 30 , 2012 , the state attorney brought a motion to [MASK] blythe in pre - trial detention , as he considered blythe a flight risk .
on june 30 , 2012 , the state attorney brought a motion to [MASK] blythe in pre - trial detention , as she considered blythe a flight risk .
during a hearing conducted the same day , judge [MASK] [MASK] of the prague 8 district court ruled that blythe will be held on [MASK] , with the possibility of a bail of [MASK] 4 , 000 , 000 ( ~ us $ 200 , 000 ) , blythe 's alleged annual income ; blythe was held in [MASK] prison .
[MASK] was deposited in the court 's bank account on mid - day of july 3 , 2012 .
after this , the state attorney had three working days to either accept the bail or to challenge it by filing a complaint .
due to public holidays it was not until july 9 , 2012 , that the state attorney filed his complaint , which was to be dealt with by [MASK] court , the prague municipal court .
due to public holidays it was not until july 9 , 2012 , that the state attorney filed her complaint , which was to be dealt with by [MASK] court , the prague municipal court .
on july 17 , 2012 , prague municipal court 's panel of three judges headed by judge [MASK] [MASK] overturned the bail decision by doubling the bail amount to [MASK] 8 million ( ~ us $ 400 , 000 ) .
after this , the state attorney challenged the conditions of release , trying to achieve that the bail is subject to blythe staying in the country and / or blythe having to report at a given police station regularly until the criminal proceedings are finished .
on august 2 , 2012 , the [MASK] court rejected the state attorney 's second complaint and ordered blythe 's immediate release .
blythe left the czech republic the next day , claiming in an interview with tv nova that he would return for the trial .
blythe left the czech republic the next day , claiming in an interview with tv nova that she would return for the trial .
= = [MASK] and trial = =
on november 13 , 2012 , the spokesperson of the prague state attorney 's office announced that the police had formally closed their investigation and proposed to the state attorney to [MASK] blythe .
after reviewing the case file , the state attorney indicted blythe on the aforementioned charges on november 30 , 2012 .
two weeks later , a judge set the trial to commence on february 4 , 2013 , with a plan to conduct the hearings in four consecutive days .
blythe was summoned to attend the hearing in person .
the case was heard by a panel of the prague municipal court , consisting of presiding professional judge tomáš [MASK] and two lay judges .
trials in the czech republic are public .
in general , the court is bound to decide on the deed as stated in the [MASK] ; however , it is not bound by its legal assessment by the state attorney .
both the defendant and the state attorney may appeal the decision ; the appeal would be heard by a panel of the prague high court , consisting of three professional judges .
a decision of second instance court is final and [MASK] .
nevertheless , an extraordinary appeal may be lodged by the defendant or the supreme state attorney , which would be heard by the supreme court of the czech republic in [MASK] ; an extraordinary appeal may , however , rest only on issues of law and does not provide for full review of the case .
after exhausting all of these [MASK] , the defendant may also [MASK] a petition to the constitutional court of the czech republic .
the petition may be based on allegation of violation of rights under the czech constitution and charter of [MASK] rights and basic [MASK] .
= = = state attorney [MASK] [MASK] = = =
[MASK] against blythe was brought by state attorney [MASK] [MASK] .
[MASK] had tried a number of murderers , such as [MASK] [MASK] ( life in prison ) , roman [MASK] ( life imprisonment at 1st instance , 25 years on appeal ) , maria [MASK] ( 13 years imprisonment ) and [MASK] [MASK] ( 11 years imprisonment ) .
he also tried a case against [MASK] [MASK] , an alleged head of russian mafia , requesting 25 years in prison for ordering a murder .
she also tried a case against [MASK] [MASK] , an alleged head of russian mafia , requesting 25 years in prison for ordering a murder .
the municipal court in prague acquitted [MASK] due to lack of evidence ; however , the decision was repealed on appeal by the high court , and the case will be heard again by a different [MASK] of the municipal court .
another of [MASK] 's murder cases which ended in [MASK] due to insufficient evidence is that of [MASK] [MASK] , who was indicted in connection with disappearance of [MASK] [MASK] , a vice - chairman of the czech football association .
= = = defense lawyers = = =
randy blythe was represented by prague lawyers martin [MASK] and [MASK] [MASK] .
[MASK] studied law at the faculty of law of charles university and at the new york university .
from 1990 to 1992 , he served as external advisor of the then prime minister [MASK] [MASK] .
from 1990 to 1992 , she served as external advisor of the then prime minister [MASK] [MASK] .
a former partner at baker & [MASK] , [MASK] established [MASK] & co. in 1996 .
he is also a member of board of directors of [MASK] 2000 .
she is also a member of board of directors of [MASK] 2000 .
[MASK] gained fame as attorney of [MASK] [MASK] , a kurdish national who was first charged in 1994 with preparing to commit three murders and committing blackmail and torture .
it became one of the longest criminal cases in the czech history , as the witnesses and alleged victims gradually withdrew or changed their testimonies against [MASK] until he was [MASK] by the municipal court in prague in 2007 .
it became one of the longest criminal cases in the czech history , as the witnesses and alleged victims gradually withdrew or changed their testimonies against [MASK] until she was [MASK] by the municipal court in prague in 2007 .
the court held that although the crimes did take place , there is no evidence that [MASK] took part in it .
he was also defending judge pavel [MASK] , who was indicted of accepting a [MASK] .
she was also defending judge pavel [MASK] , who was indicted of accepting a [MASK] .
the proceedings ended with [MASK] being found insane and [MASK] not liable .
[MASK] also acted as a defense attorney in the case of a [MASK] of czech [MASK] indicted on charges of rape and torture .
during the proceedings , the judge sent [MASK] to face the disciplinary commission of the czech bar association for what he perceived as " behaviour bordering on contempt " .
during the proceedings , the judge sent [MASK] to face the disciplinary commission of the czech bar association for what she perceived as " behaviour bordering on contempt " .

= = = first instance verdict = = =

= u.s. route 2 in michigan =
us highway 2 ( us 2 ) is a component of the united states [MASK] highway system that connects everett , washington , to the upper peninsula ( up ) of the us state of michigan , with a separate segment that runs from [MASK] point , new york , to [MASK] , maine .
in michigan , the highway runs through the up in two segments as a part of the state trunkline highway system , entering the state at [MASK] and ending at st. ignace ; in between , us 2 briefly traverses the state of wisconsin .
as one of the major transportation [MASK] in the up , us 2 is a major conduit for traffic through the state and neighboring northern midwest states .
two sections of the roadway are included as part of the great lakes circle [MASK] , and other segments are listed as state - designated pure michigan [MASK] .
there are several memorial highway designations and historic bridges along us 2 that date to the [MASK] and 1920s .
the highway runs through rural sections of the up , passing through two national and two state forests in the process .
the route of what became us 2 was used as part of two indian trails before european settlers came to the up , and as part of the michigan segments of the theodore roosevelt international highway and the king 's international highway auto trails in the early 20th century .
the state later included these trails as part of m ‑ 12 when the first state highway [MASK] were designated in 1919 .
most of m ‑ 12 was redesignated as part of us 2 when the us highway system was created on november 11 , 1926 .
since the 1930s , several changes have [MASK] the highway 's routing through the up .
one such alteration eventually created a business loop that connected across the state line with hurley , wisconsin , and others pushed an originally inland routing of us 2 closer to the lake michigan shoreline .
with the creation of the interstate highway system , part of us 2 was rerouted to coincide with the new interstate 75 ( i ‑ 75 ) , though in the 1980s , the u.s. highway was truncated and removed from the i ‑ 75 freeway , resulting in today 's basic form .
= = route description = =
according to a 2006 regional planning committee report , us 2 is a key highway for michigan , providing its main western gateway .
the roadway plays " an important role in the transportation of goods across the northern tier of states in the midwest " , and is listed on the national highway system ( nhs ) for its entire length .
the nhs is a network of roadways important to the country 's economy , defense , and mobility .
together with m ‑ 28 , us 2 is part of a pair of primary [MASK] that bridge the eastern and western sides of the up .
the 305 .
 151 miles ( 491 .
 [MASK] km ) of roadway in michigan is divided into a 109 .
 177 - mile ( 175 .
 703 km ) western segment and a 195 .
 [MASK] - mile ( 315 .
 390 km ) eastern segment , interrupted by a section that runs for 14 .
 460 miles ( 23 .
 271 km ) in the state of wisconsin .
= = = western segment = = =
us 2 enters michigan from wisconsin for the first time north of downtown hurley , wisconsin , and [MASK] , michigan , over the state line that runs along the montreal river .
the highway crosses the river into [MASK] county and passes a welcome center on the way into a commercial district north of downtown .
running along [MASK] drive , us 2 meets its only business route in michigan at douglas boulevard .
the business route was previously a full loop that ran west through downtown [MASK] and crossed the border into hurley and back to the main highway .
the wisconsin department of transportation has removed the signage on their side of the border , which reduced the loop to a business spur that ends at the state line .
us 2 continues eastward through up woodlands to the city of [MASK] .
while bypassing the community of ramsay , the highway crosses a branch of the black river .
the roadway enters wakefield on the south side of sunday lake , meeting m ‑ 28 at a [MASK] in town .
as the us highway leaves wakefield , it turns southeasterly through the ottawa national forest , crossing jackson creek and two branches of the [MASK] isle river .
us 2 and m ‑ 64 merge and run concurrently over the second branch of the [MASK] isle in the community of [MASK] .
this concurrency has the lowest traffic volume along the entire length of the highway within the state ; in 2010 the michigan department of transportation ( mdot ) recorded a daily average usage along the stretch of 770 vehicles , compared to the overall average of 5 , 188 vehicles for the highway .
at the end of the concurrency , m ‑ 64 turns northerly to run along lake [MASK] .
the highway continues parallel to the state line from the [MASK] area through the national forest toward [MASK] .
that unincorporated community is the home of the [MASK] high school [MASK] , the basketball team featured on a series of espn commercials and a documentary series on the sundance channel .
the area is also where the waters meet ; the rolling hills drain to lake superior via the [MASK] river , to lake michigan via the [MASK] and [MASK] rivers , or to the gulf of mexico via the wisconsin and mississippi rivers .
also located in the area are the [MASK] wilderness , and the lac [MASK] desert indian [MASK] , which includes the lac [MASK] desert casino and resort .
the highway travels southeasterly from [MASK] around the many lakes and streams in the area and crosses into rural iron county .
us 2 intersects federal forest highway 16 ( [MASK] 16 ) near golden lake in [MASK] township in the middle of the national forest .
the trunkline then runs along the iron river as it approaches the city of the same name and meets m ‑ 73 .
in town , us 2 intersects m ‑ 189 before crossing the river and turning northeast out of the city .
us 2 leaves the ottawa national forest at iron river , and the highway continues eastward through forest lands near several small lakes to crystal falls , the county seat of iron county .
on the west side of town , us 2 meets us 141 ; the two highways run concurrently along crystal avenue .
the combined highway turns south onto 5th street and meets m ‑ 69 's eastern terminus at the intersection between 5th street and superior avenue next to the county [MASK] at the top of the hill .
us 2 / us 141 runs south out of crystal falls to the west of , and parallel to , the [MASK] river .
the roadway passes railroad , kennedy and [MASK] lakes and leaves the state of michigan at the [MASK] river , crossing into florence county , wisconsin for about 14 miles ( 23 km ) .
= = = eastern segment = = =
us 2 / us 141 re - enters michigan where it crosses the [MASK] river and subsequently meets m ‑ 95 in [MASK] township north of iron mountain and [MASK] .
the highways merge in a triple concurrency and run south on [MASK] avenue into iron mountain along the west side of lake antoine , parallel to a branch line of the [MASK] and lake superior railroad ( [MASK] railroad ) .
the road crosses through a retail corridor and over a flooded pit of the [MASK] mine .
in downtown iron mountain at [MASK] street , m ‑ 95 turns west off [MASK] avenue to run across town to [MASK] .
us 2 / us 141 exits downtown and turns east along a second retail corridor near the [MASK] mall .
the highway re - enters [MASK] township where us 141 separates to the south to re - enter wisconsin .
us 2 continues eastward parallel to a branch of the canadian national railway ( [MASK] railway ) .
both road and rail travel through the community of [MASK] , where they pass near the largest paper mill in the up .
the trunkline runs along the main street of norway , where the highway meets the eastern terminus of us 8 .
then us 2 continues east through rural dickinson county to vulcan , passing north of [MASK] lake through the [MASK] country state forest , before crossing the sturgeon river in [MASK] and passing into [MASK] county .
in [MASK] county , the environment takes on a more agricultural character along us 2 .
the highway passes through the edge of the community of [MASK] before entering powers .
us 2 comes to a three - way intersection and turns northeast merging onto us 41 .
the concurrent highway runs from powers through the communities of wilson and [MASK] on the south side of the [MASK] railway .
at harris , the trunkline enters the [MASK] indian community .
harris is on the [MASK] county side of the reservation , but as the highway continues east , it crosses over to [MASK] river on the delta county side .
the county line in between not only separates the two communities , but also serves as the boundary between the central and eastern time zones .
east of [MASK] river , the highway crosses the community 's namesake waterway before intersecting the eastern terminus of m ‑ 69 .
the roadway crosses the ford river prior to turning due east into the outskirts of [MASK] .
us 2 / us 41 [MASK] to four lanes along [MASK] street , which forms the east – west axis of the [MASK] street grid .
near downtown , the highway meets m ‑ 35 , which runs along the city 's north – south axis , lincoln avenue .
the [MASK] merge and run north , bypassing the traditional central business district for a different business corridor .
lincoln avenue runs north carrying four lanes of traffic past the upper peninsula state [MASK] , site of one of the two state [MASK] for the state of michigan , the only state to have twin [MASK] .
us 2 / us 41 / m ‑ 35 continues north on lincoln avenue past the campus of bay de [MASK] community college .
the four - lane highway crosses the [MASK] river just upstream from its mouth near the large mead paper mill and shifts to run immediately next to little bay de [MASK] .
the section here carried the highest traffic counts along all of us 2 in the state : an average of 23 , 977 vehicles used this segment of roadway daily in 2011 .
the road turns inland again , and us 2 / us 41 / m ‑ 35 passes to the west of downtown gladstone .
the highway through here is an expressway , four lanes divided by a central median and no [MASK] access .
unlike a freeway , the expressway has standard intersections and not interchanges .
the highway intersects the eastern terminus of county road 426 ( cr 426 ) and crosses the [MASK] railroad south of the [MASK] for 4th avenue north , where m ‑ 35 separates from the us highways and turns to the northwest .
the expressway continues north parallel to the [MASK] railway , crossing the days river .
through this area , the trunkline carries a speed limit of 65 mph ( 105 km / h ) for car traffic .
this is the only road in the up with a speed limit higher than 55 mph ( 89 km / h ) besides i - 75 , which has a speed limit of 70 mph ( 110 km / h ) .
the expressway segment runs around the upper end of little bay de [MASK] before ending at rapid river .
in this location , us 41 separates to the north , and us 2 returns to an easterly track as a two - lane road , crossing the rapid and [MASK] rivers and turning southeast around the head of the bay .
as us 2 crosses southern delta county , it passes through the western unit of the [MASK] national forest .
near garden corners , the highway runs along the shore of big bay de [MASK] .
after the intersection with the northern terminus of m ‑ 183 , us 2 turns inland cutting across the base of the garden peninsula and enters schoolcraft county .
as the highway approaches thompson , us 2 leaves the western unit of the [MASK] national forest and enters the lake superior state forest .
the roadway runs along lake michigan to [MASK] , crossing the [MASK] river .
the trunkline turns inland approaching [MASK] and then turns north - northeast to blaney park .
the community there is a former logging town - turned - resort at the southern terminus of m ‑ 77 ; the resort was active from the late 1920s but declined by the 1980s .
from blaney park , us 2 turns due east and crosses into mackinac county west of gould city .
where it intersects a former routing , the main highway crosses the [MASK] railway one last time and runs to the south of [MASK] to follow the lake michigan shoreline through [MASK] .
after passing the community of [MASK] , us 2 crosses the cut river bridge , 147 feet ( 45 m ) over the cut river .
the highway crosses into the eastern unit of the [MASK] national forest near [MASK] , running between lake michigan and [MASK] lake in the process .
the road continues along the lake michigan shoreline , passing [MASK] spot near [MASK] cap and turning inland immediately west of st. ignace .
the us 2 designation ends at the highway 's partial cloverleaf interchange with i ‑ 75 .
the roadway continues easterly into downtown st. ignace as business loop i ‑ 75 ( bl i ‑ 75 ) .
= = history = =
= = = indian trail through auto trails = = =
in 1701 , the first transportation routes through what became the state of michigan were the lakes , rivers and indian trails .
two of these trails followed parts of the future us 2 .
the [MASK] – green bay trail roughly followed the lake michigan shoreline routing of us 2 between [MASK] and st. ignace .
the mackinac trail connected st. ignace with [MASK] [MASK] .
marie .
in the age of the auto trail , the roads that later formed us 2 through the up were given a few different highway names .
when the original roadways between [MASK] and iron river were completed in late 1915 , the upper peninsula development bureau ( [MASK] ) named the area [MASK] and the highway the [MASK] trail .
later the name was extended over the highway to [MASK] , and to all highways in the area in the early 1920s ; the name was phased out by the [MASK] completely in 1927 .
the roadways were also used for the theodore roosevelt international highway , named for former us president theodore roosevelt after his death in 1919 .
the roadways were also used for the theodore roosevelt international highway , named for former us president theodore roosevelt after her death in 1919 .
overall , this highway ran from portland , oregon , to portland , maine , by way of michigan and the canadian province of ontario .
through the up , the southern branch followed the immediate predecessors to us 2 , including the section through florence county , wisconsin .
the great lakes automobile route was established in 1917 by the [MASK] .
a predecessor of the great lakes circle [MASK] by seventy years , the route followed " a circular journey along the banks of lakes michigan and superior and green bay ... " this route followed the modern us 2 from [MASK] to the m ‑ 94 junction in [MASK] , using the modern m ‑ 69 and m ‑ 95 to stay in michigan .
[MASK] of the route followed us 41 and m ‑ 35 between powers and [MASK] .
the route was originally intended to entice motorists to drive around lake michigan .
the name fell out of use before its first anniversary because of world war i.
one canadian auto trail was routed through the up as well .
in 1920 , the king 's international highway linked vancouver , british columbia , to halifax , nova scotia , but there was no highway to carry it around the north side of lake superior .
[MASK] had to ship their cars by boat between [MASK] [MASK] .
marie , ontario , and thunder bay or enter the united states to continue along the auto trail .
the [MASK] varied on the maps of the time , but its basic route used us 2 through the up from [MASK] to [MASK] [MASK] .
marie until a highway north of lake superior was opened in 1960 ; by that time , the auto trail had taken on the trans - canada highway name .
= = = state trunkline = = =
the first state trunkline highway designated along the path of the modern us 2 was m ‑ 12 , a designation that was in use by july 1 , 1919 , between [MASK] and [MASK] [MASK] .
marie .
the first roadside park in the country was created by herbert [MASK] near what is now us 2 near iron river in 1919 – 20 , although other sources state that the first was a picnic table alongside us 16 ( grand river avenue ) in 1929 south of [MASK] .
when the us highway system was created on november 11 , 1926 , us 2 partially replaced m - 12 .
between crystal falls and iron mountain , us 2 was routed through florence , wisconsin .
the former routing of m ‑ 12 from crystal falls to [MASK] became a new m ‑ 69 when the former m ‑ 69 became us 102 ( now us 141 ) .
m ‑ 12 from [MASK] south to iron mountain was made a part of an extended m ‑ 45 , which is now m ‑ 95 .
by the next year , m ‑ 48 was added along us 2 from [MASK] to [MASK] as part of a larger extension .
the first changes to the routing of us 2 itself were made in 1930 with a bypass of downtown [MASK] .
a larger [MASK] was completed in 1933 between rogers park and [MASK] [MASK] .
marie .
the new routing followed mackinac trail instead of turning east to [MASK] and north to [MASK] [MASK] .
marie ; the former routing was given the m ‑ 121 designation .
another realignment in the iron mountain area shifted us 2 / us 141 to a new bridge over the [MASK] river between 1932 and 1934 .
downtown [MASK] was bypassed in 1934 , and the former route was initially designated m ‑ 54 .
the michigan state highway department ( mshd ) changed the [MASK] and designations of the highways around [MASK] , thompson and [MASK] in the mid - 1930s .
the agency rerouted us 2 between [MASK] and m ‑ 149 in thompson , turning the old road back to county control .
the section between m ‑ 149 and m ‑ 125 was redesignated as an extension of m ‑ 149 to thompson , and m ‑ 125 was replaced by a further extension of m ‑ 149 .
the last change was to route us 2 along its current alignment in the area , completing the changes on august 2 , 1936 .
the mshd started construction in 1936 on a new road that rerouted us 2 into st. ignace for the first time .
between [MASK] and [MASK] , us 2 previously followed worth road inland to the [MASK] trail to meet the northern extension of us 31 into the upper peninsula .
the new routing took us 2 along the [MASK] into st. ignace .
us 31 was truncated to the state ferry docks in mackinaw city and us 2 was routed through st. ignace along the former us 31 to rogers park ; the connection in st. ignace to the state ferry docks became m ‑ 122 .
further changes in the early 1940s [MASK] the roadway out near [MASK] and crystal falls .
additional [MASK] were completed by the mshd to move us 2 to its modern [MASK] routing between gould city and [MASK] in 1941 .
the new highway traveled due east from gould city to [MASK] and then along the lake to [MASK] .
the former route through [MASK] was turned back to local control as far east as [MASK] .
from there east , it was numbered just m ‑ 48 , removing us 2 from a concurrency .
another former section into [MASK] was added to extend m ‑ 117 .
the new highway was [MASK] around the cut river bridge until it was completed in 1946 after construction delays over steel shortages during world war ii .
the western end of us 2 took on two changes in the 1940s .
m ‑ 28 was extended along us 2 to the state line at [MASK] from its western terminus at wakefield .
a similar extension was made from m ‑ 28 's eastern terminus to [MASK] [MASK] .
marie in 1948 .
the m ‑ 54 designation was renumbered as business us 2 by 1945 .
the eastern m ‑ 28 extension was reversed in 1950 , and the western extension to the state line was shifted to a new location by 1952 .
= = = interstate era = = =
with the coming of the interstate highway system in michigan , the mshd planned to convert the eastern section of us 2 to a freeway between st. ignace and [MASK] st. marie .
in planning maps from 1947 , this highway corridor was included in the system that later became the [MASK] .
it was also included in the general location of national system of interstate highways including all additional routes at urban areas [MASK] in september 1955 , or yellow book after the cover color , that was released in 1955 as the federal government [MASK] plans for the freeway system .
the proposed number in 1958 was interstate 75 ( i ‑ 75 ) .
the first section of freeway was built in late 1957 or early 1958 between [MASK] [MASK] and m ‑ 123 north of st. ignace .
the mackinac bridge was opened to traffic on november 1 , 1957 ; a new section of freeway and an interchange connected us 2 to the bridge .
in 1961 , another new freeway segment closed the gap between the mackinac bridge and [MASK] [MASK] sections .
at the time , the i ‑ 75 designation [MASK] us 27 on the bridge , and us 2 was shifted to follow i ‑ 75 along the freeways in the st. ignace area .
the former routing of us 2 in downtown st. ignace was redesignated bl i ‑ 75 .
more sections of freeway were opened in 1962 immediately to the south of the newly constructed international bridge in [MASK] [MASK] .
marie as well as between [MASK] and [MASK] .
the last two sections opened in 1963 connected the northern end of the freeway at m ‑ 123 to [MASK] , and the section between [MASK] and [MASK] [MASK] .
marie .
at this time , all of us 2 's former routing became a county road known as mackinac trail ( h - 63 ) .
the department of state highways expanded us 2 / us 41 into an expressway between gladstone and rapid river in 1971 .
the state built a new bridge over the [MASK] river in 1983 , bypassing downtown .
mdot disposed of the former routing of us 2 into downtown in two ways .
the western half was initially an unnumbered state highway until it was later transferred to local control .
an extension of m ‑ 94 replaced the remainder , including the [MASK] bridge , through downtown .
in that same year , the department truncated us 2 to end in st. ignace by removing it from the i ‑ 75 freeway .
the last changes were made to us 2 's routing through iron river in 1998 , bypassing the bridge that formerly carried the highway over the river in town .
in 2011 , mdot raised the speed limit along the expressway section in delta county from 55 to 65 mph ( 89 to 105 km / h ) , although the speed limit for trucks remains 55 mph ( 89 km / h ) .
= = memorial designations and tourist routes = =
on july 1 , 1924 , the state administrative board named m ‑ 12 , the predecessor to us 2 in michigan , the [MASK] highway to honor frank p. [MASK] , a prominent local citizen who later served in congress from 1927 to 1933 .
in 1929 , the residents of [MASK] created a memorial to the veterans of world war i called memory lane .
the project consisted of [MASK] and maple trees planted along us 2 / us 41 west of town .
the american legion sold the trees to local businesses and individuals who could honor specific soldiers .
later in 1949 , the [MASK] women 's club created a tribute in the form of a permanent living memorial to the area veterans .
also called memory lane , the group planted 140 [MASK] and 1 , 840 [MASK] , trees and shrubs as a [MASK] parkway along 2 .
 3 miles ( 3 .
 7 km ) of us 2 east of [MASK] .
most of us 2 , along with us 23 in the lower peninsula , was designated the united spanish war veterans memorial highway in 1949 .
to connect the gap in the routing where us 2 cuts through wisconsin , m ‑ 95 and m ‑ 69 were used in place of us 2 between iron mountain and crystal falls .
signs marking the highway were not erected until 1968 when governor george w. romney had them installed .
the [MASK] memorial drive designation was created for the section of us 2 / us 41 / m ‑ 35 between the northern [MASK] city limits and county road 426 ( cr 426 ) in delta county .
the american veterans ( [MASK] ) organization in michigan petitioned the michigan legislature to grant this designation , which was assigned under public act 144 in 1959 .
two sections of us 2 are part of the overall great lakes circle tour ( [MASK] ) : the segment from the wisconsin state line near [MASK] to the m ‑ 28 junction in wakefield is part of the lake superior circle tour ( [MASK] ) , and the segment from the southern m ‑ 35 junction in [MASK] to the eastern terminus in st. ignace is part of the lake michigan circle tour ( [MASK] ) .
these two tours were created in may 1986 through a joint effort between mdot and its counterparts in wisconsin , minnesota and ontario .
the section of us 2 between iron river and crystal falls has been named the iron county heritage trail .
this pure michigan byway was designated to honor the " rich history of two industries that built a state and nation : mining and logging . "
on august 26 , 2007 , mdot announced that the section of us 2 that runs concurrently with m ‑ 35 in delta county was being included in the up [MASK] coast recreational heritage trail .
= = historic bridges = =
there are six bridges along current or former sections of us 2 that mdot has added to its listing of michigan 's historic bridges ; two of these are also listed on the national register of historic places ( [MASK] ) .
a third bridge added to the [MASK] in late 2012 has not been added to mdot 's listing however .
the first of these historic bridges is the crossing of the iron river , which has since been bypassed by a new bridge .
the original structure , dating to 1918 , is a 55 - foot - long ( 17 m ) [MASK] arch span that was built by the mshd as trunk line bridge no.
191 .
the structure was listed on the [MASK] on december 9 , 1999 , for its architectural and engineering significance .
in december 2012 , the national park service approved the listing of the upper twin falls bridge that crosses the [MASK] river northwest of iron mountain .
the structure is a single - span , pin - connected , [MASK] , through - [MASK] bridge , and it is the only known example of its type in michigan .
it was built between 1909 and 1910 because the twin falls power dam would flood an existing river crossing .
the span cost $ 5 , 106 ( equivalent to $ 780 , 000 in 2015 ) , paid equally by dickinson and florence counties .
until the 1930s , the upper twin falls bridge carried us 2 across the [MASK] river .
in 1934 , a new bridge was built about a mile downstream , and the highway was rerouted over the new span .
the bridge closed to automobile traffic in september 1971 , and the nomination process for inclusion on the national register of historic places began in 2012 .
in 2003 , mdot replaced the sturgeon river bridge in [MASK] township , dickinson county .
as of october 2011 , even though the old bridge was demolished and replaced , mdot retained it on their historic bridge list .
it was built in 1929 .
before 1983 , us 2 used a different routing through [MASK] and crossed the [MASK] river on what is nicknamed the " [MASK] bridge " .
built as a part of a [MASK] [MASK] on the river , the water level is actually higher than the road surface .
this produces a [MASK] effect , giving the bridge its nickname .
the [MASK] [MASK] and paper company was organized in 1916 and needed a dam on the [MASK] river to supply their mill .
this dam would require a large section of the city to be flooded , and shallow river banks meant difficulties in any bridge construction .
instead of expensive [MASK] , a concrete tank was built [MASK] in the river bed ; the sides of this tank provided man - made banks higher than the natural banks .
the michigan works progress administration described the bridge as having " concrete bulkheads , formed by the side spans of the bridge , [ that ] allow the mill to maintain the water level several feet above the roadbed . "
the [MASK] tourism council stated : " at one time , the bridge itself was partially supported by the water that was [MASK] forced under it , " and that the bridge has been featured in ripley 's believe it or not !
.
the eight - span structure is [MASK] feet ( 90 m ) long .
the cut river bridge carries us 2 across the cut river in [MASK] township , mackinac county .
this structure was built during world war ii but completion was delayed due to war - induced steel shortages .
the span uses [MASK] short tons ( [MASK] long tons ; [MASK] t ) of structural steel to bridge the [MASK] feet ( 195 m ) over the river and its [MASK] at a height of 147 feet ( 45 m ) above the river .
the cut river bridge is one of only two [MASK] deck [MASK] bridges in the state .
on either side of the bridge , there are picnic areas and trails down to the river .
listed on the [MASK] on december 17 , 1999 , the mackinac trail – [MASK] river bridge carries h - 63 , the modern successor to us 2 , over the [MASK] river north of st. ignace .
the bridge is another [MASK] arch structure 60 feet ( 18 m ) in length and built in 1920 .
increasing traffic along mackinac trail prompted the mshd to " widen its deck by five feet [ 1 .
 5 m ] and install new [MASK] in the 1929 – 1930 [MASK] " along with the addition of decorative retaining walls .
the last of the historic bridges along a former segment of us 2 is the structure carrying [MASK] street ( bs i ‑ 75 ) over the power canal in [MASK] [MASK] .
marie .
built in 1934 , it is one of only three steel arch bridges in the state .
the 42 - foot - wide ( 13 m ) and 257 - foot - long ( 78 m ) structure is described by mdot as " massive " with an " innovative " construction method : the previous structure was used as a [MASK] for the current bridge before removal .
= = major intersections = =
mdot has erected [MASK] along the two michigan segments of the highway that use the total [MASK] starting at the state line in [MASK] ; the signs on the eastern segment reflect the [MASK] in florence county , wisconsin .
= = business route = =
business u.s. highway 2 ( bus .
us 2 ) is a 1 .
 270 - mile ( 2 .
 [MASK] km ) business route that runs from the wisconsin state line at the montreal river .
the route extends through downtown [MASK] on silver and aurora streets before turning northward along suffolk street .
bus .
us 2 stays on suffolk street for a short while until it turns onto frederick street .
on frederick street , bus .
us 2 bears north through a residential area along douglas street .
the eastern terminus of the route is at its junction with us 2 at the corner of [MASK] drive and douglas street north of downtown .
the business route was created in august 1942 when former m ‑ 54 in [MASK] was renumbered as a business loop of us 2 .
it was originally a bi - state business connection before the wisconsin department of transportation decommissioned bus .
us 2 in hurley westward along state trunk highway 77 and northward along us 51 in 2002 .
= butterfly world tour =
the butterfly world tour was the third concert tour by american singer - songwriter mariah carey .
the tour promoted carey 's album at the time , butterfly ( 1997 ) , and included songs from several of her previous albums .
the tour promoted carey 's album at the time , butterfly ( 1997 ) , and included songs from several of him previous albums .
the tour promoted carey 's album at the time , butterfly ( 1997 ) , and included songs from several of his previous albums .
the tour visited asia , australia and the united states , with rehearsals taking place in december 1997 .
starting on january 11 , 1998 the tour spanned five shows in asia , six in australia , and one in hawaii , us .
throughout the tour , carey varied hairstyles and outfits , as well as song selections .

= [MASK] [MASK] =
[MASK] [MASK] , also known as button 's mill is a grade ii * listed tower mill constructed of brick .
the [MASK] is located at [MASK] , suffolk , england .
it was built in the early nineteenth century to grind wheat into flour .
[MASK] [MASK] worked by wind power until 1924 , [MASK] on two sails , after which it became [MASK] .
in 1979 , a group of enthusiasts purchased [MASK] [MASK] for restoration .
numerous volunteers helped to restore the mill to full working order over an eight - year period .
the mill is open to the public , and flour ground at the mill can be bought at the site .
the mill is a small four storey tower mill with patent sails and [MASK] by a [MASK] .
it drives two pairs of [MASK] , with a third pair driven by an auxiliary engine .
= = history = =
the [MASK] at [MASK] was built by [MASK] george [MASK] for william button in 1819 .
it replaced a post mill which had been moved to sandy lane , [MASK] , norfolk the previous year .
the mill was set to work on christmas day 1819 .
in 1832 , the mill was modernised by the fitting of a cast - iron [MASK] , patent sails and a [MASK] .
the new [MASK] was fitted on 16 july 1832 .
it was made by j [MASK] , the kings lynn [MASK] , and weighs 1 [MASK] tons ( 1 , 780 kg ) .
a new stock was fitted in september 1836 .
william button died on 11 february 1837 .
the mill passed jointly to his widow rebecca and their son richard .
the mill passed jointly to her widow rebecca and their son richard .
richard button worked the mill until 1860 , at which date it was conveyed to his sons richard and william , who sold it to richard [MASK] from [MASK] , norfolk in 1862 .
richard button worked the mill until 1860 , at which date it was conveyed to her sons richard and william , who sold it to richard [MASK] from [MASK] , norfolk in 1862 .
the mill was worked by stephen [MASK] , richard 's son .
he inherited the mill on the death of his father in 1875 and leased it to henry bryant in 1879 .
she inherited the mill on the death of his father in 1875 and leased it to henry bryant in 1879 .
he inherited the mill on the death of her father in 1875 and leased it to henry bryant in 1879 .
in 1884 , the mill was sold by auction , and henry bryant purchased the [MASK] .
bryant rebuilt the floors of the mill .
from 1892 , a portable steam engine was used as auxiliary power , driving an extra pair of [MASK] on the ground floor .
this was replaced in 1914 by a [MASK] oil engine .
bryant ran the mill until 1920 when he sold it to [MASK] vincent , a retired [MASK] from [MASK] , norfolk .
bryant ran the mill until 1920 when she sold it to [MASK] vincent , a retired [MASK] from [MASK] , norfolk .
the [MASK] engine was sold in the early 1920s .
the mill was [MASK] [MASK] , and as a result one pair of sails was removed .
vincent carried out some repairs to the mill and ran it until he retired in 1924 .
vincent carried out some repairs to the mill and ran it until she retired in 1924 .
one of the remaining two sails was wrecked in 1926 when the mill was again [MASK] .
on the death of [MASK] vincent in 1932 , his son george inherited the property .
on the death of [MASK] vincent in 1932 , her son george inherited the property .
he lived at the site in an old [MASK] until his death in 1973 .
she lived at the site in an old [MASK] until his death in 1973 .
he lived at the site in an old [MASK] until her death in 1973 .
the mill passed to his daughter , who sold it in 1974 to mr and mrs [MASK] , who intended to convert it into a house .
the mill passed to her daughter , who sold it in 1974 to mr and mrs [MASK] , who intended to convert it into a house .
they later changed their minds and offered it for sale for restoration .
in 1976 , the cap of the mill was blown to pieces in a gale .
[MASK] [MASK] was purchased by five members of the suffolk mills group in november 1979 , and plans for restoration were made .
the consortium consisted of mark [MASK] , charles [MASK] , peter [MASK] , david [MASK] and chris [MASK] .
the [MASK] mill and an acre of land cost £ 6 , 000 .
= = restoration = =
the mill was restored over a period of six years .
much of the work was carried out by enthusiasts who used working holidays to repair the mill .
= = = 1979 – 1980 = = =
the consortium took possession of the mill in november 1979 .
the first priority was to make the mill as [MASK] as possible .
[MASK] sheets were spread on the dust floor of the mill to prevent further water penetration of the structure .
the mill was surveyed and recorded .
in spring 1980 , the dust floor partially collapsed and was removed as a safety measure .
[MASK] was erected to allow the [MASK] to be dismantled , and the cap centering wheels were removed in preparation for the removal of the cap frame .
a two - week work - in was held at the end of july and beginning of august 1980 .
thirty - three volunteers worked on the mill over the work - in .
two new main floor beams for the dust floor were made from [MASK] of pitch pine which had previously been in a [MASK] at bury st [MASK] .
on 3 august 1980 , the [MASK] and remaining sail fragments were removed by a mobile crane , followed by the cap frame and the cast - iron curb sections .
new oak [MASK] were laid on the dust floor and temporary boarding laid to provide a working platform for repairs to the top of the mill tower .
the bin floor was removed , apart from one oak main beam which was [MASK] .
a replacement main beam was made from pitch pine , and the oak beam was repaired .
new oak [MASK] were fitted , along with some salvaged from the original floor which were fit to be reused .
one of these had previously been a whip from a common sail .
some of the [MASK] were made from pitch pine from the [MASK] [MASK] , which , following its collapse on 19 february 1977 , had been re - erected at the museum of east anglian life , [MASK] .
the [MASK] hoist was dismantled to enable its repair , brickwork was repaired , and new [MASK] were made for some of the windows .
a [MASK] was secured over the mill tower to keep the weather out over winter .
the [MASK] on the bin floor were replaced and one of the two pairs of [MASK] was removed .
the work was financed by grants of £ 500 from the council for the preservation of rural essex , £ 250 from st [MASK] borough council , £ 200 from the [MASK] trust , and £ 200 from the suffolk mills group .
other donations and income amounted to £ 65 , with the balance of expenditure being met jointly by the five owners .
the " work - in " was reported in both local and national media , including bbc look east , bury free press , eastern daily press , east anglian daily times , daily telegraph , and radio orwell .
= = = 1981 = = =
in the 1981 season two separate work - ins were held , the first from 25 july to 2 august and the second from 22 august to 30 august .
a total of 37 volunteers participated over the two weeks .
the [MASK] were removed from the stone floor , which was then repaired .
one of the main beams was found to have been attacked by death watch beetles , and over a third of the [MASK] beam was replaced with oak .
the six supports for the [MASK] frame were repaired one at a time , as they bore the whole of the weight of the machinery above .
one post required replacement .
it had [MASK] and the floor had sunk by 4 inches ( 100 mm ) causing the second main floor beam to fracture .
when this work had been completed , the stone floor was removed , including the second main floor beam , which was removed in one piece so that the most suitable route to install its replacement could be assessed .
the new main beam for the stone floor was installed and the ground floor was [MASK] .
the stone floor was reconstructed , reusing the old stone bearers and those [MASK] that were fit for reuse .
other [MASK] were made new from oak or pitch pine .
new [MASK] were laid in the dust floor , the 1 1 ⁄ 4 inches ( 32 mm ) thick [MASK] boards being double - grooved with a metal tongue between them .
those on the bin floor are of a similar configuration .
the top four courses of brickwork of the mill tower were removed and work began on rebuilding them , aided by a [MASK] attached to the upright shaft .
during the second work - in , the remainder of the stone floor was boarded , again using double - grooved boards with a metal tongue between them .
the window on the dust floor was rebuilt and the reconstruction of the top four courses of brickwork continued .
the top two courses were rebuilt with red engineering bricks .
the dust floor window had a reinforced concrete [MASK] cast as the tower was weak at this point and had distorted .
the [MASK] , the curb segments and [MASK] [MASK] were given two coats of red lead paint .
a new [MASK] for the cap was made from a piece of oak 3 feet ( 910 mm ) long by 16 inches ( 410 mm ) diameter .
a start was made on removing the old pointing on the brickwork and [MASK] with [MASK] mortar .
after the work - in had finished , the boarding of the stone floor was completed and the mill thoroughly cleaned in preparation for an open day which was held in late autumn .
the work done in 1981 cost £ 3 , 250 .
[MASK] received were £ 2 , 000 from [MASK] [MASK] , £ 1 , [MASK] from the historic buildings council and £ 130 from st [MASK] borough council .
other donations and income received amounted to £ 70 .
the project received further coverage in local media , the eastern daily press , and south norfolk news .
= = = 1982 = = =
the 1982 work - ins took place from 24 july to 1 august and 21 august to 29 august .
the work planned included the completion of the brickwork at the top of the tower , installation of the [MASK] curb , a start on the construction of the new cap , installing machinery and making and fitting various doors and windows .
the cap frame was constructed , incorporating two beams from the original cap frame that were fit to be reused .
the cap frame was completed in autumn 1982 .
it had been constructed upside down and a mobile crane was used to turn it over and place the [MASK] into position .
= = = 1983 = = =
work in the early part of 1983 was mainly confined to smaller jobs such as casting various [MASK] and overhaul of the various parts of the [MASK] [MASK] and mechanism for controlling the patent sails .
the mill was generally made as safe as possible inside in preparation for scheduled visits , including one from the wind and [MASK] section of the society for the protection of ancient buildings .
other work included the overhaul of the final drive to the 4 feet 7 inches ( 1 .
 40 m ) stones , including [MASK] the stone nut and replacement of three [MASK] in beech .
when the weather improved , work commenced outside .
the cap circle was mostly constructed before the first work - in commenced .
the work - ins took place over two separate weeks in july and august , with 35 people participating .
during the first work - in , the [MASK] posts and [MASK] were fitted .
the oak cap ribs , which had been prefabricated [MASK] were fitted and the [MASK] was supported by scaffolding ready for final fitting .
[MASK] [MASK] of oak were fitted and the [MASK] was pulled into position using a [MASK] .
the cap frame was competed with the fitting of intermediate ribs and [MASK] .
the rear of the cap circle was also completed during this time .
between the two work - ins , the rear [MASK] was completed and the fitting of [MASK] to the cap frame completed .
this enabled a start to be made on boarding the cap on the monday of the second work - in .
the boards for the cap are ½ inch ( 13 mm ) thick and 9 inches ( 230 mm ) wide at the [MASK] , [MASK] towards the top .
a new neck bearing was installed under the [MASK] , not without difficulty and much [MASK] before it would fit .
when the boarding of the cap was completed , the cover strips were fitted over the joints .
the [MASK] was drawn into position using a rope and [MASK] , and the [MASK] steel reinforcing band [MASK] into position , producing a [MASK] structure .
the striking rod was fitted through the [MASK] and the axle for the [MASK] fitted in position on top of the [MASK] posts .
at the top of the mill tower , the curb was prepared to accept the cap , and the cast iron curb track plates [MASK] into position .
[MASK] of the brickwork of the tower continued , with nearly half of it completed at the end of the second work - in .
after the work - ins had ended , work continued on finishing the cap which was scheduled for lift - on in october .
the weather hampered the work initially , but the application of a modern [MASK] paint , designed to withstand normal movement of the timber and yet remain [MASK] , was completed in time for the lift - on .
a mini work - in was held the weekend before the cap was lifted , with 17 people participating over the weekend .
final work was done to the cap and a new window was fitted to the stone floor of the mill .
the [MASK] was removed and the [MASK] dismantled .
the 5 - ton cap was lifted into place by a mobile crane on 24 october 1983 , watched by a crowd of some 70 people .
the fitting of the cap was [MASK] with beer from [MASK] [MASK] , [MASK] .
restoration work in 1983 cost £ 1 , [MASK] .
grants were received from the association of independent museums , [MASK] ' norton women 's institute , ipswich historical transport society , the national association for [MASK] children , mr d. porter and the society for the protection of ancient buildings .
further income came from the sale of guide books and a drawing of the mill by [MASK] [MASK] .
= = = 1984 = = =
four work - ins were held during 1984 .
the first two were by [MASK] from eastern electricity board .
[MASK] [MASK] was chosen at the project to benefit from the young person 's development project for that year .
[MASK] [MASK] had previously benefited from the project , and its owners , the suffolk preservation trust , had suggested that [MASK] [MASK] would be a good candidate for the scheme .
two separate parties spent a week each at the mill .
a [MASK] electricity supply was provided .
an underground cable was laid with assistance from british telecom who were [MASK] a thrust [MASK] which had been developed at their research facility at [MASK] heath .
the thrust [MASK] laid 25 yards ( 23 m ) of [MASK] through which the [MASK] cable was pulled into position .
the mill was then supplied with lights and [MASK] on each floor .
other work undertaken by the [MASK] involved repairing some [MASK] damage to the foundation brickwork , digging a drainage trench around the mill and moving the auxiliary engine into position .
a concrete path around the tower was trapping moisture , leading to rising [MASK] .
a french drain was constructed around the mill to remedy these problem .
a 21 horsepower ( 16 kw ) [MASK] & [MASK] [MASK] diesel engine had been purchased in 1981 and was fitted onto a permanent concrete base with the aid of a mobile crane .
after fitting it was then painted .
some missing or broken parts were made or repaired as necessary .
off - site , the new brake wheel and [MASK] were made .
the original brake wheel was too rotten to repair , and showed evidence that it had been altered from the original one installed in 1819 .
the original brake wheel was 6 feet ( 1 .
 83 m ) diameter to allow the common sails to run at their [MASK] speed .
when the mill was modernised in 1832 it was necessary to alter the gear ratios within the mill , as patent sails run at a slower speed than common sails .
the great spur wheel was increased in diameter and the stone nuts reduced in diameter .
the brake wheel was also rebuilt , with a cast iron segment ring fitted in place of the original [MASK] , resulting in a wheel 7 feet 2 inches ( 2 .
 18 m ) in diameter .
the opinion of professional [MASK] was sought , and it was decided that a scaled - up version of the original brake wheel would be made , but retaining the cast iron teeth segments .
the remains of the original brake wheel were retained as an exhibit in the mill .
the original iron segments were all broken , so a pattern was made and new segments were cast in heat - treated malleable cast iron .
when the brake wheel was completed it was dismantled and transported to the mill ready for [MASK] .
the [MASK] was made .
some of the small [MASK] were replaced .
the stocks were made from pitch pine and the [MASK] from douglas fir .
work at the mill over the winter included repairs to the brickwork and windows , with only one window still needing attention when the first work - in began .
new beech [MASK] were fitted to the crown wheel , which was restored to its correct position on the upright shaft .
the stocks and sails were made during the two work - ins held in july and august , a total of 41 people attending over the two weeks .
a second - hand stock had been bought in the 1920s and preserved at the mill , but upon examination it was found to be unfit for use .
thus two new stocks were required instead of one .
modern steel stocks had already been discounted on cost and [MASK] grounds , leaving two options .
traditional stocks made from a single piece of timber , or [MASK] stocks .
good quality pitch pine was not [MASK] in the lengths required .
douglas fir was [MASK] in such lengths but was discounted on strength and [MASK] grounds .
a douglas fir stock on a nearby mill had [MASK] after only seven years .
thus it was decided that [MASK] stocks would be made .
the 52 feet ( 15 .
 85 m ) long stocks were made from douglas fir .
all timber had been pressure treated with [MASK] and well [MASK] .
it was estimated that a [MASK] stock would be up to 20 % stronger than a similar stock of solid timber .
the timber used was 1 1 ⁄ 2 inches ( 38 mm ) thick and nine [MASK] were required at the centre , where the stock passes through the poll end of the [MASK] .
[MASK] attention was paid to where individual joints occurred between different pieces of timber .
both stocks were made during the work - in , with one of them being trimmed and finished ready for use .
the stocks were the first [MASK] stocks made by amateurs .
the four sails were made .
the originals being slightly different pairs .
those on the inner stock having bays of 3 feet ( 910 mm ) pitch and those on the outer stock having bays of 3 feet 2 inches ( 970 mm ) pitch .
it was decided that the new sails would be identical , at the larger pitch .
four 27 feet ( 8 .
 23 m ) long [MASK] were cut from a [MASK] of pitch pine obtained from a demolished [MASK] at bury st [MASK] .
the [MASK] are 6 inches ( 150 mm ) square at their inner end .
[MASK] bars and [MASK] were made from modern pitch pine , selected for quality .
the [MASK] for the sail bars were cut .
that at the heel of the sail being at 27 ° and that at the tip being 15 ° , decreasing by 1 ½ ° at each sail bar .
three of the four sails had been completed at the end of the work in .
the [MASK] and associated [MASK] was fitted to the mill .
at the end of the second work - in , the cap could be turned by means of the hand [MASK] .
the [MASK] itself , with the [MASK] painted red , white and blue was installed shortly afterwards .
the [MASK] arm brake wheel was assembled around the [MASK] .
it was found that the [MASK] was eccentric on the upright shaft by ½ inch ( 13 mm ) .
when this was corrected the brake wheel was within 1 / 16 [MASK] of an inch ( less than 1 mm ) of true .
the [MASK] for the stocks were [MASK] from a [MASK] of pitch pine ready for completion later in the year .
other work included a new frame for one of the ground floor doors , cleaning and painting [MASK] and further [MASK] on the brickwork .
the four sails were fitted to the mill with the aid of a mobile crane at the end of the second work - in .
the stock , with one sail attached was carefully inserted through the poll end of the [MASK] and when [MASK] in position and the [MASK] had been attached the second sail was fitted to the stock .
the process was repeated for the second pair of sails .
the mill turned by wind again on the last day of the second work - in .
work later in the year included the finishing of the fourth sail , balancing the [MASK] and sorting out [MASK] troubles with the [MASK] [MASK] .
the brake and brake lever were made and installed and [MASK] [MASK] for the sails were cast .
restoration work in 1984 cost £ 2 , 918 .
grants received were £ 1 , [MASK] from english heritage , £ 500 from st [MASK] borough council , other donations amounted to £ 52 .
[MASK] from open days at the mill came to £ 151 .
a boost to the funds was £ 2 , 000 from [MASK] [MASK] .
this money had been allocated to allow the moving of a [MASK] post mill buck to [MASK] .
in the end , the removal was not proceeded with , and mr [MASK] allowed the donation to remain with the [MASK] mill preservation trust .
the project received further support in local media , including the east anglian daily times , one of the work - ins being featured on [MASK] television 's about [MASK] programme .
= = = 1985 - 87 = = =
work planned for 1985 included the replacement of the dust floor window and completion of the stocks and sails .
the external walls of the mill were [MASK] and internal walls plastered .
two work - ins were held , from 20 july to 28 july and 17 august to 26 august .
further work over the next two years saw the restoration completed in 1987 .
= = restoration team = =
the restoration of [MASK] [MASK] was made possible by the efforts of 135 individuals and 61 organisations .
this was achieved by the donation of labour , plant , materials or grants of money , or by giving [MASK] for materials purchased or providing publicity for the project .
= = description = =
terms explained in the mill machinery article are in italics
as built in 1819
a four - storey tower mill with common sails carried on a wooden [MASK] , driving two pairs of [MASK] [MASK] .
[MASK] wheel 6 feet ( 1 .
 83 m ) diameter .
[MASK] was by hand .
as restored
the four - storey tower is built of brick , and stands 31 feet 5 inches ( 9 .
 58 m ) from ground level to the curb .
the walls are 2 feet ( 610 mm ) thick at ground level .
the mill is described from the top down .
the [MASK] cap sits on top of the tower , giving the mill an overall height of 45 feet ( 13 .
 72 m ) to the [MASK] .
it houses the cast - iron [MASK] and 7 feet 2 inches ( 2 .
 18 m ) diameter wooden brake wheel internally .
[MASK] the four double patent sails span 64 feet ( 19 .
 51 m ) .
they are 9 feet ( 2 .
 74 m ) wide and can develop 30 horsepower ( 22 kw ) .
the eight [MASK] [MASK] keeps the mill turned into wind .
the top floor of the mill is the dust floor .
it could be used for storage of grain and gives internal access to the cap .
the cast - iron [MASK] , which is driven by the brake wheel is carried at the top of the upright shaft , in the centre of the mill .
the bin floor is where the grain is stored before being ground into flour .
the [MASK] hoist mechanism is housed on this floor , driven from the wooden crown wheel on the floor below by belt .
the stone floor is where the two pairs of [MASK] french burr [MASK] are located .
the stones are 4 feet 4 inches ( 1 .
 32 m ) and 4 feet 7 inches ( 1 .
 40 m ) diameter .
the wooden crown wheel is located towards the ceiling .
this drives the [MASK] hoist on the bin floor .
other machinery on this floor are an [MASK] [MASK] and a flour [MASK] .
the ground floor of the mill is the meal floor .
it is where the [MASK] ground flour is delivered for [MASK] up .
the wooden great spur wheel , located at the bottom of the extended upright shaft and stone nuts are located on this floor .
the great spur wheel has been converted from [MASK] arm construction to [MASK] arm construction .
a third pair of 4 feet 6 inches ( 1 .
 37 m ) diameter french burr [MASK] is located on a [MASK] frame , driven by the auxiliary engine via a fast and loose [MASK] .

= [MASK] mouth =
" [MASK] mouth " is the first segment of the 18th episode of the second season , or the 38th overall episode of the american animated television series [MASK] [MASK] .
the episode was directed by andrew [MASK] , and was written by walt [MASK] , paul [MASK] , and [MASK] williams .
[MASK] and [MASK] also served as storyboard directors , and carson [MASK] , william [MASK] , and erik [MASK] worked as storyboard artists .
it originally aired on [MASK] in the united states on september 21 , 2001 .
the series follows the adventures and [MASK] of the title character and his various friends in the underwater city of [MASK] [MASK] .
the series follows the adventures and [MASK] of the title character and her various friends in the underwater city of [MASK] [MASK] .

patrick explains to her that it is a " sentence [MASK] " which is used " when you want to talk fancy . "
the two start using it in every sentence they speak .
however , when mr. [MASK] hears them , he warns the two never to use the word again or any of the 13 bad words .
however , when mr. [MASK] hears them , she warns the two never to use the word again or any of the 13 bad words .
later on , [MASK] accidentally swears again .
patrick then runs to tell mr. [MASK] with [MASK] trying to stop him .
patrick then runs to tell mr. [MASK] with [MASK] trying to stop her .
however , when mr. [MASK] accidentally [MASK] his toe , he [MASK] all the 13 bad words .
however , when mr. [MASK] accidentally [MASK] his toe , she [MASK] all the 13 bad words .

the two cannot believe it and run to mama [MASK] to tell on him .
the two cannot believe it and run to mama [MASK] to tell on her .

mama [MASK] , who is [MASK] by their use of the words , makes the three paint his house as punishment .
the episode received positive reviews , while various members of the [MASK] [MASK] crew consider the episode to be one of their favorites , mainly due to the satirical nature of the episode .
however , the episode was not immune to negative reception , and was criticized by [MASK] media group the parents television council and fans , who interpreted the episode as an example of promoting and implicitly [MASK] use of [MASK] towards children .

= = production = =
" [MASK] mouth " was directed by andrew [MASK] , and was written by walt [MASK] , paul [MASK] , and [MASK] williams .
[MASK] and [MASK] also served as storyboard directors , and carson [MASK] , william [MASK] and erik [MASK] worked as storyboard artists .
series creator stephen [MASK] has described the episode plot as " a classic thing all kids go through . "
much of the storyline for the episode was inspired by the writers ' own experiences from childhood .
the episode originally aired on [MASK] in the united states on september 21 , 2001 .
the episode marks the introduction of mr. [MASK] ' mother , mama [MASK] , who was voiced by former [MASK] [MASK] creative producer and current executive producer paul [MASK] .
the writing staff used their individual childhood experiences as inspirations to come up with much of the story lines for this episode .
the idea for " [MASK] mouth " was inspired by creative director derek [MASK] 's experience " [ when ] i got in trouble for saying the f - word in front of my mother . "
[MASK] said , " the scene where patrick is running to mr. [MASK] to [MASK] , with [MASK] chasing him , is pretty much how it happened in real life . "
[MASK] said , " the scene where patrick is running to mr. [MASK] to [MASK] , with [MASK] chasing her , is pretty much how it happened in real life . "
the end of the episode , where mr. [MASK] uses more [MASK] than [MASK] and patrick , was also inspired " by the fact that my [ [MASK] 's ] mother has a sailor mouth herself . "
the end of the episode , where mr. [MASK] uses more [MASK] than [MASK] and patrick , was also inspired " by the fact that my [ [MASK] 's ] mother has a sailor mouth himself . "
the scene where [MASK] and patrick playing a game of [MASK] and [MASK] , which is a parody of [MASK] and [MASK] , was difficult for the crew to [MASK] , since many shots featured certain board pieces changing location .
according to the series ' season 2 dvd commentary , it was planned to have a scene that had [MASK] saying " go ' [MASK] noise ' yourself " followed by patrick saying " ' [MASK] noise ' you too ! "
during the [MASK] and [MASK] game .
it was removed in the final episode check because it would have been inappropriate for the younger audience .
" [MASK] mouth " was released on the dvd compilation called [MASK] [MASK] : sea stories on march 12 , 2002 .
it was also included in the [MASK] [MASK] : the complete 2nd season dvd released on october 19 , 2004 .
on september 22 , 2009 , " [MASK] mouth " was released on the [MASK] [MASK] : the first 100 episodes , alongside all the episodes of seasons one through five .

= = = criticism and controversy = = =
according to a report titled wolves in [MASK] 's [MASK] , which documents the increase in potentially violent , [MASK] , and sexual content in children 's programming , the parents television council , a [MASK] media group , and fans believed the [MASK] [MASK] episode " [MASK] mouth " was an implicit attempt to promote and [MASK] use of [MASK] among children .
the episode originally aired during the 2001 – 02 television season , ironically the season in which the ptc named [MASK] [MASK] among the best programs on cable television , but the report cited a repeat broadcast of the episode from 2005 to prove its point that it promoted use of [MASK] among children .
in a later report , several members of the ptc listed " [MASK] mouth " as an example of how levels of [MASK] , sexual , and violent activity has increased in children 's television programming .
[MASK] , in response to the incident , said " it 's sad and a little desperate that they [MASK] to literally putting [MASK] language in the mouths of our characters to make a point .
has the fcc looked at this ? "
richard [MASK] of the new york daily news criticized the report for [MASK] an episode of [MASK] [MASK] , " [MASK] mouth " , over its intent to [MASK] [MASK] implicitly .
= military history of australia =
the military history of australia spans the nation 's 220 - year modern history , from the early australian frontier wars between [MASK] and europeans to the ongoing conflicts in iraq and afghanistan in the early 21st century .
although this history is short when compared to that of many other nations , australia has been involved in numerous conflicts and wars , and war and military service have been significant influences on australian society and national identity , including the anzac spirit .
the relationship between war and australian society has also been shaped by the enduring themes of australian strategic culture and its unique security dilemma .
as british [MASK] , the australian colonies participated in britain 's small wars of the 19th century , while later as a [MASK] dominion , and then an independent nation , australia fought in the first world war and second world war , as well as in the wars in korea , malaya , borneo and vietnam during the cold war .
in the post - vietnam era australian forces have been involved in numerous international peacekeeping missions , through the united nations and other agencies , including in the sinai , persian gulf , [MASK] , somalia , east timor and the solomon islands , while more recently they have also fought as part of multi - lateral forces in iraq and afghanistan .
in total , nearly 103 , 000 australians died during the course of these conflicts .
= = war and australian society = =
for most of the last century military service has been one of the single greatest shared experiences of white australian males , and although this is now changing due to the professionalisation of the military and the absence of major wars during the second half of the 20th century , it continues to influence australian society to this day .
war and military service have been defining influences in australian history , while a major part of the national identity has been built on an [MASK] conception of the australian experience of war and of [MASK] , known as the anzac spirit .
these ideals include notions of endurance , courage , ingenuity , humour , [MASK] , [MASK] and [MASK] ; traits which , according to popular thought , defined the behaviour of australian soldiers fighting at gallipoli during the first world war .
the gallipoli campaign was one of the first international events that saw australians taking part as australians and has been seen as a key event in forging a sense of national identity .
the relationship between war and australian society has been shaped by two of the more enduring themes of australian strategic culture : [MASK] with a powerful ally and expeditionary warfare .
indeed , australian defence policy was closely linked to britain until the japanese crisis of 1942 , while since then an alliance with the united states has [MASK] its security .
[MASK] , this pattern of [MASK] — both for cultural reasons such as shared values and beliefs , as well as for more [MASK] security concerns — has ensured that australian strategic policy has often been defined by relations with its allies .
regardless , a tendency towards strategic [MASK] has also been evident , with australians often reluctant to think about defence issues or to [MASK] resources until a crisis arises ; a trait which has historically resulted in [MASK] for major military challenges .
reflecting both the realist and liberal [MASK] of international relations and the conception of national interests , a number of other important themes in australian strategic culture are also obvious .
such themes include : an acceptance of the state as the key actor in international politics , the [MASK] of notions of [MASK] sovereignty , a belief in the enduring relevance and legitimacy of armed force as a [MASK] of security , and the proposition that the status [MASK] in international affairs should only be changed peacefully .
likewise , [MASK] , collective security and defence self - reliance have also been important themes .
change has been more evolutionary than revolutionary and these strategic [MASK] have persisted throughout its history , being the product of australian society 's democratic political tradition and [MASK] - christian anglo - european heritage , as well its associated values , beliefs and economic , political and religious ideology .
these [MASK] are also reflective of its unique security dilemma as a largely european island on the edge of the asia - pacific , and the [MASK] circumstances of a middle power physically removed from the centres of world power .
to be sure , during threats to the core australia has often found itself defending the periphery and perhaps as a result , it has frequently become involved in foreign wars .
throughout these conflicts australian soldiers — known colloquially as [MASK] — have often been noted , somewhat [MASK] , for both their fighting abilities and their humanitarian qualities .
= = colonial era = =
= = = british forces in australia , 1788 – 1870 = = =
from 1788 until 1870 the defence of the australian colonies was mostly provided by british army regular forces .
originally marines protected the early settlements at sydney cove and norfolk island , however they were relieved of these duties in 1790 by a british army unit specifically recruited for colonial service , known as the new south wales corps .
the new south wales corps subsequently was involved in putting down a rebellion of irish convicts at castle hill in 1804 .
soon however shortcomings in the corps convinced the war office of the need for a more reliable garrison in new south wales and van [MASK] 's land .
chief of these shortcomings was the rum rebellion , a coup mounted by its officers in 1808 .
as a result , in january 1810 the 73rd ( [MASK] ) regiment of foot arrived in australia .
by 1870 , 25 british infantry regiments had served in australia , as had a small number of artillery and engineer units .
although the primary role of the british army was to protect the colonies against external attack , no actual threat ever [MASK] .
the british army was instead used in policing , guarding convicts at penal institutions , combating [MASK] , putting down convict rebellions — as occurred at bathurst in 1830 — and to suppress aboriginal resistance to the extension of european settlement .
notably british soldiers were involved in the battle at the [MASK] [MASK] in 1854 on the victorian [MASK] .
members of british regiments stationed in australia also saw action in india , afghanistan , new zealand and the sudan .
during the early years of settlement the naval defence of australia was provided by detached royal navy units of the east indies station , based in sydney .
however , in 1859 australia was established as a separate squadron under the command of a [MASK] , marking the first occasion that royal navy ships had been permanently stationed in australia .
the royal navy remained the primary naval force in australian waters until 1913 , when the australia station ceased and responsibility handed over to the royal australian navy ; the royal navy 's depots , dockyards and structures were given to the australian people .
= = = frontier warfare , 1788 – 1934 = = =
the reactions of the native aboriginal inhabitants to the sudden arrival of british settlers in australia were varied , but were inevitably hostile when the settler 's presence led to competition over resources , and to the occupation of the indigenous inhabitants ' lands .
european diseases decimated aboriginal populations , and the occupation or destruction of lands and food resources sometimes led to starvation .
by and large neither the british nor the [MASK] approached the conflict in an organised sense and conflict occurred between groups of settlers and individual tribes rather than systematic warfare .
at times , however , the frontier wars did see the involvement of british soldiers and later mounted police units .
not all aboriginal groups resisted white encroachment on their lands , while many [MASK] served in mounted police units and were involved in attacks on other tribes .
fighting between [MASK] and europeans was localised as the [MASK] did not form [MASK] capable of sustained resistance .
as a result , there was not a single war , but rather a series of violent engagements and massacres across the continent .
[MASK] or disorganised however , a pattern of frontier warfare emerged with aboriginal resistance beginning in the 18th century and continuing into the early 20th century .
this warfare [MASK] the popular and at times academic " myth " of peaceful settlement in australia .
faced with aboriginal resistance settlers often reacted with violence , resulting in a number of indiscriminate massacres .
among the most famous is the battle of [MASK] in western australia in 1834 .
such incidents were not officially sanctioned however , and after the [MASK] creek massacre in new south wales in 1838 seven europeans were hanged for their part in the killings .
however , in tasmania the so - called black war was fought between 1828 and 1832 , and aimed at driving most of the island 's native inhabitants onto a number of isolated peninsulas .
although it began in failure for the british , it ultimately resulted in considerable casualties amongst the native population .
it may be inaccurate though to depict the conflict as one sided and mainly [MASK] by europeans on [MASK] .
although many more [MASK] died than british , this may have had more to do with the technological and logistic advantages enjoyed by the europeans .
aboriginal tactics varied , but were mainly based on pre - existing hunting and fighting practices — using [MASK] , clubs and other primitive weapons .
unlike the indigenous peoples of new zealand and north america , on the main [MASK] failed to adapt to meet the challenge of the europeans .
although there were some instances of individuals and groups acquiring and using firearms , this was not widespread .
the [MASK] were never a serious military threat to european settlers , regardless of how much the settlers may have feared them .
on occasions large groups of [MASK] attacked the settlers in open terrain and a conventional battle ensued , during which the [MASK] would attempt to use superior numbers to their advantage .
this could sometimes be effective , with reports of them advancing in crescent formation in an attempt to outflank and surround their opponents , waiting out the first volley of shots and then hurling their [MASK] while the settlers [MASK] .
however , such open warfare usually proved more costly for the [MASK] than the europeans .
central to the success of the europeans was the use of firearms .
however , the advantages afforded by firearms have often been [MASK] .
