following the war , the navy regularly deployed a frigate to the persian gulf or red sea to enforce the trade sanctions which continued to be applied to iraq .
a number of australian airmen and ground crew posted to or on exchange with us and british air forces subsequently participated in enforcing no - fly zones imposed over iraq between 1991 and 2003 .
= = = global security , late - 1990s = = =
since the late 1980s , the australian government had increasingly called upon the [MASK] to contribute forces to peacekeeping missions around the world .
while most of these deployments involved only small numbers of specialists , several led to the deployment of hundreds of personnel .
large peacekeeping deployments were made to [MASK] in early 1989 , cambodia between 1992 and 1993 , somalia in 1993 , [MASK] between 1994 and 1995 and [MASK] in 1994 and from 1997 onwards .
the 1996 election of the howard liberal government resulted in significant reforms to the [MASK] 's force structure and role , with the new government 's defence strategy placed less singular emphasis on defending australia from direct attack and greater emphasis on working in co - operation with regional states and australia 's allies to manage potential security threats in recognition of australia 's global security interests .
in line with this new focus , the [MASK] 's force structure changed in an attempt to increase the proportion of combat units to support units and to improve the [MASK] 's combat effectiveness .
= = new millennium = =
= = = east timor , 1999 – 2013 = = =
the former - portuguese colony of east timor was invaded by indonesia in 1975 , however , following years of violent struggle the new indonesian government of president [MASK] [MASK] subsequently agreed to allow the east [MASK] to vote on autonomy in 1999 .
the united nations mission in east timor ( [MASK] ) was established to organise and conduct the vote , which was held at the end of august 1999 and resulted with 78 .
 5 % of voters deciding in favour of independence .
however , following the announcement of the results pro - indonesian militias supported by elements of the indonesian military , launched a campaign of violence , looting and [MASK] and many east [MASK] were killed , while perhaps more than 500 , 000 were displaced .
unable to control the violence , indonesia subsequently agreed to the deployment of a multinational peacekeeping force .
australia , which had contributed police to [MASK] , organised and led an international military coalition , known as the international force for east timor ( [MASK] ) , a non - un force operating in accordance with un resolutions .
the total size of the australian force committed numbered 5 , 500 personnel , and included a significant ground force , supported by air and naval forces , in the largest single deployment of australian forces since 1945 .
under the overall command of australian major general peter [MASK] , [MASK] began arriving on 12 september 1999 and was tasked with restoring peace and security , protecting and supporting [MASK] , and facilitating humanitarian assistance operations .
with the withdrawal of the indonesian armed forces , police and government officials from east timor , [MASK] re - established its headquarters in dili on 28 september .
on 19 october 1999 , indonesia formally recognised the result of the referendum and shortly thereafter a un peacekeeping force , the united nations transitional administration in east timor ( [MASK] ) was established , becoming fully responsible for the administration of east timor during its transition to independence .
the hand - over of command of military operations from [MASK] to [MASK] was completed on 28 february 2000 .
australia continued to support the un peacekeeping operation with between 1 , 500 and 2 , 000 personnel , as well as landing craft and [MASK] helicopters and remained the largest contributor of personnel to the peacekeeping mission .
during these operations australian forces regularly clashed with pro - indonesian militia and on a number of occasions indonesian forces as well , especially along the border with west timor .
significant actions occurred in [MASK] , [MASK] [MASK] and at [MASK] in october 1999 .
however , with the security situation [MASK] the bulk of the australian and un forces were withdrawn by 2005 .
two australians died from non - battle related causes , while a number were wounded in action .
the unexpected deployment to east timor in 1999 led to significant changes in australian defence policy and to an enhancement of the [MASK] 's ability to conduct operations outside australia .
this successful deployment was the first time a large australian military force had operated outside of australia since the vietnam war and revealed shortcomings in the [MASK] 's ability to mount and sustain such operations .
in response , the 2000 defence white paper placed a greater emphasis on preparing the [MASK] for overseas deployments .
the australian government committed to improve the [MASK] 's capabilities by improving the readiness and equipment of [MASK] units , expanding the [MASK] to 57 , 000 full - time personnel and increasing real defence expenditure by 3 % per year .
in may 2006 , 2 , 000 [MASK] personnel were again deployed to east timor as part of operation [MASK] , following unrest between elements of the timor [MASK] defence force .
australian forces were involved in a number [MASK] during this time , including a heavy clash with rebels commanded by [MASK] [MASK] at same on 4 march 2007 .
however , by early - 2010 the security situation had been [MASK] and just 400 australian personnel remained to train the local security forces as part of a small international force .
following a [MASK] , the international [MASK] force commenced withdrawing from timor - [MASK] in november 2012 , a process which was completed in april 2013 .
= = = afghanistan , 2001 – present = = =
shortly after the islamist inspired terrorist attacks in new york and washington on 11 september 2001 , australian forces were committed to the american - led international coalition against terrorism .
the [MASK] 's most visible contribution — codenamed operation [MASK] — has been a special forces task group operating in afghanistan from 2001 to 2002 and again from mid - 2005 to fight against the [MASK] .
over time the australian commitment has grown , with the addition of further ground forces in the form of a reconstruction task force from 2006 to provide security , reconstruction and to mentor and train the [MASK] national army .
australia has also contributed a frigate and two ap - [MASK] orion surveillance aircraft and three c - 130 [MASK] transport aircraft to international operations in the persian gulf and indian ocean since 2001 , supporting both the operations in afghanistan and those in iraq under operation [MASK] .
a detachment of four f / a - 18 [MASK] fighter - bombers was based at diego garcia from late - 2001 to mid - 2002 , while two boeing [MASK] air - to - air [MASK] aircraft were also based in manas air base in [MASK] to provide support to coalition aircraft operating in [MASK] airspace but were later withdrawn .
a special operations task group was deployed to support the reconstruction [MASK] in april 2007 .
in addition to radar crews , logistics and intelligence officers , and security personnel , this brought the number of australian personnel in afghanistan to 950 by mid - 2007 , with further small increases to 1 , 000 in mid - 2008 , 1 , 100 in early 2009 and 1 , 550 in mid - 2009 .
a modest force remained in afghanistan over this time and was involved in counter - insurgency operations in [MASK] province in conjunction united states and other coalition forces , including the dutch prior to their withdrawal .
the force consisted of motorised infantry , special forces , engineers , cavalry , artillery and aviation elements .
by 2010 it included a combined arms battalion - sized battle group known as the [MASK] task force , and the special operations task group , both based at forward operation base ripley outside of [MASK] [MASK] , as well as the [MASK] wing group flying ch - [MASK] [MASK] , the force [MASK] [MASK] and an raaf air surveillance radar unit based in [MASK] .
in addition , a further 800 australian logistic personnel were also based in the middle east in support , but are located outside of afghanistan .
meanwhile , [MASK] of maritime patrol and transport aircraft continued to support operations in iraq and afghanistan , based out of al [MASK] air base in the united arab emirates .
also included is the deployment of one of the [MASK] 's frigates to the arabian sea and gulf of aden on counter piracy and maritime interdiction duties .
australian forces were at times involved in heavy fighting , and significant actions included operation [MASK] in 2002 and operation perth in 2006 , as well as actions in [MASK] in 2007 , [MASK] in 2009 , the shah [MASK] [MASK] and [MASK] in 2010 , and [MASK] in 2011 ; although others have yet to be publicly acknowledged due to operational security requirements .
casualties include 41 killed and 256 wounded , while another australian also died serving with the british army .
four australians have been awarded the victoria cross for australia , the first such decorations in forty years .
following a [MASK] in forces , the last combat troops were withdrawn on 15 december 2013 ; however , approximately 400 personnel remain in afghanistan as trainers and advisers , and are stationed in [MASK] and [MASK] .
over 26 , 000 australian personnel have served in afghanistan .
= = = iraq , 2003 – 11 = = =
australian forces later joined british and american forces during the 2003 invasion of iraq .
the initial contribution was also a modest one , consisting of just 2 , [MASK] personnel — codenamed operation [MASK] .
major force elements included special forces , [MASK] and fixed wing aviation and naval units .
army units included elements from the [MASK] and 4th battalion , royal australian regiment ( commando ) , a ch - 47 [MASK] detachment and a number of other specialist units .
[MASK] units included the amphibious ship [MASK] [MASK] and the frigates [MASK] darwin and [MASK] anzac , while the raaf deployed 14 f / a - 18 hornets from no.
75 squadron , a number of ap - [MASK] [MASK] and c - 130 [MASK] .
the australian special forces task force was one of the first coalition units forces to cross the border into iraq , while for a few days , the closest ground troops to baghdad were from the [MASK] .
during the invasion the raaf also flew its first combat missions since the vietnam war , with no.
75 squadron flying a total of 350 sorties and dropping 122 laser - guided bombs .
the iraqi military quickly proved no match for coalition military power , and with their defeat the bulk of australian forces were withdrawn .
while australia did not initially take part in the post - war occupation of iraq , an australian army light armoured [MASK] — designated the al [MASK] task group and including 40 [MASK] light armoured vehicles and infantry — was later deployed to southern iraq in april 2005 as part of operation [MASK] .
the role of this force was to protect the japanese engineer contingent in the region and support the training of new iraqi army units .
the [MASK] later became the [MASK] battle group ( west ) ( [MASK] ( w ) ) , following the hand back of al [MASK] province to iraqi control .
force levels peaked at 1 , 400 personnel in may 2007 including the [MASK] ( w ) in southern iraq , the security detachment in baghdad and the australian army training team — iraq .
a [MASK] frigate was based in the north persian gulf , while raaf assets included c - [MASK] [MASK] and ap - [MASK] elements .
following the election of a new labor government under prime minister kevin [MASK] the bulk of these forces were withdrawn by mid - 2009 , while raaf and [MASK] operations were [MASK] to other parts of the middle east area of operations as part of operation [MASK] .
low - level operations continued , however , with a small australian force of 80 soldiers remaining in iraq to protect the australian embassy in baghdad as part of [MASK] under operation [MASK] .
[MASK] was finally withdrawn in august 2011 , and was replaced by a private military company which took over responsibility for providing security for australia 's diplomatic presence in iraq .
although more than 17 , 000 personnel served during operations in iraq , australian casualties were relatively light , with two soldiers accidentally killed , while a third australian died serving with the british royal air force .
a further 27 personnel were wounded .
two officers remained in iraq attached to the united nations assistance mission for iraq as part of operation [MASK] .
this operation concluded in november 2013 .
= = = military intervention against [MASK] , 2014 – present = = =
in june 2014 a small number of [MASK] personnel were deployed to iraq to protect the australian embassy when the security of baghdad was threatened by the 2014 northern iraq offensive .
later , in august and september a number of raaf c - 17 and c - [MASK] transport aircraft based in the middle east were used to conduct [MASK] of humanitarian aid to trapped civilians and to [MASK] arms and munitions to forces in kurdish - controlled northern iraq .
in late september 2014 an air task group ( [MASK] ) and special operations task group ( [MASK] ) were deployed to al [MASK] air base in the united arab emirates as part of the coalition to combat islamic state forces in iraq .
[MASK] with f / a - [MASK] super [MASK] strike aircraft , a [MASK] - [MASK] multi role [MASK] transport , and an e - [MASK] [MASK] airborne early warning & control aircraft , the [MASK] began operations on 1 october .
the [MASK] is tasked with operations to advise and assist iraqi security forces , and was deployed to iraq after a legal framework covering their presence in the country was agreed between the australian and iraqi governments .
it began moving into iraq in early november .
in april 2015 a 300 - strong unit known as task group [MASK] was deployed to iraq to train the regular iraqi security forces .
[MASK] were extended to syria in september 2015 .
= = [MASK] = =
australia 's involvement in international peacekeeping operations has been diverse , and included participation in both united nations sponsored missions , as well as those as part of ad - hoc coalitions .
australians have been involved in more conflicts as peacekeepers than as [MASK] ; however " in comparative international terms , australia has only been a moderately energetic [MASK] . "
although australia has had peacekeepers in the field continuously for 60 years — being among the first group of un military observers in indonesia in 1947 — its commitments have generally been limited , consisting mostly of small numbers of high - level and technical support troops such as [MASK] , engineers , [MASK] , observers , and police .
one significant commitment has been australia 's ongoing involvement with the long running [MASK] force and observers in the sinai .
the operational tempo started increasing in the mid - 1990s , when australia became involved in a series of high - profile operations , deploying significantly larger combat units in support of a number of missions including cambodia , [MASK] , somalia , east timor , and the solomon islands .
australia has been involved in close to 100 separate missions , involving more than 30 , 000 personnel ; 14 australians have died during these operations .

= ward churchill =
ward [MASK] churchill ( born 1947 ) is an american author and political activist .
he was a professor of ethnic studies at the university of colorado boulder from 1990 until 2007 .
she was a professor of ethnic studies at the university of colorado boulder from 1990 until 2007 .
the primary focus of his work is on the historical treatment of political dissenters and native americans by the united states government .
the primary focus of her work is on the historical treatment of political dissenters and native americans by the united states government .
his work features controversial and provocative views , written in a direct , often [MASK] style .
her work features controversial and provocative views , written in a direct , often [MASK] style .
in january 2005 , churchill 's work attracted controversy because of the circulation of a 2001 essay , " on the justice of [MASK] [MASK] " , in which he argued the september 11 attacks were a natural and [MASK] consequence of unlawful us foreign policy over the latter half of the 20th century ; the essay is well known for churchill 's use of the phrase " little [MASK] " to describe the " [MASK] corps " working in the world trade center .
in january 2005 , churchill 's work attracted controversy because of the circulation of a 2001 essay , " on the justice of [MASK] [MASK] " , in which she argued the september 11 attacks were a natural and [MASK] consequence of unlawful us foreign policy over the latter half of the 20th century ; the essay is well known for churchill 's use of the phrase " little [MASK] " to describe the " [MASK] corps " working in the world trade center .
in march 2005 the university of colorado began investigating allegations that churchill had engaged in research [MASK] ; it reported in june 2006 that he had done so .
in march 2005 the university of colorado began investigating allegations that churchill had engaged in research [MASK] ; it reported in june 2006 that she had done so .
churchill was fired on july 24 , 2007 , leading to a claim by some scholars that he was fired because of the " little [MASK] " comment .
churchill was fired on july 24 , 2007 , leading to a claim by some scholars that she was fired because of the " little [MASK] " comment .
churchill filed a lawsuit against the university of colorado for unlawful termination of employment .
in april 2009 a denver jury found that churchill was wrongly fired , [MASK] him $ 1 in damages .
in april 2009 a denver jury found that churchill was wrongly fired , [MASK] her $ 1 in damages .
in july 2009 , a district court judge vacated the monetary award and declined churchill 's request to order his [MASK] , deciding the university has " quasi - judicial immunity " .
in july 2009 , a district court judge vacated the monetary award and declined churchill 's request to order her [MASK] , deciding the university has " quasi - judicial immunity " .
in february 2010 , churchill appealed the judge 's decision .
in november 2010 , the colorado court of appeals upheld the lower - court 's ruling .
in september 10 , 2012 , the colorado supreme court upheld the lower courts ' decisions in favor of the university of colorado .
on april 1 , 2013 , the united states supreme court declined to hear the case .
in a february 2014 interview , churchill commented that after living more than forty years in the northern plains / colorado region , he had relocated to atlanta , georgia in 2013 .
in a february 2014 interview , churchill commented that after living more than forty years in the northern plains / colorado region , she had relocated to atlanta , georgia in 2013 .
churchill also stated that he had a half - dozen uncompleted books which he intended to finish and publish in the next three years .
churchill also stated that she had a half - dozen uncompleted books which he intended to finish and publish in the next three years .
= = early life and education = =
churchill was born in [MASK] , illinois , to jack [MASK] churchill and [MASK] [MASK] allen .
his parents divorced before he was two , and he grew up in [MASK] , where he attended local schools .
his parents divorced before she was two , and he grew up in [MASK] , where he attended local schools .
her parents divorced before he was two , and he grew up in [MASK] , where he attended local schools .
in 1966 , he was drafted into the united states army .
in 1966 , she was drafted into the united states army .
on his 1980 resume , he said he served as a public - information specialist who " wrote and edited the battalion [MASK] and wrote news releases . "
on his 1980 resume , she said he served as a public - information specialist who " wrote and edited the battalion [MASK] and wrote news releases . "
on her 1980 resume , he said he served as a public - information specialist who " wrote and edited the battalion [MASK] and wrote news releases . "
in a 1987 profile on churchill , the denver post reported that he was drafted , went to paratrooper school , then volunteered for vietnam , where he served a 10 - month tour as long range reconnaissance patrol ( [MASK] ) , one of a six - man team sent out to track down the enemy .
in a 1987 profile on churchill , the denver post reported that she was drafted , went to paratrooper school , then volunteered for vietnam , where he served a 10 - month tour as long range reconnaissance patrol ( [MASK] ) , one of a six - man team sent out to track down the enemy .
the post article also reported that churchill was politically [MASK] as a result of his experiences in vietnam .
the post article also reported that churchill was politically [MASK] as a result of her experiences in vietnam .
churchill told the post that he had spent some time at the chicago office of the students for a democratic society ( [MASK] ) in the late 1960s , and briefly taught members of the weather underground how to build bombs and fire weapons .
churchill told the post that she had spent some time at the chicago office of the students for a democratic society ( [MASK] ) in the late 1960s , and briefly taught members of the weather underground how to build bombs and fire weapons .
in 2005 , the denver post reported that churchill 's military records show he was trained as a film [MASK] and light truck driver , but they do not reflect paratrooper school or [MASK] training .
in 2005 , the denver post reported that churchill 's military records show she was trained as a film [MASK] and light truck driver , but they do not reflect paratrooper school or [MASK] training .
the 75th ranger regiment association found no record of churchill having been a member of the unit , or a [MASK] team .
churchill received his [MASK] in technological communications in 1974 and [MASK] in communications theory in 1975 , both from [MASK] state university , now the university of illinois at springfield .
churchill received her [MASK] in technological communications in 1974 and [MASK] in communications theory in 1975 , both from [MASK] state university , now the university of illinois at springfield .
= = career = =
in 1978 , churchill began working at the university of colorado boulder as an [MASK] action officer in the university administration .
he also [MASK] on american indian issues in the ethnic studies program .
she also [MASK] on american indian issues in the ethnic studies program .
in 1990 , the university of colorado hired him as an associate professor , although he did not possess the academic doctorate usually required for the position .
in 1990 , the university of colorado hired him as an associate professor , although she did not possess the academic doctorate usually required for the position .
in 1990 , the university of colorado hired her as an associate professor , although he did not possess the academic doctorate usually required for the position .
the following year he was granted tenure in the communications department , without the usual six - year [MASK] period , after having been declined by the sociology and political science departments .
the following year she was granted tenure in the communications department , without the usual six - year [MASK] period , after having been declined by the sociology and political science departments .
he has long been interested in issues associated with the [MASK] act , which broke up the communal reservation lands and assigned plots to individual households .
she has long been interested in issues associated with the [MASK] act , which broke up the communal reservation lands and assigned plots to individual households .
[MASK] with that was the federal government 's first use of " blood quantum " to define individual membership in tribes , for what became known as the [MASK] rolls .
since re - establishing self - governments , [MASK] recognized tribes have established their own criteria for enrollment as members , often related to descent from recognized historical lists , but less often requiring proofs of blood quantum .
some of his published works address these issues , which he has interpreted as part of the federal government 's policy of [MASK] against native americans .
some of his published works address these issues , which she has interpreted as part of the federal government 's policy of [MASK] against native americans .
some of her published works address these issues , which he has interpreted as part of the federal government 's policy of [MASK] against native americans .
in 1995 churchill discussed his views with david [MASK] in an interview :
in 1995 churchill discussed her views with david [MASK] in an interview :
you could say that five hundred years ago was the basis of blood quantum in [MASK] - america .
but in anglo - america , while there was some preoccupation with it , it was not formalized until the passage of the general [MASK] act , mid - 1880s .
at that point they began to define indian as being someone who was [MASK] and [MASK] of at least one - quarter by quantum blood indigenous in a given group .
you couldn 't be an eighth cheyenne and an eighth [MASK] and be an indian .
you had to be a quarter cheyenne or a quarter [MASK] or hopefully a quarter and a quarter .
the reason for this was quite clear .
they were identifying indians for purposes of [MASK] them individual [MASK] of land in the existing reservation base at that point .
if they ran out of indians identifiable as such , then the rest of the land would be declared surplus .
so it was clearly in the interests of the government to create a definition of [MASK] that would minimize the number of indians that were available .
it was an economic motivation for the application of this genetic criteria to [MASK] in the first place .
it 's become increasingly so ever since . "
( david [MASK] ( december 1995 ) . "
interview with ward churchill : historical and current [MASK] " .
z magazine . )
in 1996 , churchill moved to the new [MASK] studies department of the university of colorado .
in 1997 , he was promoted to full professor .
in 1997 , she was promoted to full professor .
he was selected as chairman of the department in june 2002 .
she was selected as chairman of the department in june 2002 .
in january 2005 , during the controversy over his 9 / 11 remarks , churchill resigned as chairman of the ethnic studies department at the university of colorado — his term as chair was scheduled to [MASK] in june of that year .
in january 2005 , during the controversy over her 9 / 11 remarks , churchill resigned as chairman of the ethnic studies department at the university of colorado — his term as chair was scheduled to [MASK] in june of that year .
on may 16 , 2006 , the [MASK] committee of the standing committee on research [MASK] at the university of colorado concluded that churchill had committed multiple counts of academic [MASK] , specifically plagiarism , fabrication , and [MASK] .
on july 24 , 2007 , churchill was fired for academic [MASK] in an eight to one vote by the university of colorado 's board of [MASK] .

in 1992 , churchill wrote elsewhere that she is one - eighth creek and one - sixteenth [MASK] .

in 1993 , churchill told the colorado daily that " she was one - sixteenth creek and [MASK] . "

"

the website statement further clarified that churchill " was not eligible for tribal membership due to the fact that he does not possess a ' certificate of [MASK] of indian blood ( [MASK] ) " , and the associate membership did not [MASK] an individual to voting rights or enrollment in the tribe .
the website statement further clarified that churchill " was not eligible for tribal membership due to the fact that she does not possess a ' certificate of [MASK] of indian blood ( [MASK] ) " , and the associate membership did not [MASK] an individual to voting rights or enrollment in the tribe .
churchill has never asked for [MASK] certification , and finds the idea of being " [MASK] " by the us government offensive .
in june 1994 , the united [MASK] band had voted to stop [MASK] associate [MASK] .
such honorary associate membership recognizes an individual 's assistance to the tribe , but it has nothing to do with indian ancestry , and it does not [MASK] an individual to vote in the tribe as a member .
the [MASK] band states that churchill still holds the associate membership and it has not been rescinded .
in a separate interview , [MASK] berry , formerly on the tribe 's enrollment committee and four years on its council , said that churchill had never fulfilled a promise to help the tribe .

i have never claimed to be [MASK] [MASK] bull . "

churchill has responded to requests for [MASK] of her claimed indian heritage in various ways , including attacking the blood quantum upon which some native american tribes establish their membership requirements .
churchill argues that the united states instituted blood quantum laws based upon rules of [MASK] in order to further goals of personal [MASK] and political [MASK] .
for decades in his writings , churchill has argued that blood quantum laws have an inherent [MASK] purpose .

= = writing = =
churchill has written on american indian history and culture , and speaks about [MASK] inflicted on the indigenous people of the americas by european settlers and what he describes as the repression of native peoples that continues to this day .
churchill has written on american indian history and culture , and speaks about [MASK] inflicted on the indigenous people of the americas by european settlers and what she describes as the repression of native peoples that continues to this day .

according to the university of colorado investigation , " his academic publications are nearly all works of synthesis and [MASK] , drawing upon studies by other scholars , not [MASK] describing new research based on primary sources . "

in addition to his academic writing , churchill has written for several general readership magazines of political opinion .
in addition to her academic writing , churchill has written for several general readership magazines of political opinion .
in 1986 , churchill wrote an essay titled [MASK] as [MASK] : notes on an american [MASK] criticizing pacifist politics within the u.s. left as being [MASK] , de facto racist and [MASK] .
in 1998 , [MASK] ring publishing published the essay in a book entitled [MASK] as [MASK] : reflections on the role of armed [MASK] in north america and listing ward churchill as the author .
the book included a preface by ed mead , a new introduction to the essay by churchill and a commentary by mike ryan .
the book sparked much debate in leftist circles and inspired more aggressive tactics within the anti - [MASK] movement in the following few years .
agents of [MASK] ( 1988 ) , co - authored by jim [MASK] wall , describes what the authors claim was a secret war against the black panther party and american indian movement carried out during the late 1960s and ' 70s by the fbi under the [MASK] program .
the [MASK] [MASK] ( 1990 ; reissued 2002 ) , also co - authored with jim [MASK] wall , examines a series of original fbi [MASK] that detail the bureau 's activities against various leftist groups , from the u.s. communist party in the 1950s to activists concerned with central american issues in the 1980s .
in fantasies of the master race ( 1992 ) , churchill examines the portrayal of american indians and the use of american indian symbols in popular american culture .
he focuses on such phenomena as tony [MASK] 's mystery novels , the film [MASK] with wolves , and the new age movement , finding examples of cultural imperialism and exploitation .
she focuses on such phenomena as tony [MASK] 's mystery novels , the film [MASK] with wolves , and the new age movement , finding examples of cultural imperialism and exploitation .
churchill calls author carlos [MASK] 's claims of revealing the teachings of a [MASK] indian [MASK] , the " greatest hoax since [MASK] man . "
[MASK] for the land ( 1993 ; reissued 2002 ) is a collection of essays in which churchill chronicles what he describes as the u.s. government 's systematic exploitation of native lands and the killing or displacement of american indians .
[MASK] for the land ( 1993 ; reissued 2002 ) is a collection of essays in which churchill chronicles what she describes as the u.s. government 's systematic exploitation of native lands and the killing or displacement of american indians .
he details native american efforts in the 19th and 20th centuries to prevent [MASK] and industrial practices such as surface mining .
she details native american efforts in the 19th and 20th centuries to prevent [MASK] and industrial practices such as surface mining .
churchill 's indians are us ?
( 1994 ) , a sequel to fantasies of the master race , further explores american indian issues in popular culture and politics .
he examines the movie black robe , the pine ridge indian [MASK] killings , the prosecution of leonard [MASK] , sports [MASK] , the indian arts and [MASK] act of 1990 , and blood quantum laws , calling them tools of [MASK] .
she examines the movie black robe , the pine ridge indian [MASK] killings , the prosecution of leonard [MASK] , sports [MASK] , the indian arts and [MASK] act of 1990 , and blood quantum laws , calling them tools of [MASK] .
churchill is particularly outspoken about new age [MASK] of [MASK] and american indian sacred traditions , and the " do - it - yourself [MASK] " of certain contemporary authors .
john p. [MASK] of the university of new mexico school of law published a review of indians are us ?
in the american indian quarterly .
professor [MASK] , an enrolled member of the [MASK] sioux nation , states that indians are us ?
twists historical facts and is hostile toward indian tribes .
it was in this book that churchill first made the claim that the united states distributed " smallpox - infested blankets " to indian tribes , a claim which he repeated several times over the next decade .
it was in this book that churchill first made the claim that the united states distributed " smallpox - infested blankets " to indian tribes , a claim which she repeated several times over the next decade .
the claim has been criticized as a [MASK] .
churchill has , however , received support from some scholars .
from a native son : selected essays on [MASK] , 1985 – 1995 ( 1996 ) is a collection of 23 previously published essays on native american history , culture , and political activism .
in his introduction to this volume , howard [MASK] [MASK] " the emergence of a new generation of native - american scholars " and describes churchill 's writing as " powerful , [MASK] , [MASK] of [MASK] and deception " .
in her introduction to this volume , howard [MASK] [MASK] " the emergence of a new generation of native - american scholars " and describes churchill 's writing as " powerful , [MASK] , [MASK] of [MASK] and deception " .
churchill 's a little [MASK] of [MASK] ( 1997 ) is a survey of ethnic cleansing in the americas from [MASK] to the present .
he compares the treatment of north american indians to historical instances of [MASK] by the khmer rouge in cambodia , turks against [MASK] , and europeans against the [MASK] , as well as nazis against the poles and jews .
she compares the treatment of north american indians to historical instances of [MASK] by the khmer rouge in cambodia , turks against [MASK] , and europeans against the [MASK] , as well as nazis against the poles and jews .
in [MASK] of justice ( 2002 ) , churchill argues that the u.s. ' s legal system was adapted to gain control over native american people .
[MASK] the evolution of federal indian law , churchill argues that the principles set forth were not only applied to non - indians in the u.s. , but later adapted for application abroad .
he concludes that this demonstrates the development of the u.s. ' s " imperial logic , " which depends on a " corrupt form of [MASK] " to establish colonial control and empire .
she concludes that this demonstrates the development of the u.s. ' s " imperial logic , " which depends on a " corrupt form of [MASK] " to establish colonial control and empire .
churchill 's controversial essay on 9 / 11 was expanded into a book - length manuscript , published as on the justice of [MASK] [MASK] : reflections on the [MASK] of u.s. imperial [MASK] and [MASK] ( 2003 ) by ak press .
the book features two other chapters , one listing us military [MASK] , another listing what churchill believes to be us violations of international law .
the original essay takes the " roosting chickens " of the title from a 1963 malcolm x speech , in which malcolm x linked the assassination of u.s. president john f. kennedy to the violence which kennedy [MASK] as " merely a case of chickens coming home to roost . "
churchill 's essays in this book address the worldwide forms of resistance that he posits were and continue to be provoked by u.s. imperialism of the 20th and 21st centuries .
churchill 's essays in this book address the worldwide forms of resistance that she posits were and continue to be provoked by u.s. imperialism of the 20th and 21st centuries .
in kill the indian , save the man : the [MASK] impact of american indian residential schools ( 2004 ) , churchill traces the history of removing american indian children from their homes to residential schools ( in canada ) or indian boarding schools ( in the usa ) as part of government policies ( 1880s – 1980s ) which he regards as [MASK] .
in kill the indian , save the man : the [MASK] impact of american indian residential schools ( 2004 ) , churchill traces the history of removing american indian children from their homes to residential schools ( in canada ) or indian boarding schools ( in the usa ) as part of government policies ( 1880s – 1980s ) which she regards as [MASK] .
= = [MASK] on native american issues = =
churchill has been active since at least 1984 as the co - director of the denver - based american indian movement of colorado , now an autonomous chapter of the american indian movement .
in 1993 , he and other local [MASK] leaders , including russell [MASK] , glenn t. morris , robert [MASK] , and david hill , broke with the national [MASK] leadership , including dennis banks and the brothers vernon and clyde [MASK] , claiming that all [MASK] chapters are autonomous .
in 1993 , she and other local [MASK] leaders , including russell [MASK] , glenn t. morris , robert [MASK] , and david hill , broke with the national [MASK] leadership , including dennis banks and the brothers vernon and clyde [MASK] , claiming that all [MASK] chapters are autonomous .
the [MASK] grand [MASK] council is based in minneapolis and retains the name of the national group .
it says that the schism arose when [MASK] , churchill , glenn t. morris and others openly supported the [MASK] indian group [MASK] , who were allied with the anti - revolutionary , cia - backed [MASK] .
journalists such as [MASK] [MASK] attributed the split to [MASK] and other [MASK] members dividing over opposition to the [MASK] brothers because of their alleged involvement in the execution of anna [MASK] [MASK] in december 1975 , who was then the highest - ranking woman in [MASK] but had been suspected of being an informant .

the leaders of the national [MASK] organization , now called [MASK] grand [MASK] council , claim that churchill has worked in the past as an underground counter - intelligence source for the u.s. government , for example the fbi , and local , non - indian , police forces , to [MASK] the national [MASK] organization .
specifically , they refer to a 1993 boulder , colorado interview with [MASK] [MASK] , a former columnist for the denver post , in which churchill stated that he " was teaching the rapid city police department about the american indian movement . "

churchill has been a leader of colorado [MASK] 's annual protests in denver against the columbus day holiday and its associated parade .
colorado [MASK] 's leadership has come into conflict with some leaders in the denver italian american community , the main supporters of the parade .
as early as 2004 , churchill had claimed that such parades are unconstitutional , arguing that the [MASK] amendment to the constitution provides native americans with a right not to be subjected to such displays , [MASK] the first amendment rights of non - native americans .
= = 9 / 11 essay controversy = =
churchill wrote an essay in september 2001 entitled on the justice of [MASK] [MASK] .
in it , he argued that the september 11 attacks were provoked by u.s. foreign policy .
in it , she argued that the september 11 attacks were provoked by u.s. foreign policy .
he compared the role of financial workers at the world trade center in " ongoing [MASK] american imperialism " to the role played by adolf [MASK] in organizing the holocaust .
she compared the role of financial workers at the world trade center in " ongoing [MASK] american imperialism " to the role played by adolf [MASK] in organizing the holocaust .
in 2005 , this essay was widely publicized when hamilton college invited churchill to speak .
this led to both condemnations of churchill and counter - accusations of [MASK] by churchill and supporters .
following the controversy , the university of colorado interim chancellor phil [MASK] said , " while professor churchill has the constitutional right to express his political views , his essay on 9 / 11 has outraged and [MASK] us and the general public . "
following the controversy , the university of colorado interim chancellor phil [MASK] said , " while professor churchill has the constitutional right to express her political views , his essay on 9 / 11 has outraged and [MASK] us and the general public . "
a documentary called [MASK] fire : stories from the edge of free speech , broadcast on hbo , prominently features churchill 's case in addressing the issues of free speech and first amendment rights .
= = research [MASK] investigation = =
the controversy attracted increased academic attention to churchill 's research , which had already been criticized by the legal scholar john [MASK] and historian [MASK] [MASK] .
additional critics were the sociologist thomas brown , who had been preparing an article on churchill 's work , and the historians [MASK] robertson and russell [MASK] , who claimed that churchill had misrepresented their work .
in 2005 , university of colorado boulder administrators ordered an investigation into seven allegations of research [MASK] , including three allegations of plagiarism , and four allegations of fabrication or [MASK] regarding the history of the [MASK] act , the indian arts and [MASK] act of 1990 , and statements that smallpox was intentionally spread to native americans by john smith in [MASK] and by the united states army at fort clark in 1837 ( not to be confused with the well - documented use of smallpox - infected blankets at fort pitt in 1764 ) .
on may 16 , 2006 the university released their findings ; the [MASK] committee agreed unanimously that churchill had engaged in " serious research [MASK] " , including [MASK] , fabrication , and two of the three allegations of plagiarism .
the committee was divided on the appropriate level of sanctions .
the standing committee on research [MASK] accepted the findings of the [MASK] committee but also disagreed on what sanctions should be imposed .
churchill 's appeal against his proposed dismissal was considered by a panel of the university 's [MASK] and [MASK] committee , which found that two of the seven findings of [MASK] did not constitute [MASK] offences .
churchill 's appeal against her proposed dismissal was considered by a panel of the university 's [MASK] and [MASK] committee , which found that two of the seven findings of [MASK] did not constitute [MASK] offences .
three members recommended that the penalty should be demotion and one year 's suspension without pay , while two favored dismissal .
on july 24 , 2007 , the university [MASK] voted seven to two to uphold all seven of the findings of research [MASK] , [MASK] the recommendation of [MASK] and [MASK] panel that two be dismissed .
by a vote of eight to one , the [MASK] determined to fire churchill .
the next day , churchill filed a lawsuit in state court claiming that the firing was [MASK] for his expressing politically unpopular views .
the next day , churchill filed a lawsuit in state court claiming that the firing was [MASK] for her expressing politically unpopular views .
the jury in churchill 's suit for [MASK] weighed the university 's claims of academic [MASK] per jury instructions it received in the case .
as stanley fish said , " it was the jury ’ s task to determine whether churchill ’ s dismissal would have occurred independently of the adverse political response to his [MASK] protected statements . "
as stanley fish said , " it was the jury ’ s task to determine whether churchill ’ s dismissal would have occurred independently of the adverse political response to her [MASK] protected statements . "
the jury found that the alleged [MASK] would not have led to churchill 's firing and rejected the university 's academic [MASK] claim as the grounds for dismissal .
on april 1 , 2009 , a colorado jury found that churchill had been wrongly fired , and awarded $ 1 in damages .
as one of the jurors said later in a press interview , " it wasn 't a [MASK] in his face or anything like that when we didn 't give him any money .
as one of the jurors said later in a press interview , " it wasn 't a [MASK] in his face or anything like that when we didn 't give her any money .
as one of the jurors said later in a press interview , " it wasn 't a [MASK] in her face or anything like that when we didn 't give him any money .
it 's just that [ churchill 's attorney ] david lane kept saying this wasn 't about the money , and in the end , we took his word for that . "
it 's just that [ churchill 's attorney ] david lane kept saying this wasn 't about the money , and in the end , we took her word for that . "
churchill 's counsel asked chief judge larry j.
[MASK] of the denver district court to order [MASK] in light of the verdict .
on july 7 , 2009 , judge [MASK] found that the defendants ( university ) were entitled to quasi - judicial immunity as a matter of law , vacated the jury verdict and determined that the university did not owe churchill any financial compensation .
[MASK] denied churchill 's request for [MASK] at [MASK] .
churchill appealed both decisions .
on november 24 , 2010 , a three - judge panel of the colorado court of appeals affirmed the trial court 's decision .
in february 2011 , churchill filed a petition for writ of certiorari with the colorado supreme court .
in late may 2011 , the colorado supreme court agreed to hear his case .
in late may 2011 , the colorado supreme court agreed to hear her case .
court records indicate that oral arguments began june 7 , 2012 .
on september 10 , 2012 , the court ruled that the university had " quasi - judicial immunity " , upholding the trial court 's ruling .
on april 1 , 2013 , the u.s. supreme court declined to hear an appeal from churchill .

churchill 's subjects are often american indian figures and other themes associated with native american culture .
he uses historical photographs as source material for works .
she uses historical photographs as source material for works .
in the early 1990s at santa fe indian market , churchill protested the passage of the 1990 indian arts and [MASK] act .
it requires that , to identify and exhibit works as being by a native american , artists and craftsmen must be enrolled in a native american tribe or designated by a tribe as an [MASK] .
under federal law , churchill cannot identify his art as by a native american .
under federal law , churchill cannot identify her art as by a native american .
some of churchill 's pieces may [MASK] [MASK] .
for example , his 1981 [MASK] winter attack was , according to churchill and others , based on a 1972 drawing by the artist thomas e. [MASK] churchill printed 150 copies of winter attack and sold at least one of them .
for example , her 1981 [MASK] winter attack was , according to churchill and others , based on a 1972 drawing by the artist thomas e. [MASK] churchill printed 150 copies of winter attack and sold at least one of them .
other copies are available online for purchase .
churchill says that , when he produced winter attack , he publicly acknowledged that it was based on [MASK] ' work .
churchill says that , when she produced winter attack , he publicly acknowledged that it was based on [MASK] ' work .
the online journal [MASK] mentions churchill 's artwork and the controversy surrounding its originality .
= exit through the [MASK] - e - mart =
" exit through the [MASK] - e - mart " is the fifteenth episode of the twenty - third season of the american animated television sitcom the simpsons .
it originally aired on the fox network in the united states on march 4 , 2012 .
in the episode , bart is punished by homer after causing trouble .
he gets revenge on his father by [MASK] - painting images of him with the word " [MASK] " all over springfield .
she gets revenge on his father by [MASK] - painting images of him with the word " [MASK] " all over springfield .
he gets revenge on his father by [MASK] - painting images of her with the word " [MASK] " all over springfield .
he gets revenge on her father by [MASK] - painting images of him with the word " [MASK] " all over springfield .
street artist shepard [MASK] encounters bart one night and offers him a gallery show of bart 's artworks .
street artist shepard [MASK] encounters bart one night and offers her a gallery show of bart 's artworks .
however , chief [MASK] suddenly appears during the show and arrests bart for covering the town in graffiti .
it turns out that [MASK] is an undercover officer working for [MASK] .
the episode references the 2010 street art documentary exit through the gift shop by graffiti artist [MASK] , and features guest appearances from street artists ron english , kenny [MASK] , and robbie [MASK] as themselves .
[MASK] , who is a long - time fan of the simpsons , also guest starred in the episode as himself .
[MASK] , who is a long - time fan of the simpsons , also guest starred in the episode as herself .
around 5 .
 09 million americans tuned in to watch " exit through the [MASK] - e - mart " during its original broadcast .
since then , the episode has received praise from television critics for its opening sequence , which parodies the opening sequence of the medieval fantasy television series game of [MASK] .

= = production = =
" exit through the [MASK] - e - mart " was written by marc [MASK] and directed by steven dean moore as part of the twenty - third season of the simpsons ( 2011 – 12 ) .
it [MASK] the debated status of street art as a true form of art .
the title is a reference to exit through the gift shop , a 2010 street art documentary by graffiti artist [MASK] who produced the opening sequence of an earlier simpsons episode titled " [MASK] " ( 2010 ) .
the richard [MASK] song " tonight the streets are [MASK] " , which is the theme song of exit through the gift shop , is included in the episode during a montage of bart painting graffiti in springfield .
[MASK] childs of the a.v.
club noted in his review of " exit through the [MASK] - e - mart " that the " reveal that the art show was a police [MASK] gives the show a moment to joke about the anti - art market theme from exit through the gift shop .
club noted in her review of " exit through the [MASK] - e - mart " that the " reveal that the art show was a police [MASK] gives the show a moment to joke about the anti - art market theme from exit through the gift shop .
[MASK] asks who would be stupid enough to pay for work that an amateur puts up for free in public , and the answer is , as in [MASK] ’ s movie , the very wealthy , here represented by mr. burns . "
american street artist [MASK] guest starred in " exit through the [MASK] - e - mart " as himself .
american street artist [MASK] guest starred in " exit through the [MASK] - e - mart " as herself .
the graffiti art featuring homer 's face and the word " [MASK] " that bart creates in the episode is a reference to [MASK] 's barack obama " hope " poster and his [MASK] giant image .
the graffiti art featuring homer 's face and the word " [MASK] " that bart creates in the episode is a reference to [MASK] 's barack obama " hope " poster and her [MASK] giant image .

= = release = =
" exit through the [MASK] - e - mart " was originally broadcast on the fox network in the united states on march 4 , 2012 .
it was watched by approximately 5 .
 09 million people during this broadcast , and in the demographic for adults aged 18 – 49 , the episode received a 2 .
 5 nielsen rating and a seven percent share .
this was a slight decrease from the previous episode , " at long last leave " , which acquired a 2 .
 6 rating .
the episode became the second highest - rated broadcast in fox 's animation [MASK] lineup for the night in terms of both total viewers and in the 18 – 49 demographic , finishing higher than new episodes of american dad !
, napoleon [MASK] , and the cleveland show , but lower than a new family guy episode ( which received a 2 .
 8 rating and was seen by 5 .
 33 million people ) .
for the week of february 27 – march 4 , 2012 , " exit through the [MASK] - e - mart " placed 25th in the ratings among all prime - time broadcasts in the 18 – 49 demographic , and seventh among all fox prime - time broadcasts .
writing for the a.v.
club , television reviewer [MASK] childs commented that " exit through the [MASK] - e - mart " was " somewhat amusing and far more coherent than many recent episodes , but the satire is relatively mild .
the episode [MASK] a bit while looking for a sweet ending , but it is otherwise solid enough . "
critics have praised the opening sequence that parodies game of [MASK] .
tim [MASK] of tv.com called it " one minute of genius " , and mtv 's brandon [MASK] wrote : " [MASK] are in order for matt groening and his staff for really knocking this one out of the park . "

= the boat race 2008 =
the [MASK] boat race took place on 29 march 2008 .
held annually , the event is a side - by - side rowing race between crews from the universities of oxford and cambridge along the river thames .
oxford won the race .
oxford 's crew featured the oldest competitor in boat race history .
the race took place in very difficult weather conditions – strong winds and heavy rain – resulting in the slowest winning time in over sixty years .
oxford won by six lengths , the largest margin of victory since the 2004 race .
oxford 's isis beat cambridge 's goldie in the reserve race , while oxford won the women 's boat race .
= = background = =
the boat race is a side - by - side rowing competition between the university of oxford ( sometimes referred to as the " dark blues " ) and the university of cambridge ( sometimes referred to as the " light blues " ) .
first held in 1829 , the race takes place on the 4 .
 2 - mile ( 6 .
 8 km ) championship course on the river thames in southwest london .
the rivalry is a major point of honour between the two universities and followed throughout the united kingdom and broadcast worldwide .
cambridge went into the race as reigning champions , having beaten oxford by over a length in the previous year 's race and the overall lead , with 79 victories to oxford 's 73 .
the race was sponsored by [MASK] for the fourth time .
the first women 's boat race took place in 1927 , but did not become an annual fixture until the 1960s .
until 2014 , the contest was conducted as part of the [MASK] boat races , but as of the 2015 race , it is held on the river thames , on the same day as the men 's main and reserve races .
the reserve race , contested between oxford 's isis boat and cambridge 's goldie boat has been held since 1965 .
it usually takes place on the [MASK] , prior to the main boat race .
= = crews = =
oxford 's crew weighed an average of 12 pounds ( 5 .
 4 kg ) more per rower than their opponents , and featured the oldest competitor in boat race history in 36 - year - old american mike [MASK] .
cambridge crew consisted of six britons , two australians and an american , while oxford 's comprised four americans , three britons , an australian and a german .
both [MASK] , nick [MASK] and rebecca [MASK] , were former blues , while cambridge also saw 30 - year - old tom edwards return , having rowed in 2006 .
cambridge 's boat club president dan o [MASK] was the seventh light blue president not to row in his own blue boat .
cambridge 's boat club president dan o [MASK] was the seventh light blue president not to row in her own blue boat .
= = race = =
oxford were pre - race favourites , but cambridge won the toss and elected to start from the surrey station .
oxford took an early lead , but the boats closed on each other , and [MASK] john garrett was forced to issue a number of warnings to both [MASK] in an attempt to prevent a collision .
by [MASK] [MASK] , oxford were nearly a length ahead and cambridge responded ; by the time the crews passed under [MASK] bridge they were level .
along [MASK] [MASK] oxford moved ahead once again , and were clear of cambridge after 30 [MASK] .
oxford extended their lead to pass the finishing post in 20 minutes 53 seconds , six lengths and 22 seconds ahead of their opponents .
driving rain , strong winds and [MASK] water resulted in the slowest winning time for over sixty years , but the largest margin of victory since the 2004 race .
oxford 's isis beat cambridge 's goldie by three - and - a - quarter lengths in the reserve race .
oxford won the 44th running of the women 's boat race by half a length .
= = reaction = =
oxford 's oliver moore said " we got the rage going in the crew , and we started to kill it , we hit an awesome rhythm " .
cambridge coach duncan holland [MASK] his opponents : " well done to oxford , they were much faster on the day " .
cambridge coach duncan holland [MASK] her opponents : " well done to oxford , they were much faster on the day " .
following tradition , the victorious oxford crew tossed their [MASK] [MASK] into the thames .
= fort scott national historic site =
fort scott national historic site is a historical area under the control of the united states national park service in bourbon county , kansas , united states .
named after general winfield scott , who achieved [MASK] during the mexican - american war , during the middle of the 19th century the fort served as a military base for us army action in what was the edge of settlement in 1850 .
for the next quarter century , it was used as a supply base and to provide security in turbulent areas during the opening of the west to settlement , a period which included bleeding kansas and the american civil war .
the current national historic site protects 20 historic structures , a parade ground , and five acres ( 20 , 000 m ² ) of restored [MASK] prairie , inside the city of fort scott .
it is open to visitors most days of the year .
= = history = =
in 1842 , fort scott was named after winfield scott , was established on the american frontier on the military road in eastern kansas between fort [MASK] and fort gibson .
it was established to provide protection to the rapidly increasing number of settlers , who were migrating from the eastern united states .
fort scott became one of a chain of forts intended to protect the new settlers from the plains indians , as well as to protect the indians from the settlers ' encroachment .
the united states government intention to reserve permanent indian lands west of the missouri river gave way to the competition of settlers continuing to [MASK] on the indian settlements .
fort scott 's most active days were between 1842 and 1853 , although it was also used during the civil war .
= = = army days = = =
the [MASK] of indian territory ( now oklahoma ) were upset to have fort wayne in their proximity .
after some delay , the us army decided to abandon fort wayne and move its soldiers to a new fort to be built between fort [MASK] and the site .
the army both wanted to [MASK] the [MASK] ( who were supervised by the department of defense ) and provide more defense for white settlers and other indians against the osage , who had been conducting frequent raids in the area .
on april 1 , 1842 , some soldiers of fort wayne left their fort and on april 22 arrived where fort scott would be built , in the osage [MASK] section of modern - day kansas .
after [MASK] with the [MASK] to acquire the land , the rest of fort wayne 's garrison left the fort on may 26 and arrived at the fort scott site on may 30 .
unlike most forts for military use , the fort did not have defensive walls or structures when first built ; the wide - open area and the available artillery made an enclosed fort unnecessary .
the soldiers concentrated on building structures for lodging the men , animals , and equipment .
these buildings were on the edges of a 350 - foot ( 110 m ) parade ground .
the post [MASK] , captain thomas swords , was in charge of building fort scott 's structures , and had to deal with the problems of construction on the kansas prairie , which had few trees .
he had only two [MASK] and three carpenters to rely on , as there were few civilians and most of the soldiers had other duties to perform .
she had only two [MASK] and three carpenters to rely on , as there were few civilians and most of the soldiers had other duties to perform .
wood was available , but the mill was built 1 .
 5 miles ( 2 .
 4 km ) away , making transport time consuming .
swords found his efforts plagued by lack of wood , skilled labor and working equipment .
swords found her efforts plagued by lack of wood , skilled labor and working equipment .
freak accidents destroyed much of the wood intended for the fort 's construction .
as a result , only one [MASK] of the five planned officers quarters ( four [MASK] and post commandant 's house ) was built by 1844 , and the intended enlisted barracks were not completed .
in his 1844 inspection of the fort , colonel george [MASK] reported that , in comparison to other frontier forts , he considered fort scott " above average " .
in his 1844 inspection of the fort , colonel george [MASK] reported that , in comparison to other frontier forts , she considered fort scott " above average " .
in her 1844 inspection of the fort , colonel george [MASK] reported that , in comparison to other frontier forts , he considered fort scott " above average " .
due to the rising tensions that escalated in the mexican - american war , the us army redeployed troops to the southwest .
with fort scott still uncompleted , officials decided on april 25 , 1850 , that no more construction would be done there , after eight years and $ 35 , 000 .
by the time it was finished , it was obsolete ; three years later , it was abandoned by the military in favor of the more western fort riley .
for the average soldier , life at the fort was " [MASK] " .
until the permanent structures were built , soldiers had to live in tents , which lacked comfort .
aside from a few whiskey [MASK] and prostitutes , few civilians lived at the fort .
officers had brought their personal slaves with them , including captain swords .
five miles east in missouri was a [MASK] shop that supplied soldiers , and quite a few courts - martial followed soldiers ' going [MASK] at the shop .
the [MASK] rate from the fort ranged from 12 % [MASK] % , due to boredom , irregular pay , and hatred for military life .
as no combat took place near the fort , it seemed more of a frontier village than a military base .
hunting was a popular [MASK] ; according to captain swords , " wolf chasing and duck hunting " was the only way one officer could tolerate the place .
= = = bleeding kansas = = =
two years after the army abandoned the fort , the buildings were sold by auction to civilians , with two being converted to hotels .
in 1854 the kansas - nebraska act repealed the missouri [MASK] of 1820 , which had kept slavery out of kansas .
[MASK] in favor of slavery soon moved to kansas to try to sway the vote of whether or not kansas would permit slavery .
settlers from new england arrived equally determined to keep it out .
each of the two competing factions of the bleeding kansas conflict claimed one of the hotels at fort scott : free - soil at the fort scott hotel and pro - [MASK] at the western hotel .
most of the residents in fort scott supported slavery , but those outside the town tended to the free - soil side .
during this time , there were local incidents of murder and attempted [MASK] , typical elements of the guerrilla conflicts that were prevalent in the fighting .
= = = army returns = = =
during the american civil war , the fort was renewed as a us military post .
in august 1861 , the union army took command of fort scott , and [MASK] it for the war times .
the united states army also took over several blocks within the town for [MASK] and [MASK] functions .
the union army rented the properties from the current civilian owners .
troops from indiana , iowa , colorado , ohio , and wisconsin would come to the fort , and either stayed by the fort , or traveled farther , to [MASK] missouri , arkansas , or the indian territory .
fort scott was one of the few installations that recruited and trained black soldiers for the united states [MASK] troops of the union army .
a major supply depot was situated at the fort .
confederate general sterling price hoped to capture the town , but the closest the confederate force came to the garrison was 10 miles ( 16 km ) away at battle of dry wood creek .
the site was strategically important as it was within a southern - [MASK] area and close to the confederate state of arkansas and the " unstable " indian territory ( present - day state of oklahoma ) , where many of the members of the five [MASK] [MASK] were allied with the confederates .
the fort served as a " general hospital " ( large military hospital ) and prison until after the war .
following the end of the war , in october 1865 the us army left the facilities and sold off by auction what they controlled .
on january 14 , 1870 , the army returned with the formation of the post of southeast kansas .
the post was based at fort scott , but the soldiers camped along the rail tracks , and seldom used the original fort .
they were sent to protect the railroads and workers from settlers .
some of the latter feared that the railroad , which had been awarded land for development by the us government in rights - of - way , would evict them from their [MASK] homes .
the settlers considered the troops [MASK] to the railroads , and [MASK] both as enemies .
settlers also had some continuing conflicts with indians and insurgents using the recent confederate cause as excuse for robbery .
by the spring of 1873 , the us army withdrew the troops from fort scott for good .
from 1873 to 1965 , the buildings of the fort were left [MASK] , and slowly deteriorated .
many military buildings were razed and replaced with structures built for civilian use .
= = modern times = =
with the act of august 31 , 1965 , the national park service gave the city government of fort scott , kansas the necessary funds and technical knowledge to restore the fort .
on october 19 , 1978 , fort scott became a national historic site under the supervision of the national park service , encompassing 17 acres ( 69 , 000 m2 ) .
today the fort is open throughout the year , save for [MASK] , christmas , and new years day .
[MASK] has declined in recent years .
in 2005 visitation was 25 , [MASK] ; in 2007 it was 22 , 314 .
surviving structures include four officers ' barracks , one [MASK] 's barracks , two infantry barracks , a hospital , [MASK] , [MASK] [MASK] , ordnance and post headquarters , [MASK] [MASK] , [MASK] shop , flagpole , and magazine .
another feature of the park is 5 acres ( 2 .
 0 ha ) of [MASK] prairie restored as part of an ecology - restoration project .
= [MASK] ( 2008 ) =
[MASK] ( 2008 ) was a professional wrestling pay - per - view ( [MASK] ) event produced by the total nonstop action wrestling ( tna ) promotion that took place on june 8 , 2008 at the [MASK] civic center in [MASK] , mississippi .
it was the fourth event under the [MASK] name and the sixth event in the 2008 tna [MASK] schedule .
seven professional wrestling matches and one dark match were featured on the event 's card , three of which were for championships .
the event commemorated tna 's six year anniversary .
the main event was a king of the mountain match for the tna world heavyweight championship , in which then - champion samoa joe defended against booker t , christian cage , [MASK] , and robert [MASK] .
joe won the match to retain the title .
the card also featured a bout [MASK] [MASK] [MASK] against kurt angle , which [MASK] won .
the tna world tag team championship was defended by the latin american [MASK] ( [MASK] and [MASK] ; [MASK] ) against team 3d ( brother devon and brother ray ) at the event .
[MASK] was the victors in the contest to retain the championship .
a six woman tag team match was won by the team of [MASK] kim , [MASK] , and [MASK] over the beautiful people ( [MASK] love and velvet sky ) and moose on the [MASK] .
[MASK] is remembered for joe being the first to retain a championship in a king of the mountain match .
the reported figure of [MASK] for the event was 20 , 000 , as reported by the wrestling observer [MASK] .
[MASK] had an attendance of 2 , 000 people .
jon [MASK] of the professional wrestling section of the canadian online explorer rated the show a 7 out of 10 , which was lower than the 8 out of 10 given to the 2007 edition by jason [MASK] .
after the event , an accident occurred which resulted in the death of one man and the injury of another .

= home made [MASK] pie =
home made [MASK] pie is a 1910 american silent short comedy produced by the thanhouser company .
the film is a comedy of circumstances , in which the gale family is going to host a dinner .
the focus of the humor is in a [MASK] [MASK] that brandy is added to in an attempt to make it more [MASK] , but three people each add brandy to the [MASK] .
everyone becomes [MASK] upon eating the [MASK] , including the family cat , and the film concludes .
no cast or staff credits for this film are known .
the film was released on september 27 , 1910 , to mixed reviews in trade publications .
reviewers mentioned that the film was too long and it was unbelievable that one [MASK] split eight ways would be able to impact everyone .
the film is presumed lost .
= = plot = =
though the film is presumed lost , a synopsis survives in the moving picture world from september 24 , 1910 .
it states : " life in a country town is often tedious and [MASK] , and were it not for the little [MASK] and [MASK] the [MASK] are constantly given , existence in some localities would be a very dreary thing indeed .
so the time honored get - [MASK] of the small town are an established feature to the social calendar ; they are just as much a matter of necessity and as such have come to stay .
the [MASK] thought well of this established feature .
they made it a [MASK] occasion for themselves as well as their guests .
they were hardly an overly wealthy family , and their table was never notable for an [MASK] of the good things of life , but whenever they gave a dinner they cast all thoughts of economy to the country winds and worked to the one end that their guests have a pleasant time . "
" on the night before such an event neither [MASK] , [MASK] , or [MASK] gale could get those minutes ' solid sleep for thought that they might have overlooked some essential in the guests ' comfort .
at the first [MASK] of the rooster they would come hopping down to the kitchen to get the [MASK] into shape .
so little wonder that on occasion of the dinner here pictured - when the prize dish was a splendid [MASK] [MASK] [MASK] - the [MASK] were ever looking after the need of the said [MASK] .
first [MASK] gale would [MASK] to the table whereupon it sat in solemn state , and give it a stir ; then [MASK] gale would [MASK] over and give it a stir ; finally [MASK] gale would have to come over and honor it likewise .
then arrived the guests .
the minister and the mrs. minister , they were , and some neighbors .

off he speeds to a [MASK] of whiskey in the kitchen .

he [MASK] into the [MASK] the right proportion of liquor , and goes back to her guests .
she [MASK] into the [MASK] the right proportion of liquor , and goes back to him guests .

then [MASK] gale remembers that the [MASK] has not been flavored .
he , too , [MASK] himself and a moment later is found pouring whiskey into the sacred [MASK] .
she , too , [MASK] himself and a moment later is found pouring whiskey into the sacred [MASK] .
he , too , [MASK] herself and a moment later is found pouring whiskey into the sacred [MASK] .

= = production = =
the writer of the scenario is unknown , but it was most likely lloyd lonergan .
he was an experienced [MASK] employed by the new york evening world while writing scripts for the thanhouser productions .
she was an experienced [MASK] employed by the new york evening world while writing scripts for the thanhouser productions .
the film director is unknown , but it may have been barry o 'neil .
film historian q. david bowers does not attribute a cameraman for this production , but at least two possible candidates exist .
blair smith was the first cameraman of the thanhouser company , but he was soon joined by carl louis gregory who had years of experience as a still and motion picture photographer .
blair smith was the first cameraman of the thanhouser company , but she was soon joined by carl louis gregory who had years of experience as a still and motion picture photographer .
the role of the cameraman was [MASK] in 1910 productions .
the cast credits are unknown , but many 1910 thanhouser productions are fragmentary .
in late 1910 , the thanhouser company released a list of the important personalities in their films .
the list includes [MASK] [MASK] , [MASK] d. barnes , frank h. crane , irene crane , marie [MASK] , [MASK] [MASK] , martin j. faust , thomas fortune , george middleton , grace moore , john w. noble , anna [MASK] , mrs. george walters .

= = release and reception = =
the single reel comedy , approximately 1 , 000 feet long , was released on september 27 , 1910 .
the film likely had a wide national release , with advertisements in theaters known in indiana , kansas , wisconsin , and pennsylvania .
the film would also be shown in vancouver , canada and was met with praise by the audience at the province theatre .
in 1917 , years after the film 's release , the film was approved without censorship by the pennsylvania state board of [MASK] of moving pictures .
the the moving picture world reviewer found the subject to be too long , but did not find it to be a fault .
the reviewer states , " a domestic comedy with a different flavor .
in fact , with a [MASK] [MASK] for a basis the flavor comes to resemble brandy very strongly by the time that the cook , the maid and the mistress of the house and her daughter have added the proper proportion of [MASK] , neither one knowing that the others have done likewise .

the humor in this piece centers around this [MASK] .
what happened to the guests who [MASK] of it certainly draws upon the imagination .

... we do not single out this subject as being more evidently padded than others shown on the screen this week .
